entered; The Romans destitute of a General retired home; and the Goths, having
lost their chief men, kept close in their Garrisons, having no confidence in
the Fortifications of Salonae, and the Romans inhabiting it being not their
friends. Theodatus upon the news hereof slighted the Ambassadors, being
naturally slippery and faithless; The present fortune ever drew him either
into senseless fears not suitable to the occasion, or into excessive
presumption. As now upon the news of Mundus, and Mauritius, he was exalted,
not proportionably to the accident, and he flowted the Ambassadors, being now
with him. Peter once expostulating his breach of agreements, he called him into
public, and said, That Ambassadors indeed are persons of respect, and by all
men honored; but that they preserve this privilege, and the honor of their
places by moderation only. For men use to put an Ambassador to death if he
demean himself insolently to a Kings person, or lie with another man's Wife.
Theodatus said not thus, as thinking Peter to kave layen with any man's Wife;
but to show that there were crimes in an Ambassador punishable with death. But
the Ambassadors made him this answer. O Prince of the Goths! upon such
mistaken, unsound pretenses do not you violate the persons of Ambassadors. An
Ambassador, if he would, cannot be an Adulterer; who can hardly have so much as
the use of water, without the privity of those that guard him. For words
(though harsh) if he utter such as he received from his Master, not he, but his
Master is to bear the blame; An Ambassadors only part is, to execute the
service. And we, what we have received from the Emperor, will utter it all,
and you are patiently to hear us. If you be angry, you have no help, but to
abuse men that are Ambassadors. It is high time for you to perform your
Covenants with the Emperor; For which purpose we are sent hither. His letters
to your self you have; another, directed to the principal Goths, we will
deliver only to themselves. The great Officers being present, bad them give the
Letter to Theodatus; which was thus. Our care is, to receive you into our
State; for which you ought to rejoice; For you shall mingle with us, not for
your diminution, but to add more value to you. We invite not the Goths to
Countries strange, and unknown to them; but to our selves, sometimes their
familiars, though for a time divided from them. Athanasius and Peter are sent
about this business, whom you are to assist in all things.

CHAP. VI.
THeodatus perused all the letters, but refused to perform the agreements, and
put a strait guard upon the Ambassadors. The Emperor advertized hereof, and of
the successes in Dalmatia, sent into Illyrium Constantianus, Master of his
Horse, to gather an Army, and attempt Salonae; and he directed Belisarius
without delay to pass into Italy, and make War upon the Goths. Constantianus
at Epidamnus stayed some time, and raised Forces. Gripas in the mean time had
entered Salonae with the Goths. And Constantianus having made his preparations,
left Epidamnus with his Fleet, and Ragusa stands now where about this was, upon
the gulf of Venice.
cast Anchor at Epidaurus, standing to the right hand, as you sail into the
Jonian gulf. Some here sent by Gripas to discover, seeing the land Army, and
the Ships covering (as they imagined) Land and Sea, reported to Gripas, that
Constantianus had many thousands. He afraid, thought it not best to encounter
them; Neither would he willingly be besieged by the Emperors Army, Master of
the Sea. The walls of Salonae much decayed troubled him too; and he could not
trust the Inhabitants.

For these reasons he removed from thence, and encamped in a champian between
Salonae, and the City of Croton. Constantianus wayed Anchor from Epidaurus,
and came before Lys^ne upon the gulf. Hence he sent some to discover, and
report concerning Gripas; from whom understanding how it was, The Gothic war
began in the Spring, which begins exactly 11. Martii, the Sun emring into
Aries. Justinian began to reign alone after Justins death on the first of July,
says Evagrius: And with Justin the 3. day before Easter. vide Secret. Hist.
cap. 7.
he made for Salonae. Where arrived, he landed, and rested his Army upon the
place; and he directed Siphyllas, one of his Lifeguard, with 500. chosen men,
to possess a narrow passage in the Suburbs of Salonae; which he performed. And
the next day Constantianus entered the City with the Land army, and the Fleet
lay before it at Anchor. He took care of the walls, and repaired the decays;
And Gripas seeing the Romans masters of Salonae, seven days after rose, and
transported the Goths over to Ravenna. So Constantianus took in Dalmatia, and
Liburnia, and the Goths there inhabiting. And then ended the Winter, and the
first year of this War, written by Procopius.

Belisarius leaving Garrisons in Syracusa, and Annus. 2. B^ll. Goth. incipit.
being in 10. Iustiniani. (...) Ann. Dom. 536.
Panormus, passed over his Army from Messinae to Rhegium, where the Poets fain
Scylla, and Charybdis to have been. The Inhabitants came in to him daily, their
Towns having been long without walls, and without Garrisons; and they hated the
Goths, weary (it seems) of the present Government. Ebrimus also a Goth revolted
to him, with his Followers, having married Theodatus Daughter, Theodenanthe. He
was sent to the Emperor, and besides other bounties, made a Patrician. The
Army marched from Rhegium through Brutia, and Lucania, and the Navy kept close
to the Coast. In Campania they sat down before Naples, a strong maritime
City, with a great Garrison in it of Goths. The Fleet Belisarius commanded to
lie at Anchor, without Bow-shot in the Harbor. Then he took the Castle in the
Suburbs by composition. He gave the Citizens leave to send him some chief men,
to acquaint him with what they had to say, and hearing his Propositions, to
report them to their Communalty. The Napolitans sent him Stephanus, who spoke
thus to Belisarius. It is not just, O General! to bring your Army upon Romans,
and who never wronged you, having a small City, and the Barbarians within our
Masters; that we cannot do as we would: Nay the Soldiers of our Garrison have
lest under Theodatus their Wives and Children, and most precious things, that
by practicing upon us, they should not more betray our Town, then themselves.
But if we may say the truth without mincing, you have advised ill to invade us.
For take Rome first, and Naples is yours without difficulty; but repulsed from
thence, you can never be sure of this Town. So that you will spend time
impertinently in this siege. Belisarius made Stephanus this answer. We mean
not to refer it to the Napolitans, whether We be here upon good, or bad
advice. We desire you to consult of what concerns your selves, and to choose
your own best advantage. Entertain therefore the Emperors Army, come to
free you and all Italy; and do not prefer the most sorrowful things. Such as
make War to shake off slavery, or other base condition, gain in vanquishing,
with the victory, freedom from misery; and being vanquished are yet comforted
for not having willingly submitted to a wretched fortune. But such as may be
free without fighting, and yet will fight to establish their own servitude; if
they conquer, they do but more ruin themselves; and if they have the worse,
they add to their other wretchedness, the calamity of a defeat. This he said
to the Napolitans. To the Goths we give Liberty either to serve the Emperor
with us, or to retire home without harm. If you slight all this, and employ
your arms against us, we shall use you as Enemies: But if the Napolitans will
join with the Emperor, and be rid of a sharp servitude; I will pawn my faith
for such conditions, as the Sicilians had, who cannot say we are forsworn.
This Belisarius commanded Stephanus to impart to the people; promising him
great rewards, if he drew them to the Emperor. Stephanus acquainted the City
with these propositions, and with his own opinion of the inconvenience of
resisting the Emperor. With him joined Antiochus a Syrian merchant, who had
long dwelt there, and was esteemed a very wise and an honest man.

CHAP. VII.
BUt Pastor and Asclepiodotus, two Orators much esteemed in Naples, and friends
to the Goths, to cross the treaty, drew the people to propound great things,
and many, and that Belisarius would swear to their present obtaining the same:
And they gave to Stephanus demands in writing, which they thought Belisarius
would never yield to. He went to the Camp, showed the writing to the General,
demanding if he would grant those propositions, and take his Oath accordingly.
He promised to grant all, and sent him away. The Napolitans embraced the
Capitulation, and commanded the army to be received into the City: which (said
they) may safely be done, the Sicilians giving us ample proof, who for
Barbarian Tyrants have chosen the Empire of Justinian, and are become free men,
and eased of all greivance. And then in much tumult they went to open the
gates; which troubled the Goths: but being not able to hinder it, they kept out
of the way. But Pastor and Asclepiodotus assembled the people, and spoke thus.
It is not strange for a City-multitude to ruin it self, when they will
resolve in the general absolutely, without communicating with the better sort.
But being with you upon the point of destruction, we cannot but contribute this
last advise to our country. You are running to deliver your selves, and City to
Belisarius, who promises much, and will solemnly swear to it. If he could
assure you, that he shall conquer in this war, no man can gainsay, but that
these things will be good for us. It were foolish not to gratify him that is
to be our Lord; but since this is uncertain, and since none can secure the
Resolutions of Fortune; consider for what miseries you may take this pains. For
the Goths overcoming, will punish you for having done them the greatest
despite, revolting thus not forced by necessity, but as willing cowards. Nay
even Belisarius himself being Victor will esteem us false and Traitors to our
Princes; and as such, we must expect a perpetual garrison upon us. A Traitors
service pleases for the present with the victory obtained, but afterward the
Victor suspects, fears, and hates his Benefactor, having with him the marks of
his falsehood. But continuing true to the Goths, and valiant in this danger, if
they conquer, they will do us many good turns; and Belisarius getting the
victory will pardon us. No understanding man will punish a good affection
failing of success. And why fear you this seige? being in no wants, nor blockt
up; but at home, secured by these walls and soldiers? If Belisarius could hope
to force us, he would not come to this capitulation: and if he would do justly,
and us good, he would not fright us thus, and establish a power upon our
wronging the Goths, but come roundly to a battle with them, that we without
danger or Treason might follow the Conqueror. Having thus said, they produced
Jews, who assured the town should want nothing: and the Goths promised to
guard them safely. Wherewith persuaded, they defied Belisarius; who fell to
assault, and was often repulsed with losie of many, and even of his valiantest
men. For the walls what by reason of the sea, and for the steep ground, were
unaccessible, and not to be approacht by an enemy. And the cutting of the
Aquaeduct by Belisarius troubled not the Napolitans much, their wells within
supplying their uses: And they sent to Theodatus to Rome, to send them
succors. Theodatus being a coward (as I have said) made little preparation for
a war: and he had an accident (they say, but not credibly to my conceit)
which put him into great fear. Theodatus was acquainted ever with men thar
pretend to foretell things to come; and being now perplexed with the present
affairs (when men use most to run after prophesies) he asked an Hebrew,
famous for such things, what would be the event of the War. He directed him to
shut up three half scores of Hoggs severally, and to each ten to give several
names, of Goths, Romans, and the Emperors Soldiers, and so for a certain
number of days to let them alone. Theodatus at the appointed day went to the
sties, to see the Hoggs. Those which were called Goths, he found all dead, save
two: Those called the Emperors Soldiers, were almost all alive: And those
who bare the name of Romans were half living, and all with their hairs fallen
off. Theodatus by this divined the success of the war, and was afraid:
perceiving that one half of the Romans should perish, and all loose their
Estates; that the Goths should be vanquished; and reduced to a small remnant,
and that the Emperor should get the victory with the loss of few. Upon this
he was afraid to fight with Belisarius; who besieging Naples was troubled, not
thinking it would yield, and being not able to force the difficulty of the
place: and his loss to time vexed him, fearing to be put to set upon Theodatus
and Rome in the winter. But having directed the army to rise, and being thus
perplexed, he had this fortune,

CHAP. VIII.
AN Isaurian, curious to see the structure of the Aquaeduct, and how it brought
water to the City, entered it far from the city where Belisarius had cut it;
(which had made it dry) and being come in near to the town-wall, he met with a
Rock to which the Aquaeduct was joined, and through it was cut a vault, not
sufficient for a man to enter, but only to let through the water; so that there
the Aquaeduct was not passable, especially by a man armed with shield and
corslet. The Isaurian observing it, conceived that by widening the vault,
forces might enter; and being himself an obscure man, unknown to the
Commanders, he revealed it to Paucaris, a Targettier of the guard to
Belisarius, who told it to Belisarius; and he revived with the news promised
the man money, and persuaded him to take some Isaurians, and with speed and
secrecy to cut the rock wider. Paucaris, with some choice Isaurians fit to
work, entered silently the Aquaeduct, and being come to the Rock and narrow
Vault, they wrought, not cutting it with hatchets and axes, lest the noise
should discover them, but paring and filing it with instruments of iron; and in
short time there was room for a man with his shield and corslet on to go
through. All being ready, Belisarius considered, how the army entering by force,
there would be slaughter and such things as befall places forced by Enemies. He
sent therefore for Stephanus, and said to him thus. I have been at the taking
of many Cities, and and am acquainted with the usual accidents therein. They
kill the men of all ages; the women they vouchsafe not to kill, though they beg
it, but lead them away for base and pitiful uses. The children without other
Education must learn to serve their greatest enemies, whose hands are stained
with their Fathers blood. I speak not of the fire which will consume your
goods, and the beauty of your city. Beholding as in a glass in other ruined
cities, the miseries of Naples, I pity it. For my engines are ready, wherewith I
shall not fail to take it. And while I am General; I would not have an
ancient city, long inhabited with Christians and Romans, come to this fortune:
the rather having in the army Barbarians, enraged for the loss of brothers and
kindred, whom I shall not be able to restrain; if they enter by hostility. So
that choose the best for your selves while you may, and avoid this calamity;
which happening (as it will) blame not fortune, but your own Counsels.
Stephanus weeping, reported to the People this Speech of Belisarius: But they
(whose Subjection to the Emperor was to be accompanied with their mischief)
feared not, nor thought of yiedling.

Then did Belisarius about Evening choose out 400. men, and gave the Command of
them to Magnus, a Captain of Horse, and Ennes, Commander of the Isaurians,
whom he directed to stand ready with their Corselets on, and with Swords and
Shields, till he should give the Signal. And he sent for Bessas, to advise
with him of some things of Importance. Far within night, he told Magnus and
Ennes the business, showed them the place, where he had cut the Aquaeduct, and
commanded affright the Town, and to signify to him what they did. Himself
had many scaling Ladders in readiness. They entered the Aquaeduct, and went
toward the Town, and himself, with Bessas and Photius, staid in the place,
directing the Army to stand with their Arms ready; and keeping many of the
Valiantest men about himself. More then the one half who were to enter,
apprehending the danger, came back to the General, and Magnus with them: after
much exhorting them to go on, but not prevailing, Belisarius rated them, and
gave Magnus 200. other of his own Retinew, whom Photius would have led, and
first entered the vault; but Belisarius forbad him. The Run-awaies ashamed at
the reprehensions of Belisarius, took heart, and followed the rest. Belisarius,
least the Enemies sentinels upon the Turret next the Aquaeduct should discover
them, went thither, and bad Bessas talk with the Goths in their own Language,
that they might not hear the clashing of the Arms. Bessas aloud called to
them to yield, promising many Advantages; And they flouted him with scornful
Speeches against Belisarius, and the Emperor. The Aquaeduct is not only
covered without the Walls, but so continues with a high Arch of Brick a great
way within; that Magnus and Ennes being within the City, could not imagine
where-about they were, nor find where to get up, till their fore-most men
came, where they found the Roof uncovered, and where stood a Cottage, and in
it dwelt a Woman alone, and very poor; and at the top of the Aquaeduct grew an
Olive Tree. The men perceiving the Sky, and themselves in the midst of the
City, would willingly get up, but could not with their Arms, the Building
being high, and without Steps. Being long in doubt, and beginning to be crowded
with the Company pressing behind them; one of them, having a mind to make
trial, laid down his Arms, and clambered up; and finding the poor Woman in
the Cottage, threatened to kill her, if she made any noise. She astonished, sat
mute; and he tying a Rope to the Olive Tree, threw the other end into the
Aquaeduct, by which the Soldiers mounted one by one. All being up, and but a
fourth part of the Night remaining, they ascended the Wall, and killed the
Sentinels upon two Turrets on the North side, where Belisarius, Bessas, and
Photius stood expecting the Event. They called them to the Walls with their
Trumpets, and Belisarius set to the scaling Ladders, commanding the Soldiers
to mount. The Ladders were too short, the Workmen having not made them upon
view, and so not judging of a just scantling. But they tied two together, and
so mounted the Battlements. That part of the Walls next the Sea, where the
Jews guarded, the Soldiers could not ascend. For the Jews had offended the
Enemy, in hindering a peaceable surrender of the Town, and so being hopeless,
(if subdued) they fought valiantly, though the Town were entered; and they
endured beyond Expectation. But day appearing, and being charged behind by
some who were entered already, they fled; and Naples was absolutely taken, and
the Gates set open; where the rest of the Army entered. Those who were quartered
Eastward, having no Ladders, burnt open the Gates there, the Guards being all
run away. A great Slaughter was made; all being angry, and especially such as
had Brothers, or Kins-men slain in the former Assaults, and they killed all,
sparing no Age; broke into the Houses, and made the Women and Children Slaves,
and pillaged the Goods; principally the Massagetes, who spared not the
Churches, but killed many who fled into them; till Belisarius rode about and
restrained them, and assembling the Army, spoke thus. Since God has given us
Victory, and the glory of subduing a City, heretofore impregnable; let us not
prove unworthy of the Favor, but by our Clemency to the Vanquished, make it
appear, that we have justly overcome them. Do not without limit extend your
hatred to the Napolitans, beyond the Rules of War. No Conquerours continue
hating the Vanquished; if you kill them now, you are not rid of Enemies, but
indamaged by the death fo your Subjects. So that do them no further harm, nor
gratify you own Anger. It is base, having conquered your Enemies, to be
overcome by your own Passion. Take the Wealth, as the Reward of your Valor;
but restore the Women and Children, and let the Conquered find by the Events,
what kind of Friends they lost by their own ill Counsels. Belisarius having
thus said, released all their Women and Children, and other Prisoners, without
enduring any Dishonor, and reconciled the Soldiers to them. So in the same
day the Napolitans had the Fortune to be made Slaves, and to recover their
Liberty, with the most precious of their Goods; having hid their Gold, and
things of Value from the Enemy, under ground, and so found them upon the
Restitution of their Houses. Thus ended this Seige, having lasted twenty days.

CHAP. IX.
THE Gothish Garrison, being 800. men, Belisarius took, and hurt not, but
respected them as his own Soldiers. Pastor, when he saw the Town taken, fell
dead of an Apoplexy, having never had any touch of it before; Asclepiodotus his
associate, with some other chief men, came to Belisarius, whom Stephanus
seeing, Thou vildest of all men (quoth he) what mischief have thou done thy
Countrymen, and sold their safety for Barbarians Favor? If they had
prospered, thou would have claimed Rewards, and accused us of Conspiracy with
the Romans, who gave the best Counsels. And now the City being the Emperors,
and we preserved by this man's Virtue, dare thou thus foolishly come to him?
as if clear of all disservice to the Neapolitans, and the Imperial Army?
Stephanus in passion for the Disaster uttered this. But he answered him; Worthy
Sir, you unwittingly extol me, in that you rail at me for my affection to the
Goths. None loves his Superiors in danger, but from a constant mind. Me the
Victors shall find a Defender of their State, as lately their Enemy. A
faithful man changes not his Mind with Fortune, nor entertaines Propositions
from Enemies in an alteration. But he that is sick of Inconstancy, renounces
his Friends upon his first fears. Having thus said, and retiring, the common
people followed and charged him with their Sufferings, and left him not, till
they had killed him, and torn him in pieces. And they entered Pastors house,
searching, and not beleiving the Servants Affirmation of his Death, till they
saw his Body, which they crucified in the Suburbs; then excused their doings
to Belisarius upon such just provocation; and obtaining Pardon, went home.

But the Goths in Rome, and other Towns that way, wondered to see Theodatus so
tame, not offering to fight with the Romans, being his so near Neighbors: And
they suspected him to betray their State to Justinian, caring only to live at
ease himself, and to be rich. When they heard that Naples was taken, they
assembled at Regeta 35. miles from Rome, and accused him openly. The place they
found fit to encamp in, being near to a fair Champian, and to the River of
Decanovius, so called, because having made a compass of 19. miles, it enters
the Sea about the City of Taracina. Near unto which is the Mountain Circaeum,
where they say Ulysses had the Company of Circe, improbably in my conceit;
Homer affirming Circes house to be in an Island. Indeed Circaeum runs far into
the Sea, and seems an Island along the Shore to the Sailer: but being in it,
he finds his mistaking. Upon this reason Homer might call it an Island. But
the Goths assembled at Regeta, chose Vitigis their King, a man of no
conspicuous Family: but in Fights about Sirmium, against the Gepaedes (with
whom Theodorick had War) he got great Reputation. Theodatus hearing his, ran
away to Ravenna: after him Vitigis sent Optaris a Goth, to bring him alive, or
dead. This Optaris had a pique against Theodatus: for having betroathed a
handsome Maid, an Inheritrix, Theodatus persuaded her for Wealth to marry
another man. So that to gratify his own Anger and Vitigis too, he pursued
Theodatus eagerly day and night: And overtaking him upon the way, laid him upon
his back like a Beast, and cut his Throat. This end made Theodatus in the third
year of his Reign.

CHAP. X.
VItigis then marched to Rome, glad of the news of Theodatus Death, and he put
his Son Theudegisclus in safe Custody. From thence, finding things yet in no
good preparation, he thought it best to go to Ravema, and having there
completely furnished himself, to enter into the War. He assembled therefore
the Goths; and spoke thus unto them. Great Actions, fellow Soldiers, prosper
not commonly by sudden Opportunities, but by solid Counsels; seasonable
delaying often doing good, and many undoing their hopes by undue have. For men
unprovided, though equal in numbers, are more easily beaten in Fight, then
though inferior in Powers, yet well prepared. Let us not therefore, provoked
with the present honor, hurt our selves incurably. It is better with a short
disgrace to preserve a perperuall Reputation, then avoding it for a moment, to
be ever confounded with Ignominy. Leander calls this Venetia Marca Trivigiana.
Our maine numbers, and our magazines are in Gaul, and Venetia, and other
remote Parts. We have also a War with the Francks; which before we have settled,
to enter into another, is folly. Who stands between two Enemies, and has not
his eye upon one at once, is commonly ruined by both. I say then, that we ought
to go to Ravenna, and having agreed the War with the Francks, and disposed our
business, then to fight with Belisarius. Let none be ashamed, or fear that
this Retraite will be called a running away. A seasonable Imputation of
Cowardice has crowned many a man with Success: And the name of Valor, gotten
by some before the time, has ended in a Defeat. Let us not affect Names, but
real Advantages. Actions in their conclusions, not beginnings, show the worth
of men. They run not away, who return upon the Enemy with greater
preparations; but who hide themselves, as if they would keep their Bodies ever
alive. And of this City be not afraid. If the Romans be well affected to us,
they will secure it for us; being to endure no extremity in the short time
before we return. If they be unsure, they will hurt us less by receiving the
Enemy into their City; it being ever best to Encounter men that hate us in an
open way. But this also I shall prevent; leaving in it a strong Garrison, and
an able Commander; and that being so settled, we can have no hurt by this
Retrait. The Goths approved this advise of Vitigis, and prepared for the
Journey. Then Vitigis using many Exhortations to Liberius the Bishop of Rome,
the Senate and People, to think of Theodoricks Reign, and to continue their
affections to the Gothish Nation, he bound them in strong Oaths; And leaving
to guard Rome 4000. men under Leuderis, a man ancient, and much esteemed for
his Wisdom, he marched to Ravenna with the rest of his Army, taking the most
part of the Roman Senators with him in the quality of Hostages. There he
married perforce Mattasuntha, a Beautiful Virgin, the Daughter of Amalasuntha,
that by alliance with the Blood of Theodorick he might make his Reign firm.
Then he assembled the Goths from all parts, and ranckt them in order,
distributing Horses and Arms to them. Those only lying in Gaul, for fear of
the Francks, he sent not for.

The Francks were formerly called Germans, where they first inhabited: and how
they incroached upon Gaul, and then fell out with the Goths, I will tell you.
I said before, how from Calis and the Ocean, into the Mediterranean, the left
hand continent is called Europe; and that against it, Africa, and further on,
Asia. The Countries beyond Africa I can say nothing of, being not inhabited;
whereby the Spring of Nile is unknown, which, they say, comes from those
Parts. But Europe at the first is like Peloponesus, having the Sea on both
sides. The first Province from the Ocean is named Spain, unto the Alps, which
are in the Pyrenaean Mountains (the Natives calling narrow passages, Alps)
From thence Gaul reaches to Liguria, where other Alps divide the Gauls and
Ligurians. Gaul is broader then Spain (for Europe begins narrow, and proceeds
to a great breadth by degrees) and it has the Ocean on the North side, and on
the South the Tyrhene Sea. Among other Rivers it has the Rhone, and the Rhine,
having contrary courses; the Rhone into the Tyrrhene Sea, but into the Ocean
the Rhine. Here Lakes also are, where-about anciently these Germans did
inhabit, now called Francks, a Barbarian Nation, and at first not considerable.
Beyond them dwelt the They inhabit (some say) Belgia about Brabant.
Arborychi, subject formerly to the Romans, as all the rest of Gaul and
Spain. Augustus planted the Thuringians to the East of the Arborychi, not far
from whom to the South inhabited the Burgundians, and beyond the Thuringians
the Suevians, and Almans, Potent Nations. All these were free States, and from
all Antiquity seated there. In process of time the Visigoths oppressing the
Roman Empire, subdued Spain, and Gaul, to the River of Poe, and made them
tributary. The Arborychi were then become Roman Soldiers, whom the Germans, or
Francks, to bring them in Subjection, being their Borderers, and for having
abandoned their former Commonwealth, pillaged, and made a general War upon
them. In this War the Arborychi showed much Valor and Affection to the Romans:
And the Germans not able to force them, offered to make them their
Confederates, which they willingly embraced (both being Christians) and being
joined into one people, they grew into a great power. Other Roman Soldiers
also Garrisoned in the Confines of Gaul, being not able to return to Rome,
nor willing to mingle with the Goths their Enemies, and Arrians, yielded
themselves, their Ensigns, and the Country under their Guard to the Arborychi
and Germans, which they have left to their Posterity, and preserved the Roman
Customs, which to my time they religiously observe. They still are enrolled in
the same Bands they anciently served in, have their proper Ensigns in Fights,
and use the Roman Laws, and Habit; and especially the Fashion of their
Diadems. The Roman State flourishing, Gaul on this side the Poe was the
Emperors; But Odoacer usurping the same, by the Tyrants cession, the Visigoths
had all Gallia Cisalpina to The Author calls the Pyrean and the Apennine by the
name of Alps.
those Alps, which sever Gaul and Liguria. Odoacer being slain, the
Thuringians and Visigoths; fearing the Germans power (who were grown a strong
multitude, subduing all in their way) sought alliance with the Goths: And
Theodorick afterward gladly contracted affinities with them. Theudichusa his
Daughter, a young Virgin, he betroathed to Alarick the younger, Prince of the
Visigoths; and Amaloberga, the Daughter of his sister Amalafrida, he affianced
to Hermenefridus, Prince of the Thuringians. And the Francks, fearing
Theodorick, forbear to force the Visigoths and Thuringians, but made War upon
the Burgundians.

CHAP. XI.
Afterward the Francks and Goths made a league against the Burgundians, upon
conditions to ruin the race of them, and to subdue their Country, and that
the Conquerours shall have a Fine from the part not joining in the War, but the
Country to be a common conquest of both. The Francks accordingly went with a
great Army against the Burgundians. Theodorick made preparations in show, but
delayed the expedition, expecting the event. At last he sent his Army, which he
bade march fair and softly; and hearing the Francks to be vanquished, to go no
further; but understanding them to be victorious, to march on speedily. They
did so; And the Francks in a Battle with the Burgundians stiffly fought, with
much slaughter, routed the Enemy, and drove them into the uttermost borders of
their country (where they had many strong places) and subdued the rest. The
Goths hearing it, were speedily with them; and being blamed by their
Confederates, they alleged the ill ways, and paying their Fine, divided the
Country with the Conquerours. And thus Theodorick showed his great providence,
by gaining thus half the Country with a little money, and without loss of
his Subjects: Thus the Goths and Francks held part of Gaul. Afterward the
Francks power increasing, without any fear of Theodorick, they led an Army
against Alarick and the Visigoths. Alarick sent for Theodorick, who marched with
a great Army to his aid. In the mean time the Visigoths hearing how the
Francks besieged Carcasona, encamped themselves near to oppose them. The siege
continuing, and their country being spoiled by the Enemy, they murmured, and
put scorns upon Alarick, railing at the delay of his Kinsman, and affirming
themselves strong enough without company to beat the Francks. Alarick thus
constrained to hazard a Battle, before the Goths could come, was therein
slain, and many of his people by the Francks, who thus got the greatest part
of Gaul. They straightly besieged Carcasona, hearing there was much treasure
in it, which Alarick the Elder had pillaged, when he took Rome. There were the
jewels of King Solomon, goodly pieces, by reason of a green stone in many of
them, and long ago taken by the Romans out of Jerusalem. The Visigoths
remaining, made Giselick their Prince, a base son of Alarick; Amalarick, his
Daughters son, being a child. But Theodorick coming with the Goths Army, the
Francks raised their siege; and returning from thence, Note. Beyond the Rhone
in respect of Italy.
held the parts of Gaul beyond the Rhone to the Ocean; from which Theodorick
could not drive them, and so let them keep it, and recovered the rest of Gaul.
Giselick also being dead, he made Amalarick his Daughters son Prince of the
Visigoths, and himself protector of the Child, and out of Carcasona he took
the Treasures, and returned to Ravenna. His aim was to make the Dominion of
Spain and Gaul his own for ever, sending Forces thither, and Governors, whom
he appointed to send the tributes to him, which (not to appear avaricious) he
gave as a yearly donative to his Armies of Goths and Visigoths: who upon this
occasion, of having one Prince and the same Country, married with one another,
and mingled their races: And afterward Theudis a Goth (whom Theodorick sent to
command the Army) married a Wife of a rich Family of the Spaniards, no
Visigoth, but very wealthy, and Lady of a great country. He had 2000.
Soldiers, and a strong guard of Lanciers, and was in show as Theodoricks
Governor of the Visigoths, but in effect an usurper.

Theodorick grown now an absolute wise man, fearing least while he had a War
with his own servant, the Francks might assail him, and the Visigoths rebel,
he discharged not Theudis of his command, but still upon any War directed him
to lead the Army. Only he got some principal Goths to write to him, that he
should do both justly, and as a wise man, to go to Ravenna, and salute
Theodorick. He continued obedient to Theodoricks command, and failed not in the
annual tribute, but to Ravenna he would neither go, nor promise it.

Theodorick being dead, the Francks invaded the Thuringians, killed their
Prince Hermenfridus, and held them in subjection. Hermenfridus his Widow fled
to Theodatus her Brother, then King of the Goths. Afterward the Francks
vanquished the remaining Burgundians in a Battle, and kept their Prince close
prisoner in a Castle; they used them as men conquered in War, made them serve
in their Armies, and their Country tributary which they dwelt in before.
Amalarick Prince of the Visigoths, From the Poe and Gallia Cis-Alpina to the
Rhone.
being at man's estate, and fearing the Francks greatness, married the Sister
of their King Theudibert: And Gaul he gave to Atalarick his cozen german, King
of the Goths. So that Gaul on this side the Rhone the Goths had, and that
beyond it was subject to the Visigoths: Namely Gallia Narbonersis, or rather
some part of it.
And they agreed to suppress the tribute imposed by Theodorick; And the said
Atalarick fairly restored to Amalarick the treasures taken out of Carcassona by
Theodorick.

The two Nations being joined thus in alliance, who had married any Wife of the
other, might either go with his Wife, or bring her home to his own kindred;
And some (as they pleased) brought home their Wives, others followed them.
Amalarick afterward offended his Wives brother, and was ruined. He was an
Arrian, and permitted not his Wife, being orthodoxall, to use her country
fashions, nor religion; but for her not applying her self to his customs, he
used her with much dis-respect.

The Lady acquainted her Brother with her grievance, which put the Francks, and
Visigoths into a War; and in a Battle long and stoutly fought, Amalarick was
vanquished, with loss of many, and of his own life. Theudibert received his
Sister with all her goods, and so much of Gaul as the Visigoths held. The
survivors with their Wives and Children went into Spain to Theudis, who now
openly usurped. So then all Gaul was held by the Francks and Goths: But
Theodatus King of the Goths, hearing of Belisarius landing in Sicily, made an
accord with the Francks; That they should command in the War; and have the
Goths part of Gaul, and twenty Centenaries of gold to assist them in this War.
But before this treaty was finished, he dyed as has been told.

CHAP. XII.
AND many of the Goths best men under Marcias were Garrisoned in that part of
Gaul; These Vitigis could not safely raise from thence, but thought them
rather too weak for the Francks, who would certainly overrun that part of
Gaul and Italy, if he with his Army went to Rome. So he called to him those
Goths he trusted most, and said; I call you here to impart an advice not
pleasing perhaps, but necessary; and you must hear patiently, and in the
present case counsel what becomes you. Whose affairs are not according to
their mind, such must obey necessity and fortune, and so manage the occasions
presented. We are excellent well prepared for this War, save only that the
Francks stand in our way; our ancient Enemies, with whom hitherto, though with
the hazard of our lives and fortunes, we make our party good. But now (another
Enemy appearing, against whom we must march) it behooves us to make peace with
them. If they continue Enemies, certainly they will come with Belisarius; A
common Enemy ever combines men in amity and mutual aid. And if we encounter
them severally, we shall be beaten by both: So that it is better by loosing a
little, to save the maine of our Dominions, then by coveting all, to perish and
loose all. My opinion is, if we give the Francks the parts of Gaul, bordering
on them, they will lay down their quarrels, and join with us in the War. How
to recover those parts upon our good success, let none examine now: I remember
an old saying; To settle well the present.

The principal Goths conceiving this course advantageous, resolved upon it,
and Ambassadors were sent to the Francks, to surrender Gaul, and pay the
money, and to conclude a Confederacy. The Princes of the Franks were then
Childebert, Note. Clouis the first Christian K. of France had 4. sons,
Childebert, Theodorick, Clotarius, and Clodomir. Clodomir died without issue,
and Childebert had his partage; this Theodebert was son of Theodorick. See
Agathias, lib. 1. cap. 1.
Theudebert, and Clotarius, who received that Gaul with the money, and divided
it proportionably to every man's dominion; They agreed to be firm friends to the
Goths, and to send them succors, not Francks, but of the Nations subject to
them. They could not enter into an open War with the Romans, having lately
promised to join with the Emperor in this. The Ambassadors having dispatched,
returned to Ravenna, and Vitigis sent for Marcias and his Troops.

Belisarius in this mean time prepared his journey for Rome. He appointed 300.
Foot under Herodian for the guard of Naples. He put a Garrison into Cuma to
guard the Castle there; there being no strong place in all Campania, but Naples
and Cuma. In Cuma they yet show Sibyllas Cave, where her Oracle was. It is a
maritime Town, distant sixteen miles from Naples. Belisarius put his Army in
order; but the Romans fearing the fortune of the Napolitans, resolved to
receive the Emperors Army, being moved thereunto chiefly by the Bishop of
Rome, Liberius Note. He calls this Bishop of Rome in the secret History
Silverius. And so Helvicus in his Chronology.
. They sent one Fidelius, born in Milan, a City of Liguria, and formerly
Quaestor to King Atalaricus, inviting Belisarius, and promising to surrender
the City. He led his Army by Via Latina, leaving Via Appia on his left hand;
which Appius a Roman Consul made 900. years ago; and it reaches five days
journey from Rome to Capua: It is broad enough for two Carts a breast, and
worth the sight; all the stones being of Millstone quarry, and very hard, and
brought by Appius from a far country. They are smooth wrought, square, and
close fastened, without brass between, or any thing else. They are so well
fastened and close, that one would think them to grow together. After so long a
time trampling on by Carts, and Beasts every day, there is not the least chink
in the pavement, nor any stone broken, nor worn out, nor that has lost the
brightness.

But the Gothish Garrison in Rome understanding the Enemies approach, and the
Romans intent, were troubled; being not able both to guard the City, and
encounter the Enemy. So that by the Romans permission they left Rome, and went
to Ravenna: Only Leuderis (ashamed it seems) staid behind. The same day and
hour Belisarius entered Rome with the Emperors Army at Porta Asinaria, and the
Goths went out at Porta Flaminia. The taking of Rome, Anno 11. Iustiniani, Anno
Dom. 337.
Thus Rome was recovered in the. 11. year of Justinians Reign, sixty years
after the last taking of it. The keys of it, and Leuderis Belisarius sent to
the Emperor: He took care of the walls decayed in many places, and made the
turrets tenable against an assault. He made Works upon the left side of every
turret, to secure the Defendants left side from shot: And about the walls he
drew a good deep ditch. The Romans commended the Generals providence, and
chiefly his skill in contriving the turrets: But they murmured, wondering he
would enter Rome with an opinion of being besieged, a place unfit for a siege
for want of provisions, being not upon the Sea, and having a huge compass of
walls, and in an open champian easily invested. But he, though he heard all
this, yet still prepared for a siege. The corn he brought from Sicily he kept
in public Granaries, and he compelled the Romans (though they grumbled) to
bring in all their provisions from their Farms.

CHAP. XIII.
A GOTH then, one Pitzas, yielded to Belisarius half Samnium, lying upon the
Sea, and the Goths there inhabiting to the River, which divides the country.
The Goths on the other side the River, neither would follow Pitzas, nor submit
to the Emperor. Belisarius gave him some Soldiers to help to guard the Towns
there. The Calabrians and Apulians having no Goths, had voluntarily before
submitted to Belisarius, both in the Mid land, and upon the Seacoast; Of which
was Beneventum, anciently by the Romans called Maleventum; now Beneventum, to
avoid the reproach of the name: for Ventus in Latin signifies the Wind:
because in Dalmatia over against it uses to blow a rough wind, during which no
Traveller is seen upon the ways; they all shut themselves in their houses. The
force of the wind is such, that it snatches up a Horseman and his Horse
together, carries them in the air, and throws them down and kills them. And
Beneventum standing high, and over against Dalmatia, shares in the
inconvenience of this wind. Diomedes built the City, being banished from Argos
after the destruction of Troy. It has a monument of him, the teeth of the
Calydonian Bore, the prize of Meleager his Uncle in that famous hunting, which
are still there, and worth the seeing, the circumference like a half moon,
being of three spanns. Here they say Diomedes met with Aeneas, and according to
Minerva's Oracle, gave him the Image stolen by him and Ulysses out of her
Temple, when they came as spies into Troy, before the City could be taken.
Afterward being sick, they say, he consulted the Oracle, which answered, that
he should never have ease, unless he gave that Image to some Trojan. Where it
is the Romans now know not, but show the figure of it graven in stone, standing
to my time in the Temple of Fortune, before the brazen Statue of Minerva in the
open air, on the East Side of that Temple. It resembles Minerva fighting, and
charging her Lance; yet in a long robe, and with a face not like her Grecian
Statues, but as the ancient Egyptians made them. They of Constantinople say,
that Constantine buried the Statue in the Marketplace bearing his name. But
Belisarius thus conquered Italy on this side the Jonian Gulf, to Rome and
Samnium. On the other side Constantianus (as has been said) got all, to
Liburnia.

To speak something how Italy is inhabited; the Adriatique Sea discharges a
stream far into the firm Land, and makes the Jonian Gulf; Not as in other
places, where the Sea running to the Land-ward, in the end makes an Isthmus, or
neck of Land. As the Chrisaean Gulf ending in the Haven of Lechaeum by
Corinth, makes there the Isthmus, being some five miles broad: And the Gulf
Melas from the Hellespont makes another of the same breadth in Chersonesus.
Whereas from Ravenna, where ends the Jonian Gulf, to the Tyrrhene Sea, is
eight days journey over land, by reason the current of that Sea is carried out
far to the Southward. The first Town on this side the Jonian Gulf is
Otranto in Apulia. To the North of that Town is part of Calabria, and Samaium:
Next to which is Picenia, reaching to Ravenna. On the other side of that Town
is the rest of Calabria, then Bruttia, and Lucania. Next to which is Campania,
to the City of Taracina. To them adjoynes the Territory of Rome. These Nations
hold both the shores of the Mediterranean, and all the Mid-lands that way. Here
is that which was formerly called Magna Graecia. In Bruttia are seated the
Epizephyrian Locrians, Crotonians, and Thurians. On the other side of the
Jonian Gulf, first are the Graecians of Epirus, to Epidamnus, which stands
upon the Sea. Bordering thereunto is the Province of Precalis: Beyond which it
is called Dalmatia, accounted of the western Empire, and all beyond it, as
Liburnia, Istria, and Venetia, reaching to Ravenna. Above these up into the
Land are the Siscians, and the Suevians (not those subject to the Francks) and
the Carnians, and Norioi beyond them. To the right hand of whom are the Dacians
and Pannonians, holding Singidon, Sirmium, and other places, and extending to
the river Ister. The Nations on that side the Jonian gulf, the Goths at the
beginning of this war ruled. Beyond Ravenna, to the left hand, and by North of
the Poe, are the Ligurians, and beyond them Northward the Albanians, in an
excellent Country, called Languvilla. To the West of these Nations are the
Gauls, and then the Spaniards. To the South of the Poe is Aemilia, and Tuscany,
which reaches to the Territory of Rome.

But Belisarius took all the said territory of Rome to the Tiber, and fortified
it round about; which being in good estate, he directed Constantianus with a
band of his own Targetiers, and with Zanter, Chorsomanus, and Aeschmanus,
Hunnes, and some of his Lifeguard, and other Forces to march into Tuscany, and
take in the Towns there. And he gave order to Bessas to take Narnia, a strong
place in Tuscany. Bessas was of the race of the Goths formerly inhabiting
Thrace, but followed not Theodorick into Italy. He was valiant, a skillful
Soldier, and an excellent Captain, and very dextrous in his own person. He got
Narnia by the Inhabitants good will; and Constantianus as easily took Spoletum
and Perusia, and some other Towns in Tuscany; the Tuscans willingly receiving
him. He placed a Garrison in Spoletum, and himself with his Forces lodged in
Perusia, the chief City in Tuscany. Vitigis sent an Army against him under
Vnilas, and Pitzas, whom Constantinus encountered in the Suburbs of Perusia. At
first, the Barbarians having advantage in numbers, the battle was equal; but
at last the Romans by their valor routed them, and killed them almost all;
Their Commanders they sent prisoners to Belisarius. Vitigis upon this would
stay no more at Ravenna, where he attended Marcias and his Troops. First he
sent an Army under Asinarius and Vligisalus, to recover Dalmatia to the Goths;
directing them to get Barbarians out of Suavia to join with them, and so to
march directly to Salonae: Which to besiege by Sea also he sent along many
Pinnaces. Then himself prepared to go against Belisarius, and Rome, with no
less then 150000. Horse and Foot, the most of them armed, horses and Men.
Asinarius raised an Army of Suevians; and Vligisalus led the Goths alone into
Liburnia, where he fought with the Romans at a place called Scardon, was
beaten, and retired to the City of Burnus, where he staid for Asinarius.
Constantianus hearing of Asinarius his preparations, and fearing Salonae, drew
together the Soldiers garrisoned thereabout, made a Ditch about the City
walls, and provided against a siege. Asinarius with a great levy of Barbarians
came to Burnus, and joining with Vligisalus marched to Salonae. They compast
the Walls with their Trenches, and manning their Pinnaces with soldiers,
blockt Salonae to the Sea-ward, and so besieged it by Sea and Land: But the
Romans set suddenly upon their Pinnaces, scattered them, and sunck many with
the men aboard, and took many, the men being gone. Yet the Goths raised not
their siege, but were rather more eager upon the Romans within.

CHAP. XIV.
IN the mean time Vitigis hearing of the smalnesse of Belisarius his Army, it
repented him for retiring from Rome; so not enduring longer where he was, in
much anger he marched thitherward. Upon the way he met a Roman Priest, of whom,
they say, he asked earnestly, if Belisarius were yet at Rome; as fearing not to
catch him before his running away. He bad him apprehend no such thing,
undertaking that Belisarius would not fly, but stay upon the place: Which made
him have the more; openly praying, to see Rome before Belisarius were run out
of it. Who hearing the whole Nation of Goths thus coming upon him, was
troubled; For though his Army were very small, he would not leave destitute
Constantinus and Bessas, nor abandon the places in Tuscany, least with them the
Goths should block up Rome. So upon advice he sent to Constantinus, and Bessas,
to leave competent Garrisons in the most important places, and with the rest to
come to Rome. Constantinus accordingly placing Garrisons in Spoletum and
Perusia, came with the rest to Rome. But Bessas staying to settle Narnia, the
Enemy passed that way, and the Feilds and Suburbs were full of them, being
Avant-coureurs, whom Bessas charged, and defeated them, and killed many; but
pressed with their numbers, he retired into Narnia, where he left a Garrison; and
coming to Rome, brought news, that the Enemy would speedily be with them.
Narnia stands almost 44. miles from Rome. Vitigis would not spend time upon
Perusia, and Spoletum, being strong places. His desire was to find Belisarius
in Rome, before he was run away. And Narnia possessed by the Enemy, and a place
steep and hard of access, he would not stir neither: it stands on a high hill,
at the foot whereof is the River of Narnus, giving the name to the City; and it
has two ascents on the East and West sides; the one narrow with ragged rocks;
to the other is no coming, but over the bridge upon the River, which is an
ancient building of Augustus Caesar, admirable to see, and with the highest
arches we know. Vitigis, not to spend time, speedily went thence with his whole
Army toward Rome, marching through the Sabins Country. Being within a mile and
three quarters thereof, he came to a bridge upon the Tiber, where Belisarius had
built a Tower, and Gates, and placed a Garrison. The Tiber was every where
passable by Boats and other Bridges; but this he did, to put the Enemy to more
delay (expecting from the Emperor more Forces) and that the Romans might have
the more time to bring in provisions; conceiving that the Goths repulsed here,
could not pass by any other Bridge in less then twenty days; and to get Boats
would be a longer work.

Upon these considerations he placed that Garrison. The Goths lodged near it,
and the next day intended to assault the Tower. Here came to them 22.
Fugitives, Barbarians born, but Roman Soldiers of Innocentius Horse-troop.
Belisarius thought fit to make a Camp near the Tiber, the more to hinder the
Enemies passage, and to give some demonstration of their own courage.

The Roman Garrison upon the Bridge frighted with the multitude, and the danger,
quitted the Tower at night, and ran away into Campania. They would not go to
Rome, fearing chastisement from the General, or ashamed to see their fellows.
The next day the Goths brake down the Gates, and passed over, none opposing.
Whereof Belisarius hearing nothing, with 1000. Horse marched toward the bridge,
to view their ground, where they might best incamp; who lighting upon the Enemy
newly passed over, were engaged in a fight unwillingly. They were both sides
Horse: And Belisarius, though formerly cautions, observed not then the rank of
a General, but fought in the head of his Soldiers, which hazarded extremely
the Roman affairs, the whole inclination of the War depending on him. But he
was upon a Horse used to the War, and skillful to save his Rider. He was of a
brown bay, and from the forehead to the nostrils white (Such a Horse the
Grecians call (...), and the Barbarians, Balan.) Most of the Goths shot at
Belisarius and his Horse upon this occasion. Those new-come Fugitives seeing
Belisarius fighting in the first rank, and knowing that by his fall the Romans
would be ruined, cried aloud to shoot at the bald faced Horse. This word ran
through the Goths Army, who in the tumult being not inquisitive, nor certain it
was Belisarius, but guessing the word so generally spread was not for nothing,
most left all others, and shot at Belisarius. Such as were ventrous, and
ambitious of honor, got near, reached at him, and in fury laid on with Lances
and swords. And Belisarius laid about him too, killing those within his reach.
The affection of his Lanciers and Targetiers stood him in good stead in this
danger; who sticking close to him, showed valor, the like whereof (I think)
was never seen, holding their sheilds before the General, and receiving all
the arrows, and thrusting off the multitudes with main strength.

CHAP. XV.
THus was the whole fight about one man, wherein fell at least 1000 Goths, and
such as fought in the first rancks. Many of the best of Belisarius his Retinue
were slain, and Maxentius, one of his Lanciers, after he had performed
bravely: Himself was neither wounded that day nor shot, though the fight was
about him alone. In conclusion, the Romans routed the Enemy; multitudes flying,
till they recovered their camp: where their foot being fresh, received the
Romans, and easily repulsed them. Who seeing another supply of Horse coming,
fled up to a Hill, where they made a stand; and encountered the Barbarian horse
overtaking them. Where Valentinus, Gentleman of the horse to Photius,
Antonina's son, showed extraordinary valor, gallopping into the thickest of
the enemy, and stopping their course, and bringing off his company; and thus
they escaped to the Walls of Rome, with the Barbarians at their heels up to the
gate, now called Belisaria. The Romans within, fearing the Enemy might enter
pell mell, would not open the gate, notwithstanding Belisarius's earnest
commands, loud cries, and threats, who could not be discerned from the Turret
(it being after Sun set) having his face covered with blood and dust, and they
did not think the General to be alive; those that ran away at the first defeat
having reported him to be slain, fighting bravely in the head of his troops.
The Enemy therefore coming with multitudes, and much Fury, thought to get over
the ditch, and charged the retirers, who near the Walls stood thick and close
body to body in a small room. And they within being no Soldiers, nor prepared
at all, and afraid of their city, could not succor them; when a sudden bold
resolution of Belisarius saved all, who encouraging his company, charged the
Enemy: and they being disordered, as in the dark, and upon a chase, and seeing
those that fled unexpectedly coming on, suspected succors to be come from the
city, and in a fear run all away. Belisarius pursued them not, but turned about
to the walls; whom the Romans, taking heart, received in, and his company. In
so great peril was Belisarius, and the Emperors affairs. The fight beginning
in the morning ended at night; wherein Belisarius did best of the Romans, and
of the Goths Visandus the standard bearer, who with the rest charged
Belisarius; and went not off, before he fell to the ground after 13 wounds
received, and neglected by his companions (though they had the victory) he was
left among the dead. Three days after, the Goths being encamped near Rome,
sent out to bury the dead men, and to perform their funeral rites: these
searching the bodies, found Visandus with breath in him, but he could not
speak; his inward parts with famine and drouth being extremely inflamed, they
put water in his mouth, and so having drunk and got life, they carried him to
the camp; and for this he was in great reputation with the Goths, and he lived
long after. Belisarius being in safety, assembled his soldiers to the walls,
and most of the common people; commanding them to light fires, and to watch all
night. He went the round himself, set all in order, and appointed commanders to
every gate. Bessas, who guarded Porta Praenestina, sent him word, that the town
was entered by the Enemy at a gate bearing the name from Saint Pancratius. The
company advised Belisarius to escape out at some other gate; but he misliked
the motion, sent horsemen down to the Tiber, who upon the view brought word,
that there was no Enemy thereabout appearing. Wherefore he sent direction to
the Commanders of every gate, if they heard that the Enemy was entered at any
other part, not to succor, but to continue upon their guards; least they
should be disordered with false alarms; Himself would take care of those
things. Vitigis (the Romans being in this tumult) sent a Commander named Vacis,
to Porta Salaria, who reviled there the Romans for their disloyalty to the
Goths, and thus betraying their country, and indeed themselves, having
exchanged the Goths power, for Greeks, unable to defend them; none of which
nation were formerly seen in Italy, but stage players, and some pilfring
mariners. But seeing none would answer him, he went back to Vitigis. The Romans
also flouted Belisarius, who had so hardly escaped, yet bade them despise these
Barbarians; for he knew he should absolutely beat them. By what he knew this,
shall be said anon; but now it being grown late, and he being yet fasting, his
wife and friends had much ado to persuade him to eat something.

CHAP. XVI.
THe next day the Goths thinking with ease to enter Rome, by reason of the
greatness of it; and the Romans defending it, were thus quartered. The city
has fourteen gates, and some posterns; but the Goths, unable to encompasse the
whole circuit thereof, made ^ixe intrenchments, and infested the space of five
Gates, from Porta Flaminia to Porta Praenestina. These were on this side the
Tiber; But fearing least the enemy should take down Pons Milvius, and so
exclude them from all from the river to the sea, and thereby might not feel the
inconveniences of the Seige; they made a seventh Intrenchment on the other side
of Tiber, in Nero's feilds; that they might have the said bridge in the midst
between their Camps. And so they infested two gates more; It was called Porta
Triumphalis, and Vaticana, and was next to Pons Triumphalis, Leand. in descrip.
Italiae. Mons Janiculus it was called.
Porta Aurelia (now named of Peter, the chief of Christ's Apostles, lying
buried near unto it) and the Gate beyond the Tiber. Thus they encompassed half
the city; and being not cut off by the River, made the war in what part of it
they pleased. The Romans have built their walls on both sides the River, thus.
The Tiber grown great, runs a good space by the walls on this side of it,
which stand by the Rivers side, upon Ground flat, and very assaultable.
Opposite to them beyond the Tiber, is a * great hill, where stand the City
mills; the water being brought by an Aquaeduct to the hill top, and from thence
descending with much swiftness: which caused the ancient Romans to compass
this hill, and the Rivers banck near it with a wall; that an Enemy might not
demolish the mills, nor pass the River to assail the town walls; which with a
bridge they joined to this part; and building houses upon this ground beyond
the Tiber, took the River into the midst of the City. The Goths also made deep
ditches about their intrenchments; and casting the Earth inward, and therewith
making the intrenchment very high, and pitching the top with multitude of
stakes, they made their camps not inferior to so many Castles. The
Entrenchment in Nero's feilds Marcias commanded, being come out of Gaul with
his troops, and there quartered. The other were commanded by Vitigis, and five
other; a Commander to every intrenchment. They cut also all the Aquaeducts, to
cut off the cities water that way: they are fourteen in all, ancient works of
brick; and so deep and broad, that a man on Horse back may ride in them. But
Belisarius to guard the City used this order; himself had Porta Pinciana, and
Porta Salaria standing to the right hand of it, because the wall there is very
assaultable; and being opposite to the Enemy, the Romans were to sally there.
He gave Porta Praenestina to Bessas, and to Constantianus Porta Flaminia (which
stands to the left hand of Pinciana) and rammed up the gate with stones within,
that it might not be opened; fearing the Enemies designs there, being close to
one of their Entrenchments. The other gates he directed the commanders of the
foot to guard. The Aquaeducts he fortified a good space, to avoid mischeife
that way from without. But the Aquaeducts being cut, they wanted water for
their mills, and with beasts they could not work, their scarce provisions of
fodder (as in a siege) not sufficing for their horses of service. Belisarius to
help this, tied cables before the bridge, that joined to the City wall, from
one banck of the river to the other, stretching them stiff, and fastening boats
to them two foot asunder, where the stream from the arches of the bridge ran
strongest; and putting into each boat a millstone, he hung the Engine between
the boats which turns the Mill. Beneath these he tied other boats together in
the same manner in a distance proportionable, fitting them with like Engines;
and the stream being strong, and turning the Engines, set the Mill stones on
work, and grinded sufficient for the City. The Enemies informed hereof by
fugitives, endeavored to spoil the Engines by throwing into the River great
trees and bodies of Romans slain, and these being driven down with the stream,
brake the Engines at first; but Belisarius had this remedy. He hung before the
bridge iron chains across the River, which stopped all that came down the
stream; which men appointed drew up to the land; and this he did not only for
the mills, but to prevent the Enemies entrance with boats through the bridge
into the midst of the City. The Barbarians failing in their attempt gave it
over, and the Romans made use of those mills, but for want of water were shut
from their Baths; they had sufficient to drink, those who dwelt far from the
River having the commodity of wells. Their common sewers they needed not
secure, having all their mouths into the River; and so impossible to be entered
by the Enemy.

In the mean time among the Samnites, their boys who kept their sheep, choosing
two of the lustiest, and calling one Belisarius and the other Vitigis, caused
them to wrestle. It was Vitigis chance to be thrown; whom the boys in sport
hung on a tree, and suddenly a wolf appearing, they all ran away, and poor
Vitigis after a long time hanging in great pain dyed. The Samnite upon this
accident punished not the boys, but divining at the event, believed that
Belisarius would get the Victory.

CHAP. XVII.
BUT the people of Rome not used to the miseries of war, and a siege; and now
wanting their baths, and pincht with scarcity, being put also to guard the
walls, and want their sleeps; supposing too, that ere long their City would be
taken, and seeing already their country farms spoiled by the Enemy; they
murmured greivously to be besieged and run this hazard, having done no offense.
So assembling themselves, they railed at Belisarius for presuming to make war
with the Goths, having no competent forces from the Emperor, and the Senators
privately objected the same unto him. Vitigis understanding this from fugitives,
to exasperate them yet more, and so to put the Romans affairs into confusion,
he sent Ambassadors to Belisarius; among whom was one Albes, who having access
to him in the presence of the Senate, and Commanders of the army, spoke thus.
Anciently, O General! men fitly defining names for things, have distinguished
presumption from valor; the one drives men into danger with dishonor, the
other with virtue brings abundantly glory. One of these has brought you
hither, and which of them you may quickly manifest. If in the confidence of
your valor you have entered into this war; you see from your walls your
Enemies; and brave S^. you have means to be valiant enough. If through
presumption you have invaded us, you will certainly repent what you have rashly
done, as overweening men ever use when they come to the trial: Add not
therefore more misery to these Romans, whom Theodorick has bred in freedom and
delights; and oppose not your self against the Lord of the Goths and Italians.
How absurd is it for you, shut up thus, and afraid of your Enemies, to lodge
in Rome, while her King lives in a trench, acting the mischeifes of a war upon
his own Subjects? Yet will we grant to you and your troops a free retreat,
and leave to carry away your goods; holding it not religious nor manly to
insult upon men, who have learnt to be sober again. But we would willingly ask
these Romans wherewith they can charge the Goths, that they thus have betrayed
both us and themselves; having hitherto enjoyed our moderation, and now finding
what your aides are. Belisarius to this speech made this answer. Our season for
fighting shall not be at your disposing; men use not to make war by the advice
of their Enemies, whose Law is for every man to order his own business to his
own liking: The time will come when you would hide your heads in bushes, and
shall not be able. We having taken Rome, possess nothing that is another. You
usurped it formerly being not yours, and now have restored it to the ancient
owners. And who ever of you hopes to enter Rome without fighting, he is
mistaken. It is impossible Belisarius should live, and so much degenerate. Thus
spoke Belisarius. But the Romans for fear sat mute, not daring to contradict
the Ambassadors, though reproached thus with treason. Only Fidelius was bold
to reprove them, being Prefect of the palace made by Belisarius, and most
affected to the Emperors Service. The Ambassadors were reconducted to the
camp; whom Vitigis asked what manner of man Belisarius was, and how resolving,
touching his retreat. They answered, that the Goths hoped an impossibility, if
they thought to fright Belisarius: whereupon Vitigis resolved to assault the
City; for which he was thus prepared. He made Towers of wood equal with the
walls; having the just measure of them by often numbering the stones: at the
Bases and corners of the towers were wheels, which with ease were moved and
turned about as the assailants pleased, and drawn by oxen. He fitted also many
Ladders, and made four Rams; which Engine is made first setting up four
wooden pillars equal and opposite to each other; into which are mortessed
eight cross beams, four above and four into the Bases, making the form of a
little house four square. This instead of roof and walls was covered with
Skins, that it might be light to draw, and they within secure from shot. Within
about the Engine aloft, hangs another cross beam with loose chains, the top
whereof is made sharp, and over it a great quantity of iron laid as on the
head end of an arrow, where the said iron is made four square like an anvill.
The Engine is raised upon four wheels, fastened to the four pillars; and within
fifty men at least move it, who having set it to the walls, draw the said loose
beam backward with a pully, then let it go with violence at the walls; and by
often shooting it thus, it shakes and makes a breach where it hits: hence the
Engine has the name; the point of the said beam putting forth, and pushing like
a ram. The Goths also had quantity of fagots of wood and reed ready, to make
the ground and the City ditch even for their Engines to pass without rubb.
Belisarius upon the other side placed upon the Towers engines called Balistae.
These have the form of a bow, with a hollow horn sticking out beneath and
hanging loose, but lying upon a strait piece of Iron: when they are to shoot,
they bend the two pieces of wood, making the two ends of the bow, with cord;
and put the arrow upon the hollow horn, being half so long as common arrows,
and four times as thick. It mounts not with feathers, but instead thereof has
thinn pieces of wood mortess'd in, and it is in shape wholly like common
arrows, having a head of iron proportionable to its thickness; men at both
ends bend the bow with pullyes; and the hollow horn going forward, at last
falls off, and out flies the arrow with such force, that it reaches twice as
far as an arrow from a bow, and lighting upon tree or stone, cleaves it
asunder. It is called Balistae, because (...)it shootes very far. Other Engines
were set upon the battlements proper for slinging stones, and are like slings,
and are called wild Asses. At the Gates they set up wolves, These wolves were
something like Potteulisses.
made thus. They set two beams from the ground reaching to the battlements; and
laying Chequer wise pieces of Timber wrought, some upright and some a cross,
they joint them so, that the mortessing holes meet one another. And before
each joint sticks out a pointed piece of wood like a thick spurr and fastening
the cross timbers to another beam, which from the top reaches half way down,
they lay the beams flat-long upon the Gates, and an Enemy approaching, men
above lay hold of the higher ends of the beams and thrust them down, which
falling suddenly among the Assailants with those wooden points sticking out,
kill all they light on. Belisarius having these preparations, the Goths
conducted by Vitigis himself the eighteenth day of the siege about sun rising,
marched to the assault. The Towers and Rams in the head of them astonished the
Romans, not used to such sights. But Belisarius seeing the Enemies order with
their Engines, fell into a laughing, and bade the Soldiers stand and begin no
fight, till he gave the Signal. He imparted not the reason of his laughing,
but afterward it was known. The Romans thinking he jeered them, railed at him,
and called him an impudent man, and extremely murmured, that he did not stop
the Enemy coming near or still. Who being approacht the town ditch, the
General bent his bow and shot an armed man, leading the rest into the neck;
and the wound being mortal, the man fell down with his face upward. All the
people of Rome upon the Battlements taking it for an excellent presage, made a
huge shout. Belisarius shot again, with the like fortune, and again there was
a greater shout from the walls, that the Romans within thought the Enemy had
been vanquished. Then Belisarius gave the signal to the whole Army to shoot,
and commanded those about himself, to employ all their Arrows against the
Oxen; which soon fell all, and so the Enemy could neither bring on their
Towers, nor invent any remedy, being puzzel'd in the midst of their business.
Then was known Belisarius providence, not to stop them afar off; and that he
laughed at their sottishness, in hoping to bring their Oxen to their Enemies
walls so unadvisedly. These things were about Porta Belisaria.

CHAP. XVIII.
BUT Vitigis being there repulsed, left a good part of the Army, ordered in a
deep Batallion; and directing the Commanders, not to assail the walls, but to
stand in their orders, and ply the Battlements with shot, to divert Belisarius
from succouring another part (which with greater Forces he meant to assault)
he marched toward Porta Praenestina, to that part which is called Vivarium (or
the Park) where the Walls are most assaultable, having other Engines of Rams,
Towers, and scaling Ladders. The Goths also made another assault against Porta
Aurelia; without which stands Adrians Tomb, a stones cast from the walls, worth
the sight. It is made of Parian stone close joined, without any other matter
within. It has four equal squares, each being near a stones cast broad, and
is higher then the City walls. On the top are Statues of the same stone of men
and horses, of admirable work. This tomb the Citizens have anciently joined
to the walls by two Flanckers from the same; that it shows as a turret
defending the gate there. The Fortification being very sufficient, Belisarius
gave the command of it to Constantianus, directing him to take care of the wall
adjoining, which had but a small guard. For the wall being there strong (the
river running under it, he looked not for an assault that way, and so put no
important guard at it; distributing his maine Forces (which were but few) to
the most necessary places. For the Emperors Army at the beginning of this
siege amounted but to five thousand men in Rome.

Constantianus perceiving the Enemy to attempt a passage over the Tiber, and
fearing the Flancker there, himself went to the succor with a few, directing
the rest to guard the Gate and Adrians tomb. Where the Goths gave on, holding
before them their leather Bucklers like Persian Targets, and having no engines
of Batteries, but store of scaling Ladders and Archery, thinking quickly to
perplex the Enemy, and master the Garrison being few. Their opposites saw them
not, till they came very near, being covered by the Porticus, which reaches to
Saint Peter's Church. Then suddenly the Goths showing themselves, began; and the
Romans were not able to use their Balistas (which can shoot but right forward)
nor with their Archery to annoy them, the shot doing no good by reason of those
Bucklers. The Goths pressed hard, and shot thick at the Battlements, and were
ready to se their Ladders to the Flanckers, having almost encompassed the tomb,
and when the Romans came on, still wheeling about at their backs. The Romans
were troubled, seeing no hope of holding out, till they agreed to take down the
Statues being great, and the stones huge, which they threw down upon the
Enemies heads. Who being hurt, gave ground by little and little, and the Romans
grew bold, and repelled them with their Bows and stones; and falling to their
Engines, put them into fear, so that their assault was not long. And
Constantianus appearing, frighted those who attempted to pass the River, not
finding the Flancker there without guard, as they imagined.

Thus the Aurelian gate was in safety, and all about it. The Enemy also
attempted Porta Pancratiana upon the River, but did no good upon the place,
being strong, and the walls not easily assaultable there, standing on steep
ground. Paulus with his Foot company guarded there. Neither attempted they
Porta Flaminia, situate upon craggy ground, not easy of access, and guarded
by a Foot-company of Rhegians, commanded by Vrsicinus. Between this gate and
Porta Pinciana, next it on the right hand, part of the wall had been long
broken half way down from the top. It fell not, but panch't on both sides,
part appearing inward, and part outward: whence the Romans call it the broken
wall. Belisarius at his first coming, going about to repair it, the Romans
hindered him, alleging that the Apostle Peter had promised to guard the
place, whom above all they reverence. And it succeeded according to their
expectation: For neither that day, nor during all the siege of Rome the Enemy
ever approacht it, not was the least trouble about it. And we wondered in all
the time, that the place never came into the Enemies thoughts, having made so
many assaults, and attempts by night. No man since has been so bold as to
repair it, but still the wall remains broken. At Porta Salaria in the mean
time, a tall goodly man, valiant, and of good quality among the Goths, being
armed with Corslet and Morion, left his rank; and standing on a tree, threw a
rope up to the Battlements, whom an arrow from a Balista piercing through his
body half way into the tree, nailed him dead to the same. This frighted the
Goths from coming within arrow-shot, and kept them in their ranks, from
infesting any more those upon the walls.

CHAP. XIX.
IN the mean time Bessas and Peranius (whom Vitigis hotly charged in the
Vivarium) sent for Belisarius. And he speedily came to their relief, fearing
the weakness of the wall in that part; and leaving at Porta Salaria one of his
retinew, He encouraged the Soldiers in the Park, frighted with the assault,
and the Enemies multitude. Anciently the Romans finding the ground flat, and
fit for invasion, and the bricks of the wall there grown loose, scarce sticking
together, compassed the same with a Flancker, not so much for safety (for it
had no Battlements, nor other Fortification upon it, to resist an Enemy) but
for pleasure, to keep in it Lions, and other wild Beasts, whereupon it was
named Vivarium, the Park. Vitigis made ready his Engines against the wall
there, and commanded the Goths to get through the Flancker into the Park, and
then he knew he should be easily master of the Town-walls, being weak.
Belisarius seeing the Enemy digging through into the Park, and in many parts
assaulting the walls, suffered not his men to defend, nor stay upon the
Battlements, but held them, with their swords and Armor ready near unto the
Gate there. The Goths having now cut through the wall, and entered the Park, he
sent out Cyprianus with his company to begin the fight; who killed them all,
falling down for fear, and spoiled by one another, running out at their
narrow breach: the whole Enemy being amazed with the suddenness, and out of
their orders, and some carried one way, some another. Belisarius instantly
opened the Gate, and sallied with the whole Army; And the Goths having no mind
to fight, ran away every man; whom the Romans followed, and killed them with
ease, and had a long execution; the Goths having assaulted there far from their
Entrenchments. Belisarius commanded to burn the Enemies Engines, which with the
flame (being high) more astonished them. At Porta Salaria also they sallied at
the same time unexpectedly, killed the Enemy running away without resistance,
and burnt their Engines. The flame rose above the walls, which put them all to
a general retreat: the Romans from the walls shouting to encourage the
