day to Arnum, declaring Belisarius his direction. But John refused to go with
them, and detained Damianus with his 400 men; so that leaving the foot
companies, they went away with the Lanciers and Targetiers of Belisarius. Soon
after Vitigis with his whole army sat down before Ariminum. He made a wooden
tower higher then the walis, and upon wheels brought it where the same were
most assaultable: They drew it not on with oxen, least they should speed as
they did at Rome; but men covered within it, shoved it on: within it was a
great broad scaling ladder for the common soldier to mount the battlements,
they not doubting but to get up with ease so soon as their tower was set to the
walls, so was the figure thereof contrived. Being come near the walls with it,
they lay still, because it grew dark, set their sentinells about it, and took
their rest, dreaming of no opposition; there being but a small trench only to
hinder their approach. The Romans past the night in fear, expecting the next
day to be ruined. But John neither despairing nor fearing, about midnight left
the rest upon their Guards, and himself with his Isaurians carrying Mattocks
and other instruments, got secretly without the walls, and caused them to dig
in the trench, and to cast up the Earth to the town-ward, which served for a
rampire, and in a small time, the Enemy being fast a sleep, they made the
Trench of reasonable depth and breadth, where the walls were weakest, and the
Goths were to approach with their tower: who (the night being far spent)
perceived it, and ran to beat them off: but they, the trench being completed,
got within the walls. Vitigis was extremely vexed at in the morning, and put to
death some sentinells: and being as eager as ever, commanded to fill up the
ditch with Faggots, and so to draw the tower on. They did his commands with
alacrity, though mightily opposed from the walls. But the faggots with the
weight of the Tower sunk, that they could not get it forward, the Ground
growing still steeper, where the Earth was cast up, as I said. So that fearing
the night approaching, and the Enemies sallying to burn their Engine, they drew
it back. John to hinder them, put the Soldiers in Arms, and used this
Exhortation. "Fellow soldiers, and my partners in this danger, he that would
live, and see those he has left at home; let him know that he holds this hope
by his sword only. When Belisarius sent us out, the hope and Love of many
things made us cheerful in the business. We suspected not so near the sea
(the Romans being masters of the sea) to be besieged, nor imagined, that the
Emperors army could so much neglect us. Then the occasion of showing our
affection to the state, and of getting Glory encouraged us; now, but by our
valor, we cannot so much as live, and for life (were there nothing else) we
must of necessity undergo this hazard. And who pretends to valor also, has a
fair opportunity this day to get Glory by it; which is gotten not by overcoming
inferiors in power, but by a victory with less preparations, and greater
courage. And who love their lives best, shall gain most by daring; whose
affairs (as ours now) are upon the Edge of a razor, such as are preserved only
by despising danger. Having thus said, he led them against the Enemy, leaving
some upon the battlements; the Enemy received them bravely, and it was hotly
fought; and with much ado about Evening they brought their Tower to the Camp
with loss of many good men, that they resolved to assault no more; but lay
still to take the Romans by Famine; whose provisions failed, and they knew not
which way to get supply.

CHAP. X.
BUT Belisarius sent toward Millan, 1000 Isaurians and Thracians; Ennes led
the Isaurians, and Paulus the Thracians, and Mundilas commanded in chief,
having some Targetiers of Belisarius. Fidelius (made Prefect of the Palace)
being born at Millan, was thought fit to accompany these forces, having some
power in Liguria. From the port of Rome, they went by Sea to Genoa, the utmost
City in Tuscany, at the Entrance of the Gaulish and Spanish seas; where leaving
their ships they took their journey, putting their schiffs upon waynes to pass
the Poe with. Being passed the River, and come to the City of Picenum, the
Goths, with many and of their best men fought with them; For such of them as
dwelt in those parts, had put into Picenum their Goods of most value, it being
a strong place; but the Romans after a hot fight had the victory, slew many,
and failed little of taking the town; for the Goths had much ado to shut their
gates, they were so closely pursued. Fidelius, as the Romans rod back, staid to
pray in a Church; and having a fall by the stumbling of his horse near the
Town: the Goths sallied and killed him, unseen by the Enemy, which much greived
Mundilas and the Romans, who went to Millan, and took it without fight, and all
Liguria. Vitigis understanding it, sent an army thither under Vraeas, his
Sisters son. And Theodebert, King of the Francks, sent to his aid at his
request, 10000, not Francks, but Burgundians, that he might not seem to wrong
the Emperor. These Burgundians pretended to come of their own accord, not upon
the Command of Theodebert. The Goths joining with them came before Millan
unexpected by the Romans, and besieged it; that they had no means to import
provisions, but were instantly in want of necessaries. Neither could the
Soldiers guard the walls; Mundilas having put Garrisons into Pergamum, Comum,
Novarra, and other small fortresses near Millan; and having there with himself
but about 300 men, and Ennes and Paulus, so that necessarily the Cityzens were
to guard in their turns. And thus the winter ended, and the third year of this
war written by Precopius.

But Belisarius about midsummer went against Vitigis, leaving in Rome a small
Garrison; and taking the rest with him. He sent some to entrench before Tudera,
Incipit annus quartus bell. Goth, being in It reg. Justinian et anno domini 539.
and Clusium, meanning to follow, and with them to besiege the Goths therein.
But they hearing of the army coming, sent to Belisarius, and yielded upon
composition to have no hurt done them. He took the Goths there, and sent them
to Naples and into Sicily, then left Garrisons in Tudera and Clusium, and
marched on. In the mean time Vitigis sent another army under Vacimus to Auximum,
to join with the Goths there, and to attempt the castle of Ancona. This Ancona
is a cornerd rock, from whence it has the name, Ancoa, signifying an Elbow. It
stands from Auximum ten miles, and is the Haven for it; the Castle is at the
corner of a rock, very secure, but the houses without being not many, have no
defense of walls. Conon, who had the Guard of the place, hearing Vacimus to
come against him, and not far off, fell upon a senseless resolution, as if it
were nothing to save the Castle, Peole, and Soldiers. He left the castle
unguarded, and drew out some five furlongs off, standing in order of battle,
not of any depth, but compassing the hill, as if he were hunting. But when they
saw the Enemy so much exceeding in numbers, they all ran away to the Castle.
The Barbarians pursuing, killed many that could not get in; set to their
Ladders to mount the Castle, and put fire to the houses without. The Romans who
dwelt within were amazed, and first having opened the Gate, and received in the
flying Soldiers, now seeing the Goths at their heels ready to enter with
them, they shut the Gates, and drew up with ropes diverse, and Conon among them.
The Goths, mounting by their Ladders, had taken the Castle, if two men upon the
Battlements had not miraculously thrust them off, the one a Thracian, and a
Lancier to Belisarius, named Vlimun, the other Bulgudas a Hunne, a Lancier of
Valerianus. These by chance landed a little before at Ancona, and in this fight
keeping off the Goths with their Swords, saved the Castle beyond expectation,
but were carried off themselves mangled and half dead.

CHAP. XI.
THen came news to Belisarius, that Narses was come from Constantinople with
an army, and was in Picenia, Narses was an Eunuch, and Treasurer to the
Emperor, valiant above the condition of an Eunuch: with him came 5000 men in
several Regiments, commanded by Justinus, General of Illyrium, and others;
and another Narses, a Pers-Armenian, who revolted formerly to the Romans with
Horatius his Brother, who came a little before to Belisarius with other forces,
and 2000 Herulians under Visandus, Alueth, and Phanotheus. Formerly the
Herulians inhabited beyond the river Ister, serving many Gods, and holding it
no impiety to appease them with human sacrifices. They had Laws differing from
other men: When men were grown aged or sick, they were not to live, But to
entreat their kindred to put them out of the world: Who made a pile of wood,
and set the man in the top, and sent a stranger to him, in blood, with a sword
to dispatch him; then set the pile on fire, and the flame being done, gathered
up his Bones, and buried them. When an Herulian died, his wise (if she would be
thought virtuous) was to strangle her self over her husbands Tomb; otherwise
she was esteemed infamous, and an Enemy to her husbands kindred. In time
over-topping the bordering Barbarians in populousness and power, they
vanquished them in fight one by one, and forraged their country, and kept them
under. They subdued the Lombards being Christians, and made them pay Tribute,
upon Covetousness or vain glory, it being a thing not used by the Barbarians
in those parts. In the Reign of the Emperor Anastasius, having none left to
invade, they remained quiet for three years: But were discontented for it at
their King Rodulphus, flocking about him, and calling him coward, and
immodestly they scoft and abused him. Who not enduring the disgrace, made a
causeless war upon the Lombards, not charging them with breach of Treaties, or
any other pretense. The Lombards sent to R^dulphus to know why the Herulians
were in arms against them; if their Tribute were not all paid, they would
satisfy it with advantage; if they thought it too mean, they would make it
greater. But Redulphus sent their Ambassadors away with Threats. They sent
again other Ambassadors, who used much entreaty; but speeding not, the third
came and advised him; In no sort to make a war without a cause: if he did, the
Lombards (though unwillingly) must oppose the invasion; calling God to
witness, whose least drop upon the scale will weigh down all the power of men,
and as he is induced by the causes, will determine the conclusion of this war.
The Herulians not frighted herewith, nor relenting, resolved to have a Battle.
Both parts being near each other; over the Lombards the air was suddenly over
cast with a black thick cloud; there being a clear sky over the Herulians, a
Presage that the Herulians entered the fight for their own mischeife, and among
those Barbarians before a battle the saddest prodigy that can be. But the
Herulians, not heeding the same, marched proudly against the Enemy, judging of
the success by their great multitudes. But they were very many slain, with
their King Rodulphus, and the rest flying were almost all cut in pieces. Upon
this they left their Country, and passing through all the land beyond the River
Ister, came where the Regians, or Rugians had inhabited, (who were gone with
the Goths into Italy) and there they sat down. But the land being wast, and
famine compelling they removed, and came to a country next the Gepaedes; who at
the first perm^tted them to plant, coming as Suppliants: But afterward they
wronged them, forcing their wives, and making prey of their Cattle and Goods,
and at last began unjust quarrels with them: which the Herulians not able to
bear, past the River Ister to dwell by the Romans there. And Anastasius the
Emperor received them, to plant in the country. Soon after by committing much
wickedness upon their neighboring Romans, they offended him, and he sent an
army against them; which in a battle had the victory, killed most of them, and
would have destroyed them all; but their cheiftains remaining, with
supplications begged their lives, and to be taken for Auxiliaries and Servants
to the Emperor; who granted the same, and so some Herulians escaped alive, but
neither aided nor served the Romans. Justinian coming to the Empire gave them a
good country, and Goods, and made them absolute Associates, and persuaded them
to be Christians; upon this they grew civiller, and applied themselves to the
Laws of Christians, serving the Romans as Auxiliaries. But still they are
false to us, and covetous; not thinking it any shame to wrong their Neighbors.
They use impious mixtures with men and Beasts, being indeed the wickedest of
all men, and wretches wretchedly to perish. Some few of them continued their
League with us; the rest revolted upon this occasion. To show the lavagenesse
of their nature, they killed Ochon their King, suddenly, without alleging any
thing, but that they would no more be under a King. And indeed their King
before had only the name, otherwise little advantage above a private man. All
sat and ate with him, and put licentious scorns on him; the Herulians being
the most indiscreet, and the lightest men alive. This foul Fact they instantly
repented, finding no possibility to live without Governors, and Generals.
After much consultation, they resolved to send for one of the Blood Royal from
the Island of Thule. For the Herulians being overthrown by the Lombards, and
leaving their native Soil, some dwelt in Illyrium (as I said) others past not
the River Ister, but thought it better to plant in the uttermost borders of the
habitable World. Conducted by many of the Blood Royal, they past through all
the Nations of the Slavonians; then passing a large desert Country, they came
to a Nation called the Varnians, after whom they traversed the Nations of the
Danes; the Barbarians there using no violence against them: Then they came to
the Ocean, and getting Shipping, arrived at the Island of Thule, where they
staid.

CHAP. XII.
THule is ten times bigger then Britany, much distant from it to the Northward:
The most of it is waste; Mr. Cambden. Nec me latet vastissiman illam ^egion^m
Scandiam sub Thules nomine a Procopio describi. Indeed this Scandia, wherein is
Norway and part of Denmark, it appears in the Map as a Peninsule. It is
called by some of our Writers, Vagina gentium.
but in that which is inhabited are seated thirteen populous Nations, and over
every Nation is a King. The Sun about the Summer Tropic sets not in the Island
for forty days, being in all that time a strange sight still above the Earth.
And near the Winter Tropic, it is not seen in the Island for forty days, but
a continual night hangs over it; the Inhabitants leading a sad life all the
while, and not conversing which one another. It was not my fortune to go to
this Island, though I much desired to behold the wonder: But inquiring of some
that came from thence, how they knew the due times of Sunrising and
Sunsetting, they told me the true reason; That the Sun sets not indeed there
for forty days, but it shines sometimes from the Eastward, sometimes from the
West; and when they see it return to that place of the Horizon, where first
they saw it rise, they reckon a day and a night. And in the long nights they
count the days by the courses of the Moon, which they see every month. When
five and thirty days are runn out of this long night, men used to it are sent
to the tops of the Mountains, who there seeing the Sun, bring word that within
five days it will shine again. For this good news a solemn Feast is
celebrated in the dark; which is the Thulites greatest Holy Day. They fear (it
seems, notwithstanding their yearly experience) that the Sun may forsake them
quite. Of all the Nations of Thule, only the Scritifini are Savages, who use
no apparel, nor shoes to their feet, nor get any man's meat out of the earth;
themselves neither manuring it, nor their Wives using any work, but both
perpetually hunting; for their vast Woods and Mountains breed multitudes of
wild Beasts; which they, catch and feed upon their flesh, covering themselves
with their Skins, which they patch together with Sinews of Beasts, wanting
thread, or any thing to sow with. Their Children are not nursed like other
people, with Woman's milk, nor hang at the Mothers breast, but are nourished
with the Marrow of the wild Beasts they take. The Woman having brought forth
her child, wraps it in a Skin, and hangs it on a Tree, and laying Marrow to
the mouth of it, out she goes a hunting with her Husband.

The rest of the Thulites differ not much from other people. They worship many
Gods, and Damons, both Celestial, and of the Air, Earth, and Sea; and the
Spirits said to be in Fountains, and Rivers. They are perpetually sacrificing,
and pacifying with blood; and their fairest Victime is a Man, before taken
Prisoner, whom they sacrifice to Mars, esteemed their greatest God. And they
do it, not by cutting his throat only, but hanging him on a tree, and
throwing him among Briars, and other kinds of death. Among these Thulites the
Herulian wanderers, planted themselves; and those who continued among the
Romans, having murdered their King, sent some chief men to the Island of
Thule, to bring home one of the blood royal, if they could find any there.
They found many, and made choice of one whom they liked best, and took him
with them. But being come near home, he dyed of a sickness; and the men went
again to Thule, and brought another, named Todasius, accompanied with his
Brother Aordus, and two hundred Herulians of the Island. Who being long upon
their journey, the Herulians about Singedon conceiving it might be inconvenient
to introduce a King from Thule, without the Emperor Justinians consent, to
Constaneinople to the Emperor, to give them what King he pleased: He sent them
Suartuas, an Herulian, who had long continued in Constantiople, whom the
Herulians at first received joyfully, adored him as King, and obeyed him in the
usual directions: But within few days, they had news how the Ambassadors
from Thule were near. Suartuas commanded them to go out and kill them; and the
Herulians followed him with a seeming approbation; but being within a days
journey of them, they revolted from him by night to the new comers, and
himself alone fled to Constantinople; the Emperor was studious to restore
him; and the Herulians fearing the Romans, betook themselves to the Gepaedes:
And this was the cause of their Revolt.

CHAP. XVIII.
THE Armies of Belisarius and Narses joined at Firma, a City standing near the
Jonian Gulf, a days journey from Auximum. They held a Counsel of War where
to oppose the Enemy with best advantage. If they go to relieve Auximum, they
doubted the Enemy from Auximum might at their backs infest them, and spoil the
Romans inhabiting those parts. And likewise of the beseiged in Ariminum, they
were afraid they might be distressed for want of Victual. Most of the
Captains offended with John, charged him in their speeches for running into
that danger rashly, and to get money, and for crossing (contrary to order) the
Counsels of Belisarius concerning the War. But Narses (who loved John above all
men) fearing least Belisarius upon the Captains speeches might put Ariminum in
the second place, spoke thus. Fellow Commanders, you discourse in things not to
be discoursed of, and consult where none reasonably can be of two Opinions; but
where he who never knew the War may choose upon the sudden. When the danger
appears equal, and the damage alike in mistaking, abundant consultation, and
much discourse is fit, and so to determine the matters propounded. But we
deferring to attempt Auximum now, shall receive no important hurt; for what so
soon can alter our case? Whereas if we receive a blow at Ariminum (as can no
otherwise be) we shall ruin (a harsh word) our whole power in Italy. If John
have contemned your Commands, excellent Belisarius, you have it now in your
power to punish him, by saving the Offender, or abandoning him to the Enemy.
But take heed you do not punish the Emperor and us, for an unwitting Offense
of John. If the Goths take Ariminum, they will make Captive a valiant General
with his Army, and a City of the Emperors obedience. Neither will the
mischief stop there, but even constitute the whole fortune of the War. For the
Enemy have now much advantage in numbers; but by being often beaten, are become
Cowards, their ill Fortune having taken their confidence from them. But if in
this design they prosper, they will soon recover their Spirits; and them
dispute the War with more then equal Courage: Such as escape difficulties
being commonly wiser, then they who never had misfortunes. Thus Narses spoke.
But a Soldier from Ariminum brought Letters to Belisarius from John, which
were thus; Know, that our Victual has long failed us, and we can no longer
answer the People, nor resist the Enemy; but within seven days must sore
against our wills yield the city and our selves. We can no longer strive
against our necessities, which will sufficiently apologize for us, if we shall
do any thing not so honorable. Belisarius at this was troubled, and full of
irresolution. He was afraid of the besieged; and he doubted that the Enemy in
Auximum would fly abroad and burn the towns thereabout without control; and
by watching advantages distress his own army, especially if there should be a
battle. In the end he left Aratius with a thousand men to incamp by the Sea
side, 25 miles from Auximum, and not to stir, nor give fight to the Enemy but
in their own Defense; By this he hoped that Enemy would lie quiet in Auximum,
and not infest his army, having a camp of Romans so near them. He sent also
forces by Sea, commanded by Herodian, Vliaris, and Narses, Brother to Aratius,
and the whole in chief by Ildeger. Whom Belisarius directed to sail directly
for Ariminum, and to land not far off from the foot, which should march by the
Sea shore commanded by Martinus, and appointed to wait upon the Fleet; whom he
directed being near the Enemy to light many fires, not proportionable to their
small army so to give the Enemy apprehension of greater numbers. Himself with
Narses, and the rest of the army, marched by Vrbisalia, far from the Sea coast;
a city so ruined by Alaricus, that nothing remained of the former beauty, but
some relics of one Gate, and of the pavement. Here I met with this adventure.
When Jo came with his army into P. the people were in much confusion. and the
women some suddenly fled where they could, others were carried away captives.
In this place some woman, newly delivered of a Child, had left it in swathing
clouts upon the Ground; whether she ran away, or were taken from it by the
Enemy, she never did return, being likely either gone out of Italy, or the
World. The child lying in that Desert cried, and a she Goat perceiving it,
pitied it, and having also lately brought forth young, came to it and gave it
her Teate, guarding the child, that no Dog nor wild beast might hurt it. The
troubles lasting long in the country, this Infant had long the benefit of this
Teat. But the Picenians finding the Emperors army was come against the Goths
only, and not to hurt the Romans, returned to their several homes. And into
Vrbisalia the women with their husbands coming, and seeing the child, could not
imagine what it was, and wondered how it lived: such women as were sit, offered
their breasts; but the child would not take woman's milk, neither would the Goat
leave it; but importunatly bleated, and seemed to be greived at the women's
troubling it, and in a word pretended to it her own. So that the women let it
alone, and the Goat nursed it; for which the people called the child Aegisthus.
I traveling that way, they brought me to it, and angered it to make it cry;
the Goat hearing it, being a stones cast off, ran to it bleating, and stood
over it that none might hurt it, and this is the story of Aegisthus.

CHAP. XV.
BUT Belisarius marched by the mountains, resolving not to come to a direct
battle, being much inferior in numbers, and the Goths desperate with their
misfortunes. But he thought that when they heard of Forces invading on every
side, they would not resist, but run away; and the guest as it fell out. For
being upon the Mountains a days journey from Ariminum, he lighted upon Goths
traveling about business; who being suddenly surprised, could not turn out
of the way, but were some slain by the Romans, and the rest wounded ran up, and
hid them in the rocks: from whence seeing the Romans marching many together in
narrow passages, they judged them far more then they were, and perceiving the
Ensign of Belisarius, they knew that he led them. The night overtaking, the
Romans flayed there, and the Goths hurt men run to Vitigis Camp; whether being
arrived about noon the next day, they showed their wounds, and reported
Belisarius to be at hand with an innumerable army. Hereupon they prepared to
fight; marching to the North of Ariminum (which way they thought the Enemy
would come) and still looking to the mountain tops. At night having put off
their arms, and taking their rest, they saw fires some seven miles from the
City Eastward, kindled by Martinus. They fell into terrible fear, apprehending
in the morning to be surrounded by the Enemy; and so lay still that night in
that fear. And by Sun rising they saw a great fleet coming, which even struck
them dumb; that with tumult and clamouring they tru^s'd up, harkning to no
commands, nor thinking upon any thing but how to get quit of the camp, and
within the walls of Ravenna. If the besieged had had any strength or courage
left, they had cut the Enemy in pieces, and made an end of the war; but they
were heartlesse with their miseries, and feeble with want of food. The Goths in
that confusion left much of their baggage behind, and ran amain to Ravenna
Ildiger with his forces first seized the Enemies trenches, took the baggage
they left there, and some sick men At noon Belisarius came with the army, and
seeing John and his company pale, and greivously nasty, he said, he must give
thanks to Ildiger, glancing at his unadvised presumption. He answered that he
acknowledged none to Ildiger, but to Narses the Emperors Treasurer; intimating
that Belisarius did not willingly relieve him, but persuaded by Narses; both
these were ever after jealous of each other: That Narses friends would not let
him march with Belisarius, su^gesting how poor it was for him who communicated
of the Emperors secrets, not to be an absolute commander, but to obey one that
was but a General; and that Belisarius would never endure to command with him
in Equality, but that if he would himself lead an army, he should have more
Soldiers and better captains to follow him; the Herulians, and his own
Lanciers and Targetiers, and the troops under Justinus and John himself, with
those of Narses and Aratius, being not less in all then 10000 valiant men and
able Soldiers. That they would not have the conquest of Italy wholly
attributed to Belisarius, but Narses to share in it, who had not left his
attendance on the Emperors person, to establish with his own dangers the Glory
of Belisarius; but by showing his own valor and wisdom, to grow famous in the
world; and that Belisarius without him could do nothing; most of the army
commanded by him being dispersed in the places he had taken. All which they
reckoned up from Sicily to Picenia. Narses was much pleased with these
discourses, and could not contain himself within his present condition: but
Belisarius directing him any business, still he flew to some excuse, rejecting
his commands. Which Belisarius observing, he assembled the Commanders, and
spoke thus. Fellow commanders, I find not my self to be of the same opinion
with you concerning this War. You despise the Enemy, as absolutely subdued; but
I think this confidence will bring you into danger; knowing that the Goths
have not been beaten through their cowardice, or want of men, but
overstratagem'd with counsel and foresight, and so routed. And you in like
sort I fear from some false opinion may receive a blow, which may undo your
selves and the Roman affairs. They are more easily undone, who are insolent
with successes and conceit of victory; then such as having lost some honor, do
for the time to come use fear and caution toward their Enemies. Carelessness
has ruined many well settled, and a solicitous labor releived men after
misfortunes: the powers of the negligent lessening of themselves, but care
naturally adding powers, Consider that Vitigis is in Ravenna with many
thousands, That Vraas besieges Millar, and holds all Liguria; That in Auximum
is a great and gallant army; and that there are other garrisons of Goths able
to fight with us, all along to Vrbiventum, which is a neighbor to Rome. That
if we should now be compassed by the Enemy, our danger were more then ever. The
Francks also are said to be in arms in Liguria, which every Roman ought to
consider and apprehend. My opinion therefore is, that part of the army be sent
into Liguria and Millan, and all the rest to march against Auximum, and
undertake as God shall enable, and as shall seem best and most advantageous. To
this speech of Belisarius, Narses replied. Noble General, in all the rest
(being nothing but truth) none can contradict you; but that all the rest of the
Emperors army should be confined to Auximum and Millan, I hold it
inconvenient; for you to lead such of the army as you please for those
purposes, is good reason: In the mean time we will get Lombard Ci^padana, from
the city of Ast to Parma vid. Leanurum.
Emilia for the Emperor, a Province most set by by the Goths; and we will give
such alarmes to Ravenna, that you shall bring the Enemy on your part to what
terms you please, being excluded from hope of succors. I fear if we sit down
before Auximum together, the Goths will set on us from Ravenna, and we shall be
charged on both sides, and wanting Victual perish upon the place. Belisarius
fearing least by dividing the Forces, the Emperors Affairs might fall
asunder, and ruin by the disorder arising from thence; produced the Emperors
Letters directed to the Commanders in these words. We have sent Narses our
Treasurer into Italy, not to command the Army; it being our pleasure that
Belisarius alone shall have the leading thereof, whethersoever himself thinks
best; and it behooves you all to follow him for the good of our State. Narses
took hold of the last words of this Letter; and said, that Belisarius did now
advise against the good of the State, and therefore they were not bound to
follow him.

CHAP. XV.
BElisarius upon this sent Peranius with an Army to beseige Vrbiventum;
Himself led the rest to Vrbinum, a strong Town, a days journey from Ariminum,
which had a good Garrison of Goths within it: Narses and John followed him, but
before the Town they encamped severally at the foot of the Hill, Belisarius on
the East side, and Narses on the West. Vrbinum stands upon a round high Hill,
not craggy, but unsafe to mount, only for the steepness, and neernesse to the
City. Toward the North is an entrance upon plain ground. Belisarius (the Army
being thus quartered) sent Ambassadors to the Goths, hoping to bring them
(being afraid) to a composition; and promising many advantages by their
submission to the Emperor. The Ambassadors at the Gates (being not admitted
into the Town) used many allurements; but the Goths presuming upon the strength
of the place, and their abundance of Provisions, rejected them and their
motions. Belisarius upon this caused the Army to gather Poles, and with them to
make a Gallery for men, to approach the Gates and Walls under this covert. Some
Friends of Narses told him that Belisarius labored in vain, ( John having
attempted the place when the Garrison was small, and found it impregnable)
therefore he should take in the Emperors Towns in Emilia. Narses upon this
advise rose that night (though much wooed by Belisarius to stay and help to
take Vrbinum) and went to Ariminum with the rest of the Army. Morras and the
Goths under him, in the morning seeing half the Army gone, flouted from their
Walls at those that staid behind. But Belisarius with them resolved, to
assault, and consulting about it, he had strange Success. The only Fountain in
Vrbinum which watered all the Inhabitants, grew dry of it self, and in three
days so failed, that the Goths drunk the water with mud, whereupon they
determined to yield: whereof Belisarius not knowing, put the Army in readiness
to assault round about the Hill, and commanded to bring on the wooden Gallery
upon the even ground. The men within unseen by the Enemy brought the same on,
at which the Goths held out their hands, crying for peace. The Romans knowing
nothing of the Fountain, conceived that it was the Fight they feared, which
they gladly forbear: And the Goths rendered themselves, and Town to Belisarius,
upon composition of indemnity, they becoming Subjects to the Emperor, and
serving in the Army with equal conditions. Narses wondered to hear the News,
and took it for a misfortune. He lay still in Ariminum, but commanded John with
the Army to lead out against Cesina. They approach the Castle with their
scaling Ladders upon their backs, and assaulted; But the Goths defended
stoutly, and Phanotheus Leader of the Herulians was slain, and many more, so
that John would attempt it no more, seeming impregnable, but marched on with
Justinus, and the rest of the Army, and took an ancient City, named Forum
Corneli^, by surprise: And he recovered all Emilia; the Goths avoiding still to
fight with him. Belisarius also having taken in Vrbinum, thought it not
expedient (being at the Winter Tropic) to go against Auximum, expecting a long
Seige of it, the place being strong, and impossible to be forced, by reason the
Goths within it were many, and of the best, who having forraged much Country,
had brought in great quantity of Provisions, so that he appointed Aratius to
winter in Firmum, and to restrain the Goths incursions, and to spoil the
Country; and himself marched against Vrbiventum, persuaded by Peranius, who had
learnt of run awaies, that the Goths within wanted Victual; and that it was
thought, they would yield upon sight of Belisarius Army, which came so to
pass. Belisarius quartered his Army before it, and himself went round, and
viewed the Town, and found it not possible to be taken by force, but he thought
by some plot it might be faisable. Vrbiventum is built upon a Hill, standing
alone in a Valley, and being plain at the top, and toward the bottom craggy.
About it, a stones cast off are many Rocks, and the Town has no Walls, nor
other Fortification, Nature having made it impregnable; in regard there is but
one way to it between those Rocks: which being guarded, the Townes-men fear no
invasion at any other part. And where the way into the Town is, a large River
unfordable takes up all the space between the Hill and those Rocks. So that
there is only a small Fortification at the said passage, and a Gate to it,
which the Goths guarded.

CHAP. XVI.
BUT Belisarius begirt the Town with his Army, hoping to incommode the Enemy
from the River, and to take them by Famine. The Goths for a while were in no
absolute wants, and though furnished very barely, yet they endured beyond
expectation, having not Food to satisfy, but to keep alive only; and their
Provisions being failed, they fed upon Hides, and Skins soaked in water, and
upon vain hopes, which Albilas their Commander gave them, a man of great
Reputation with the Goths.

The Summer being come, the Corn in all those parts grew of it self, but not
in such quantity as formerly; being not covered under Furrows by the Plow and
Harrow; but lying upon the Face of the Land, which could yield so but small
Crop: And none being to reap it, much shed, and never grew again. The same
happened in Emilia, that the Inhabitants went all into Picenia, which being
upon the Sea, they thought the Famine not to be so much there: Which seized
also upon Tuscany; but there the Mountainers grinded Acornes, and made bread,
which bred all kind of Diseases in many; but some recovered and lived. But in
Picenia 50000. Roman Husbandmen at least perished, and more on this side the
Jonian Gulf. I have seen their Countenances, and manner of deaths. They grew
lanck, and pale, the Flesh wanting Food (according to the old saying) feeding
on it self; Choler prevailing spread a wan Complexion over their Bodies: And as
the Disease grew, all moisture forsook them; the Skin was hard like a tanned
Hide, and looked as if it cleft to the bones; afterward they became
black-coloured, and like Lincks much burnt. Their Countenance were hideous,
like madmen; and as most dyed for want of Sustenance, so some with greedy
feeding: whose heat being quenched within, if they were nourished to
satisfaction, and not by little, and little, like Babes new born, being not
able to digest the meat, they dyed. Some forced by the Famine fed upon one
another. Two Women in a Village beyond. Ariminum were reported to have eaten
17. men, they only were left alive in the place, and so Passengers lodged in
their Cottage, whom they killed sleeping, and eat them. As they were attempting
the like upon the 18. he waked, and finding out the truth, killed them both.
Many being pincht with this Famine, went where there was Grass, and stooping
to gather it, but being not strong enough to pull it up, they fell upon their
hands, and dyed with the Grass in their mouths. None buried any, nor had the
least thought of Funerals: The very ravenous Fowls, that feed on dead bodies,
would not touch them, there being no flesh left to allure them, which the
Famine had consumed all. So grievous was that Famine.

But Belisarius sent Martinus and Vliaris with an Army against Vrbias and the
Goths, whom he heard to besiege Millan. They encamped and stayed upon the Poe a
days journey from Millan, and spent much time in consulting about their
passage over the River. Which Mundilas understanding, sent one Paulus a Roman
to them; who slipped by the Enemy and finding no Boats upon the Poe stripped
himself, and in great danger swam over the River. Coming to the Roman Camp he
told the Commanders Martinus and Vliaris, that they did unjustly, and not
befitting their reputations, to come there in pretense to serve the Emperor,
but in effect to augment the Goths power. That Millan, the chief of the
Italian Cities for bigness, wealth, and populousness, being a Bulwark for the
whole Roman Empire against the Germans, and other Barbarians, is now in peril
with Mundilas and the Emperors Forces, and yet by them neglected. The wrong
they did the Emperor, he would forbear to aggravate, time not allowing many
words, but demanding speedy succor, whilst yet some hope is left. That
therefore they must instantly relieve Millan; if they delayed it, Our fortunes
(quoth he) will be after the bitterest sufferings to perish, and yours, to
betray the Emperors Soldiers to the Enemy.. Seeing such are justly said to
betray, not only who open their Gates to an Enemy, but who having means to
rescue their best Friends beseiged, by preferring a backward security before
hazarding, abandon them to the Enemy. Paulus spoke in that sort, and Martinus
and Vliaris promised him to follow immediately, and so sent him away; who
entered Millan by night, revived the Soldiers and other Romans, and made them
yet more cheerful in their Faith to the Emperor.

CHAP. XVII.
BUT still the Troops with Martinus were backward, and lay still, and so
continued long. Martinus to put the blame from himself, wrote thus to
Belisarius: You sent us out to relieve our distressed Friends in Millan: we
have used our best diligence, and are as far as the River of Poe; which the
Army fears to pass, hearing that in Liguria is a great Army of Goths, and a
multitude of Burgundians; with whom we conceive our selves not able to fight.
Command therefore John and Justinus (who are our neighbors in Emilia) to join
their Troops with us in this adventure; whereby we shall be safe our selves,
and do some hurt to the Enemy. Belisarius upon receite of this Letter,
commanded John and Justinus immediately to join with Martinus for Millan. They
refused, unless Narses directed them; whereupon Belisarius wrote thus to
Narses: Consider how the Emperors Army is one body: If (as members in bodies)
you be not all of a mind, but will be doing one without another concurrence;
in the end (having done nothing you should) you will all perish. Wherefore
leave Emilia, which has no strong place in it, and for (...) present is not of
any importance to us; and command John and Justinus immediately to march with
Martinus against the Enemy before Millan, whose Troops are near the same, and
well furnished to vanquish the Barbarians. From hence it is not convenient to
send Forces thither, much time will be spent in the march, that they will come
after the season; and being come, they will not be able to use their Horses in
a fight after so long a journey. But those, and Martinus and Vliaris marching
to Millan, in likely hood will beat the Goths, and then again subdue Emilia,
none being to oppose them. Narses after perusal of this Letter, wrote to John
and Justinus to march to Millan accordingly. John afterward was sent to the
Seacoast, to get Barks for transporting the Army over the Poe; but a sickness
hindered his business. In the mean time of this backwardness of Martinus
Troops, and John's staying for Narses his Orders, the Besieged became infinitely
distressed with Famine. The extremity constrained them to feed on Dogs, Rats,
Mice, and such uncouth creatures. The Goths sent to Mundilas to render the
City, offering Indemnity to himself, and the Soldiers. He accepted, so they
would give assurances of performance, and not use hard measure to the
Inhabitants. When the Enemy had given assurances to Mundilas and the Soldiers,
but being angry with the Ligurians, appeared resolved to destroy them; he
called the Soldiers and spoke thus. If ever men have chosen to dye honorably
when they might have lived basely, such would I have you now to be, and not for
love of breath to live in disgrace; the rather being of the School of
Belisarius, where you have learnt so plentifully, that it were impious not to
be generous, and extremely daring. To all men that come into this light, one
fate is appointed, in their due time to dye. But in the manner of their deaths
men are distinguished; Cowards first becoming the scorn and laughter of their
Foes, fulfill their destiny too in their defined times. But generous men suffer
the same with Virtue, and an advantage of Honor. If by becoming Slaves to the
Barbarians we could preserve this People, our base preservation would have an
excuse; but for us to behold so many Romans destroyed by the Enemy, is more
bitter then any death; for we shall seem even to have helped the Goths to act
this Calamity. Whilst therefore we are yet Masters of our selves, and can bear
necessity with Virtue, let us make this our hard Fortune, our Glory. My Opinion
is, to arm our selves completely, and to sally upon the Enemy not looking for
us: We shall gain one of these two; either Fortune to do something for us, or
else an honorable riddance of our miseries, by a happy death beyond our hopes.
The Soldiers for all these words of Mundilas would not hazard, but yielded
themselves and the City upon the Conditions offered. Them the Goths hurt not,
but made Prisoners with Mundilas, but the City they demolisht to the Ground,
killing men of all ages, 300000. at least. The Women they made Slaves, and gave
to the Burgundians, to gratify their joining with them. Finding there
Reparatus, Prefect of the Palace, they cut him in pieces, and threw them to
the Dogs. Vergentinus, who was then in Millan, went into Dalmatia with his
Troops through Venetia, This is now Marca Trivigiana, says Leander.
and other Countries, and from thence brought the news to the Emperor, of the
Romans Disaster at Millan. The Goths also took other Towns by composition from
the Roman Garrisons, and quickly subdued all Liguria. And Martinus and Vliaris
returned toward Rome with their Army.

CHAP. XVIII.
BElisarius heard nothing of these Occurrents in Liguria, but the Winter being
ended, he marched with his Army into Picenia: In which Journey he understood to
his great grief what was become of Millan. Vliaris he suffered not to come
into his sight, and wrote the whole matter to the Emperor, who punished no man;
but hearing of the differences between Belisarius and Narses, he sent for
Narses home, and appointed Belisarius absolutely to command all the Army.
Narses went to Constantinople with some few Soldiers; And being gone, the
Herulians would (...) stay in Italy, though Belisarius in his own name and the
Emperors made them large promises. They first went into Liguria; where meeting
with Vraeas his Army, they sold their Slaves, and Cattle they had, and for a
Sum of money given them, swear never to take Arms against the Goths, and so
peaceably they came into Venetia; where having speech with Vitalius, they
repented of their Error against the Emperor, and to expiate the same, left
Visandus there, and his Troops. The rest came to Constantinople, conducted by
Alu^th, and Philimuth, who was chief; Phanotheus being dead in his Tent.

But Vitigis hearing that in the beginning of the Spring Belisarius would come
against him, and the Goths in Ravenna, they were all afraid, and consulted
what to do; and finding upon debate themselves alone not able to match the
Enemy, they resolved to draw in the aid of other Barbarians. Of the Germans
they were shy, having already had experience of their unfaithfulness, being
contented they should continue neutrall, not joining with Belisarius. But to
Vacis King of the Lombards they sent Ambassadors and large Sums for aid; but
he being a Friend, and Auxiliary of the Emperor, they returned without doing
any thing. So that Vitigis, in much perplexity, demanded the advice of ancient
men, what was to be done to repair his Affairs. After many Opinions of his
Counsel, some unseasonable, some worthy of consideration, it was said; That
the Roman Emperor could not invade the Barbarians of the West, before he had
made truce with the Persians. Then the Vandales, and Moors were ruined, and
these things now befell the Goths. If the King of Persia might be put into a
quarrel with Justinian, the Romans in war with that Nation could maintain none
elsewhere. Vitigis liked the Counsel, and resolved to send Ambassadors, who
were not Goths, to set Chosroes, King of Persia, at variance with Justinian
(for fear of discovering, and spoiling of the negotiation.) But they persuaded
two Priests of Liguria with money to undertake the Service. One of them taking
upon him the show and name of a Bishop, was the Ambassador, and the other went
as his attendant. To these Vitigis gave his Letters to Chosroes, who being
therewith moved, did those mischiefs to the Romans during the Truce I
formerly, related. And the Emperor, so soon as he found the Persians plotting
those mischiefs, thought good to end the War in the West: He sent therefore
for Belisarius to go against the Persian, and he dispatched Vitigis
Ambassadors, (who yet were at Constantinople) with promise to send some to
Ravenna, to conclude a Truce with the Goths, as should be expedient for both
parts. But Belisarius made stay of the Enemies Ambassadors, until they also
sent home Athanasius and Peter, who went to Constantinople, and were highly
rewarded. Incipit. Annus 5. belli Goth. 13. Reg. Justiniani and Ann. Dom. 540.
Athanasius the Emperor made Prefect of the Palace in Italy, and Peter,
Captain of the Emperors Guard. And thus the Winter ended, and the fourth year
of this War, written by Proc^pius.

Belisarius resolved first to get Auximum and Faesulae, and then no Enemy being
in his way, nor to be at his back, to set upon Vitigis and Ravenna. Unto
Faesulae he sent Cyprian and Jastinus with their own Troops, and some
Isaurians, and 500. Foot under D^metrius; these beseiged the Goths in that
Castle. Toward the Poe he sent Martinus and John Phagas with their own Troops,
and other Forces, commanded by that John; whom he directed, in case Vraeas with
his Forces came toward them out of Millan, by any means to get the Rear of
them, and to follow at their backs. These taking Dorthon, a Town unwalled upon
the River, there encamped.

CHAP. XIX.
BElisarius himself with eleven thousand men came before Auximum; which is the
Metropolis of Picenia. It stands ten miles and a half from the shore of the
Jonian Gulf, and from Ravenna three days journey, and ten miles more, upon a
high Hill, with no entrance in any plain ground, and so not approachable by an
Enemy. Vitigis had Garrisoned in it the choicest Goths, supposing that the
Romans, missing this Town, would not dare to invade Ravenna. Belisarius
encamped his Army round about the bottom of the Hill, divided and lodged in
several quarters. The Goths seeing them thus severed, and not likely in a
great Campagnia to succor one another, charged them about evening from the
East side of the Town, where Belisarius Quarter was with his Lanciers and
Targetiers: who opposed the Invaders, and soon routed them; and pursuing got up
to the midst of the Hill; where the Barbarians trusting to the advantage of the
place, turned head against them, killed many, shooting upon their heads, till
the night prevented them. The day before this skirmish, some Goths being sent
out early to get Provisions, were returning by night; and seeing the Romans
fires, stood amazed. Many adventured and got into Auximum unseen by the Romans,
others of them hid themselves in the Woods, thinking to go to Ravenna, but
were surprised, and all cut in pieces. Belisarius finding Auximum strong, and
no means to assault it, despaired to take it by force, but hoped by a close
Siege to reduce them to wants, and in time to subdue them. The store of Grass
near the Walls was occasion of daily skirmishes: The Romans seeing the Goths
cut the same for their Horses, ran up the Hill, fought with them gallantly
still, hindered their carrying away the Grass, and killed many of them. The
Barbarians overmatcht by their Enemies valor, did thus. They took the Wheels
and Axeltrees off their Wagons, and (their men beginning to cut Grass) they
rolled them down upon the Romans, when they were ascended the middle of the
Hill; but they went to the bottom without touching a man. The Goths failing
herein, ran into the Town. Afterward they laid an ambush of their best men in
Valleys near the town; then some few appeared about the Grass plot, and when
the fight was come to Sword and Lance, they rose from their ambush, and having
the advantage much in numbers, and amazing the Romans being unlookt for, they,
killed many, and put the rest to flight. The Romans in the quarters saw the
Enemy rise from their ambush, and cried loud to their companions to retire, but
were not heard, being divided from them the whole length of the hill, and the
Barbarians clashing their arms to drown their cries. Belisarius was troubled
at it, and Procopius, the writer of this History, came to him, and said. Noble
General, Anciently the Roman Trumpeters were skillful in two tunes, one
composed to encourage the Soldiers to fight, the other to sound a retreat,
when the General saw his time: Who by this means signified his pleasure, and
the Soldiers put it in Execution. For in a battle to do it by shouting is
impossible; the fright of it amazing, and the clashing of arms overcoming the
noise. But now rudeness has berest us of this skill, and we cannot signify
both with one Trumpet: wherefore do you thus. Let the horsemens trumpets
encourage the Soldiers to fight, and let those of the foot call them to the
retreat; they cannot but distinguish the sound, the one being made of Leather,
and very thin wood, and the other of a thick piece of Brass. Belisarius liked
Procopius advise, and calling the army, spoke thus. Courage and forwardness is
expedient and commendable so far as it is moderate, and hurts not them who use
it; all things becoming ever worse with Excess. Commit therefore no more of
these Errors through vain ambition; to fly sometime is no shame, and who
unadvisedly runs into evident mischief, if he chance to escape, yet is he
guilty of Folly. The gallant man is he, that fights valiantly in time of need.
The Goths now unable to fight with you, endeavor to ruin you with ambushes;
and you are more to be blamed for standing the danger, then if you had run out
of their ambush; nothing being baser, then to serve an Enemies Counsels. I
will be careful to prevent your falling into ambushes; and you, when I give
the signal, presently retire, which shall be done by the sound of the foot
Trumpets. The Soldiers after this speech, seeing the Enemy at the Grass, went
toward them, and at first killed some. A Moore espying one of them with Gold
Ornaments, ook him by the hair, and drew him aside to strip him; but a Goth hit
him through both the calves of his legs with a dart, and so fettered them both
together, yet still he drew the dead body, holding, it by the Hair. In this
instant the Goths rose from their ambush, and immediately Belisarius seeing all
from the camp, caused the foot Trumpets to sound, which the Romans hearing,
retired gently, taking up the Moore with the Dart through his legs. The Goths
durst not follow them, but retired too. Afterward the Goths considered how they
might advertise Vitigis of their wants, which grew great, and none adventuring
to go, as thinking it impossible to slip by the Enemy, they observed a night
without moon light, and preparing their men with Letters to Vitigis, when the
night was far spent, they made great cries upon the walls, as if they were in
some terrible confusion, pressed by Enemies, and their town suddenly taken. The
Romans could not imagine the cause, and kept within their quarters by
Belisarius's direction, fearing a surprise from the Town, and from some army
from Ravenna, which might be come to the Enemies succor; and so thought better
to lie still in a safe place, then in a dark night to run into danger: Whereby
the Goths sent out their men unespied to Ravenna; who the third day, without
meeting Enemy, delivered the Letters to Vitigis, to this Effect.

When your Majesty placed us in Auximum, you said, that in our hands you left
the keys of Ravenna, and of your Kingdom, and you therefore summoned our
uttermost power to conserve the dominion of the Goths, and if we needed it, you
promised to come to us unsent for with your whole army. We have fought with
Famine and Belisarius, and been faithful Guards of your Kingdom; but you have
not thought meet to succor us at all. Think if the Romans take Auximum, and
the keys which lie here by you forgotten, whether they will be kept out of any
thing you have. Vitigis, upon perusal hereof, promised forthwith to succor
Auximum with his whole forces, and difmist the men: But upon better
consideration he lay still, doubting least the troops with John might fall upon
his back, and before him fearing a great power of resolute men with Belisarius;
but principally want of victual troubled him, not knowing from whence to
furnish his army, in regard the Romans were masters of the Sea, and
transporting their provisions from Sicily and Calabria, to the Castle of
Ancona, from thence had it brought with case in the due season; but the Goths
in Picenia should have no means of supply. But the Messengers came safe to
Auximum with Vitigis promise, which raised them with vain hope. And Belisarius
hearing thereof, caused the Guards to be more strictly kept.

In the mean time Cyprian and Justinus, besieging Faesulae, could not approach
to assault the place; and the Goths willing rather to end it by fights, then to
endure the want of victual, sallied often. At first the fights were equal, in
the end the Romans being too hard for them, shut them within their walls;
keeping exact watch that none might get out. In Auximum the Goths perplexed
with their wants, sent out again to Vitigis for succor, as unable to hold out
any longer. He directed Vraeas with the army in Liguria to march into Picenia;
promising also to come to the besieged with his whole power. Vraeas went into
Picenia accordingly, with the army with him; passed the Poe, and came near the
Romans Camp. and sat down about 7 miles distant from them. They began no
fights, the Romans thinking it enough to keep them from joining with the
besieged. And the Goths were afraid to fight, considering if they should lose
the battle, they should ruin all; being to have no more means of joining with
Vitigis, and with him of opposing the Enemy: with there counsels they both lay
still.

CHAP. XX.
IN the mean time the Francks hearing how both the Goths and Romans were wasted
with this war, conceived it easy to get a good share of Italy, and repined to
sit idle thus, and look upon others, disputing a province so near neighboring.
So that forgetting their late oaths and accords both with Romans and Goths
(for this nation of all men is the most slippery of Faith) with an army of
50000 men under the leading of Theodebert, they invaded Italy. They had some
few horse men, Lanc^ers, to attend their King. The rest were foot men, without
bows or Lances, only wearing a sword, a shield, and a battle axe; the iron
whereof was broad and sharp on both sides, and the handle very short; This upon
a signal at the first charge they throw from them, to break the Enemies
sheilds and kill them. Thus the Francks, passing the Alps which divide Gaul
and Italy, came into Liguria. The Goths were before angry for their not
accepting their offers of a large country, and great sums to aid them; but
now hearing Theodebert was come with a mighty army they rejoiced; and hoped to
beat their Enemy now without striking stroke. And the Francks, while they were
in Liguria, hurt not the Goths, that they might find no impediment in their
passage over the Poe; and at a Town in Picenia, where was an ancient bridge
over the River, the Garrison supplied them, and let them at their pleasure
pass the Poe. But the Francks being masters of the Bridge, such women and
children as they found, they sacrificed, and threw into the River as the first
spoils of the War, It seems they had Almans with them yet Heathen. See
Agathias lib. 1. cap. 3.
retaining yet (though Christians) much of the old religion, and using
sacrifices, and other ungodly Rites in making their predictions. The Goths
seeing it, in a great fear fled into the town, and the Francks being past,
marched toward the Goths Camp: Who at first seeing them in small troops, were
glad of their coming, thinking it to be to aid them. But when numbers came on,
and fell to the business, and darting their Battle axes hurt many, they turned
about, and ran away by the Romans camp into Ravenna. The Romans seeing them
fly, thought that Belisarius had vanquished them in fight, and taken their camp
from them; and they took arms, thinking to join with him in the pursuit; but
they found an Enemy unlook't for, and unwillingly they fought, till being
beaten, and not able to return to their camp, they fled into Tuscany, and sent
News of the accident to Belisarius. The Francks having conquered both parts,
and taken their Camps without any men in them; there then found their
provisions. But in a while they had nothing to feed on in a wasted Country, but
Oxen, and water of the Poe, no bread at all, and being not able to digest the
flesh, and abundance of water, they fell into fluxes and dysenteries, which they
could not get cured for want of things convenient: So that a third part of them
are said to have so perished, and being not able to march on, they staid there.
Belisarius hearing of this army of Francks, and how the troops of John and
Martinus were routed, he was afraid of his army, especially of those before
Faesulae, who were nearest the Barbarians, and he wrote this Letter to
Theodebert. Noble Theodebert, for one pretending to virtue, and especially
being a King of so great a Nation, not to be true of his word, is not Princely;
but to violate oaths and accords reduced into writing, is not fit for the
meanest man. Herein you know your self a Transgressor; having lately agreed to
join with us against the Goths; and now not so much as continuing neutrall,
but advisedly having taken arms, and set upon us. Put not this affront upon
the Emperor, Good Sr. who will revenge it in the highest kind. It is better
for a man to hold his own securely, then by meddling with what belongs not to
him, to run a danger in that which most concerns him. Theodebert upon this
Letter, and being troubled with his present Estate, and reviled by the Germans
for letting them die thus in a desert country to no purpose, rose with the
Francks surviving, and made haste home.

CHAP. XXI.
Nevertheless Martinus and John came back with their Troops, least the Enemy
should set upon the Army before Auximum. Where the Goths hearing nothing of the
Franks retreat, but despairing at the delays from Ravenna, thought once more
to importune Vitigis, but could not get by the Enemy. Seeing at noon one
Burcensius, a Bessian by birth, and a Soldier of Narses the Armenian, standing
Sentinel to keep off the Town from cutting Grass; some came to parley with
him, and agreed to give him a great Sum in hand to carry a Letter to Ravenna,
and more at his return with Letters from Vitigis. The man for the Money
undertook the service, and presently put it in execution. He brought the
Letters sealed up to Vitigis with all speed, which were thus. You will perceive
our estate, by enquiring who is the bearer of this Letter; there being no
means for a Goth to get out of the Town walls; and our best supply of
Victual is the Grass that grows about them, which we cannot touch without
fighting and loss of men. To what conclusion this will bring us, you and the
Goths in Ravenna are seriously to consider. Vitigis returned this answer: My
best Friends in the World! think not I am so dejected, nor come to that degree
of baseness, as through sloth to abandon the Goths affairs; my own journey
was in readiness, and Vraeas by my direction was coming from Millan with his
Army; but an unexpected invasion of Franks stopped our preparations, whereof I am
not to bear the blame: For things above humane power bestow this favor on the
unfortunate, to make him unblameable; Fortune taking the whole imputation upon
her self. But Theodebert being now gone, as we hear, we will shortly, God
willing, be with you with our whole Army. And you must bear your Fortune
valiantly, and suitably to the necessity. Think upon the virtue for which we
made choice of you to guard Auximum; and respect that general opinion held of
you by all the Goths, which set you there a Bulwark of Ravenna, and of their
whole safety.

Vitigis with this Letter and good store of Money, dispatched the man: Who
coming before Auximum pretended to his Companions a sudden sickness, which
caused him to go to a Church near there for cure; and standing Sentinel where
he was wont, he delivered the Letters unseene by the Romans. The reading
whereof so raised their Spirits, though oppressed with the Famine, that they
would not yield, albeit Belisarius much woed them to it: But having no news of
any Army from Ravenna, and being in extreme want of Victual, again they sent
Burcensius, writing only, That they were able to struggle with the Famine five
days, and no more; who brought them again a Letter from Vitigis, holding them
in suspense with like hopes. The Romans also were weary of this long Siege in a
barren desert Country, and troubled to see the Goths not to yield, though in
so much misery. Belisarius therefore sought to take some Enemy alive, from whom
he might learn the ground of this obstinacy of the Goths. Valerianus promised
to serve him therein; who had in his Troops Slavonians, that used to lie under
some Stone or Bush, and to steal Enemies; a thing ordinarily practiced by them
by the River Ister, where their dwellings are, both upon Romans and Barbarians.
Belisarius liking his way, and committing it to his care, he chose out a
Slavonian, a tall lusty fellow, and valiant, and assured him a good reward from
Belisarius to get an Enemy alive; and told him, That at the Grass plat, which
the Goths used to eat for want of food, he might do it with ease. The
Slavonian before day-breake, put himself near the Town walls, concealed in a
Bush, and gathering up his feet close about him. By daylight a Goth came out
to gather Grass, suspecting nothing from the Bush; but had his eye upon the
Camp, least any enemy might come from thence. The Slavonian stealing behind
him, snatched him up fast between his arms, and delivered him to Valerianus;
who enquiring, from what confidence the Goths being so weak refused to yield,
and wilfully endured so much distress; the Barbarian told him all the story
about Burcensius, desiring he might be brought face to face. Burcensius seeing
himself discovered, concealed nothing; and Belisarius gave him to his
Companions to use him as they pleased, who burnt him alive in the sight of the
Enemy: And this fruit had Burcensius, of his covetousness. But Belisarius
seeing the Goths still hold out, he had a design upon their water, by that way
thinking to take them in with most ease and advantage.

CHAP. XXII.
THere was a Springhead to the Northward of Auximum, in a craggy ground, a
stones cast from the Town, sending a small stream into a Cistern anciently
there built, which being filled from that small stream, supplied water for the
Citizens. Belisarius thought that if the water were not received into the
Cistern, the Goths being plied with Arrows, would be long filling their
Vessels from so small a stream. To spoil this Cistern, he did thus; he put his
Forces in Arms, and in their orders round about the Town, as if he would make
a general Assault; The Goths fearing the same, stood upon the Battlements, to
oppose the Enemy. In the mean time Belisarius brought to the Cistern five
Isaurians, covered under a multitude of Shields, skillful in Masonry, with
Axes, and other Instruments to cut stones, commanding them to break down the
sides of the Cistern. The Goths thinking they came to approach the Walls, kept
quiet; that being nearer they might shoot at them with more advantage, not
imagining the business. But seeing the Isaurians within the Cistern, they
plied them with Arrows, and stones; The rest ran back, and the five Isaurians
being under in safety, fell to work; there being an Arch over the water for
shade, under which they made no account of the Enemies shot, though it came
thick. The Goths opening the Gate there, sallied furiously upon the Isaurians,
and the Romans encountered them, where was a hot fight long, and body to body,
and much slaughter on both sides. The Romans fell thicker, the Goths having the
advantage of the upper ground; but the Romans gave not back, Belisarius being
present, and with loud shouts encouraging them: When from the Enemy came an
Arrow whizzing toward the Generals belly, whether shot by chance, or
purposely: Belisarius seeing it not, could not ward nor shun it; but Vnigatus,
one of his Lifeguard, perceiving the Arrow coming almost to his belly, put his
right hand between, and saved the Generals life; and being himself wounded
with it, and in extremity of pain, he retired: His Sinews were afterward cut
asunder, and he lost the use of his hand. The Fight beginning in the morning
ended at noon, where seven Armenians of the Troops of Narses, and Aratius,
showed great deeds of Valor; running up the steep Hill, and upon the plain
killed all that stood them, until they had routed the Goths in that part. And
the Romans seeing the Enemy give ground, fell to Execution and the Defeat being
clear, the Goths got within their Walls. The Romans thought the Cistern to be
down, and the Isaurians to have dispatched their work; but they could not force
one stone out of it. The ancient Artists, above all, careful of their Credits,
had so wrought this building, that it would not yield to time, nor the attemps
of men; wherefore the Isaurians, seeing the Romans masters of the Field, came
out of the Cistern, and retired to the Camp. Hereupon Belisarius caused the
Soldiers to throw dead bodies of Beasts, and poisonous Herbs into the water,
and to quench burning Lime in it; that the Goths having but one Well within the
Walls, with little water in it, were much scanted. Neither did Belisarius use
any more force or designs against the Town, hoping by Famine only to have his
will of the Enemy; and therefore he attended earnestly to his Guards and
Sentinels. The Goths also in their great wants were quiet, expecting an Army
from Ravenna.

In Faesulae the Beseiged endured fore Famine, and much misery, and having no
hope from Ravenna, they resolved to yield: And coming to a Parley with Cyprian
and Justinus, and taking assurance for their lives, they rendered themselves and
the Castle. Cyprian brought them and the Roman Army before Auximum, leaving a
Garrison in Faesulae. Belisarius showed their Leaders to the Goths in Auximum,
bidding them leave their Opiniativenesse, and hopes from Ravenna, from whence
receiving no good, but being more ruined daily, they will at last come to the
same Fortune with those of Faesulae. They considered of it, and being unable to
hold out longer against the Famine, they embraced the Proposition, and rendered
the City upon conditions of indemnity to themselves, and to go with their Goods
to Ravenna. Belisarius was in some doubt to suffer so many brave men to join
with those in Ravenna; but he would not lose the opportunity of marching
thither against Vitigis, while Affairs was yet in suspense, and the Francks
expected to come with succors to the Goths; whose coming though he would
willingly prevent, yet he would not raise the Seige of Auximum, before it were,
taken. But the Soldiers opposed the Goths having their Goods, showing their
wounds, and recounting their toiles in the Seige, whereof they alleged the
spoils of the Conquered to be the due Prizes. In the end forced by the
pressing opportunity, and the Goths compelled by the Famine, they came to this
accord; That the Romans should have half the Goods, and the Goths with the
other half he subject to the Emperor: And upon this they gave Oath, the Roman
Commanders to observe the Agreement, and the Goths not to conceal any of their
Goods. So they shared the Goods, and the Romans had Auximum, and the Goths were
mingled with the Army.

CHAP. XXIII.
BElisarius having taken Auximum, made have to Ravenna with his whole Army; He
sent Magnus before with competent numbers, to skirt the Bancks of Poe, and
prevent the transporting of Provisions into Ravenna that way. Vitalius, being
come out of Dalmatia with Forces, guarded the other side of the River; a
Fortune here befell, which showed evidently, that she it is who will determine
the controversy. For the Goths had formerly brought down into the Poe many
Barks out of Liguria laded with Corn, bound for Ravenna; but the water was
grown so low then, that they could not row on; till the Romans coming,
surprised the Barks and all the lading. Soon after, the River had the wonted
stream and was Navigable again; which never happened so before, that we could
hear. And now the Goths began to be scarce of Provisions, importing nothing
from the Jonian Gulf (by reason the Enemy was Master of the Sea) and the River
being blockt up.

The Kings of the Francks understanding how things went, and desiring to put
for Italy* sent Ambassadors to Vitigis with offers of aides, so they might
share the Dominion of the Country with him; which Belisarius being advertised
of, sent also Ambassadors to dispute it with the Francks, and among others,
Theodosius the Steward of his house. The Francks Ambassadors were first heard,
and spoke thus: The Kings of the Francks have sent us hither, sorry to hear
that you are distressed by Belisarius, and ready according to their League to
avenge you. There is an Army passed the Alps, of 500000. men, who at their
very first Encounter will over-whelme the Roman Army with their battle Axes.
Hearken not therefore to their Counsel, who would make you Slaves, but to
theirs rather who in their Affection to you embrace the hazards of a War; And
the rather, because joining with us, the Romans cannot hope to match both our
powers, but we shall with ease have the Victory. Whereas if you join with the
Romans, yet shall they not be able to stand against the Francks, (the Battle
even then being not to be with equal powers) and you will be vanquished in the
company of your greatest Foes. To run therefore into so evident mischief,
having means to be preserved without hazard, is extremest folly. The Romans
are not faithful to any Barbarians, but naturally Enemies to them. But we (if
you like it) will share with you the Dominion of Italy, and divide the Country
as we shall both think best. Make choice therefore of what is most expedient
for you. The Francks having done, the Ambassadors of Belisarius spoke thus:
That the Francks multitudes shall not hurt the Emperors Army, as these men
would fright us, what needs a long Speech to you, whose experience has learnt
all the moments of War? and that Valor is not vanquished with multitudes. The
Emperor can more then any, (if he please) exceed his Enemy in numbers. The
faithfulness of these men to all Barbarians, we know, and themselves have
showed it to the Thuringians, Burgundians, and to you their Allies: So that we
would gladly ask, by what God they mean to swear for the pledge of their
Faith. How they have respected him by whom they have already sworn, you know;
who coming as Friends to aid you, did not only not join in the danger, but
impudently took Arms against you; if you remember what they did at the Poe.
What need we, by repeating things past, convince the Francks impiety? Can any
thing be more detestable then this their Embassage? as if they had forgotten
former Treaties; now they pretend their aides to be better then other men's; but
if they obtain the Goths to mingle with their Armies once, what will be the
period or their insatiable desires, were good to consider. Belisarius
Ambassadors having thus spoken, Vitigis after long conference with the
principal Goths, chose an Accord with the Emperor, and dismissed the Francks
with denial.

From hence forward the Romans and Goths sent Ambassadors to each other: But
still Belisarius set Guards to hinder importation of Provisions; and he
employed Vitalius to take in Towns in Venetia, and himself with Ildeger
guarded both sides of the Poe, to draw thus the Goths to yield to him upon his
own terms for want of Victual. Hearing how there was much Corn in the
public Magazines of Ravenna, he won a Citizen with money to set them all on
fire; which loss (some say) happened by Mattasuntha's advise, the Wife of
Vitigis. It was so suddenly done, that some thought it was by lightning, as
others by design, and Vitigis and the Goths taking it in either kind, fell
into more irresolution, neither trusting one another, and thinking God himself
made War against them.

In the Alps also which divide Gaul and Liguria, (called Alps Cottiae) are
many Castles, whereof many principal Goths have the Guard, having long dwelt
there with their wives and children. Belisarius desirous to reduce them, sent
Thomas thither, one of his retinue, with some few, to give Faith, and receive
the Goths upon composition, whom Sisigis commander of all those Garrisons
received into a Castle, and with himself brought in all the rest. In the mean
time Vraeas with 4000 choice men out of Liguria, and those Castles, was
marching to succor Ravenna: These hearing what Sisigis had done, and afraid of
their own Estates, with Vraeas went first to these Cottian Alps, and besieged
Sisigis and Thomas. John Vitalianus hearing of it, and Martinus (being then
about the Poe) came to their succor with their forces, and some of the Castles
they surprised, and made the Inhabitants slaves, and among them many wives and
Children of Vraeas soldiers, who from those Castles had followed him; but
hearing now how their own Estates were ransacked they suddenly ran from the
Goths Camp to John, whereby Vraeas could do nothing there, nor yet relieve
Ravenna, but went into Liguria with some few, and lay still.

CHAP. XXIV.
IN the mean time, Belisarius shut up in Ravenna, Vitigis, and the chief of
the Goths: and the Emperors Ambassadors arrived, Domnicus and Maximinus, both
Senators; with commission to make peace upon Terms, that Vitigis should have
half the Revenues of the Crown, and the Dominion of the country beyond the Poe;
the other half of the Revenues to be the Emperors, and the rest of Italy to be
subject to him, and to pay him Tribute. The Ambassadors showed the Emperors
instructions to Belisarius, and were conducted into Ravenna: And Vitigis and
the Goths gladly agreed to conclude the treaty upon those condition. This
discontented Belisarius, as an ill service to hinder him from the absolute
conquest, and his bringing Vitigis to Constantinople prisoner, having it in his
power: and at the Ambassadors return he refused to sign the Treaty, upon which
the Goths were jealous of the Romans that they fraudulently propounded a peace,
and protested to conclude nothing without the signature and oath of Belisarius.
Who hearing that some Commanders taxed him with a design against the Emperors
service, to prolong the War; he called them all, and in the presence of
Domnicus and Maximinus spoke thus The fortune of the war (I and you know)
stands not upon firm Ground; many in hope of an instant victory have been
overthrown, and an Enemy, in appearance ruined, has beyond imagination
subsisted. So that men consulting of peace, are not to fancy the best for
themselves only, but to consider the event both ways in possibility, and so to
resolve. And I now assemble you my fellow Commanders, and the Emperors
Ambassadors, that choosing with all freedom what you think most expedient for
the Emperor, you may not after the business done, lay imputations upon me; it
being most unreasonable, when you may choose the best, to be silent, and when
you see the Event, then to coin accusations. The Emperors resolution, and
Vitigis mind for concluding the war, you know; which if you conceive to be
expedient, say so; but if you think your selves able to recover Italy, and to
subdue the Enemy, there is no danger, boldly to say it. Belisarius having
spoken, they all said plainly that the Emperors instructions were best, and
that they were not able to do more then they had done. The opinion pleased
Belisarius, and he bade them express it in a writing, that they might not deny
it afterward; which they signed accordingly; that they were not able to subdue
the Enemy by war. But the Goths the while pressed with Famine, could hold out no
longer; weary they were of Vitigis government, and yet scrupulous to yield to
the Emperor; fearing to be removed by him out of Italy to Constantinople, and
planted thereabout. So that the principal men upon debate resolved to declare
Belisarius Emperor of the West, and secretly they sent to entreat him to
accept the Empire, professing to be most willing to obey him. Belisarius would
not take the Empire without the Emperors consent; to whom he was tied in a
solemn oath, not to innovat during the said Emperors life; and the very name
of an Usurper he hated: yet to facilitate his business, he seemed to accept
the offer. Vitigis perceiving it, out of fear, commended the Goths resolution,
