and secretly animated Belisarius, that there should be no rub in his way to the
Empire. Belisarius hereupon called the Commanders with the Ambassadors, and
asked them, if they thought it not a matter of importance, to make all the
Goths, and Vitigis the Emperors Captives; to share their wealth, and to
recover all Italy to the Romans: They said, it would be an extreme high
fortune, and prayed him to effect it if he could. Presently Belisarius sent
some of his favorites to Vitigis, and the chief Goths, willing them to perform
their offer immediately. Indeed the Famine would not permit a put-off, but
brought them to it; that again they sent Ambassadors with the former
propositions openly, but privately to take Belisarius oath for their indemnity,
and that he would be King of Italy; and that done, to return into Ravenna with
the Roman army. Concerning the rest Belisarius gave oath; but touching the
Kingdom, he said he would swear it to Vitigis and the Goths Commanders. The
Ambassadors not thinking he would reject the Kingdom, but that he desired it
above all things, prayed him forthwith to march into Ravenna. Belisarius sent
away Narses, Aratius, Bessas and John, (whom he suspected to be worst affected
to him) to quarter with their Troops in several countries, telling them he
could not possibly bring into that city provisions for the whole army. They
with Athanasius, Prefect of the Palace, lately come from Constantinople, went
accordingly; and himself and the rest of the army entered Ravenna, with the
Goths Ambassadors. He commanded also ships he had laded with Corn, to come into
Esclae the haven for Ravenaa. When I saw the entrance of this army into
Ravenna, I considered how actions are not concluded by valor, multitudes, or
human virtue; but that some spirit steers the wits and judgments of men
thither, where nothing can hinder the pre-ordained conclusion. The Goths had
much the advantage in numbers and power, and since they came to Ravenna had no
battle, nor their courages dejected with any accident, yet they became
prisoners, and thought it no shame to be slaves to fewer in number. The women
(who had heard from their Husbands, that the Enemy were tall gallant men, and
not to be numbered, scorned the Soldiers when they saw them in the City, and
reviled their husbands cowardice, pointing at their conquerours.

CHAP. XXV.
BUT Belisarius kept Vitigis in an honorable restraint, and sent away such
Goths as inhabited this side the Poe, to their own houses, to possess them
freely; fearing from thence no hostility, nor that the Goths would gather head
in those parts, because much of the Army was there Garrisoned. And these Goths
were glad to go home, whereby the Romans in Ravenna were secure, having equal
numbers. The Treasures in the Palace he seized, with intent to carry them to
the Emperor; But neither himself plundered any Goth, nor suffered others;
leaving them their Estates according to the Accord. The Captains of
Fortresses, hearing Ravenna and Vitigis to be in the Romans hands, sent to
Belisarius offers of surrendering the same upon Composition. He gave them
assurances, and received Tarvisium, and another strong Hold: Cesina and Emilia
he had taken in before with Ravenna; and the Goths Garrisoned in those places,
upon assurances given, came into Beli^arius, and staid with him. ^^debad also,
Governor of Verona, having his Children Prisoners in Ravenna, sent to
Belisarius to the same purpose; but he would not put himself into his hands
there. In the mean time some Commanders had traduced Belisarius to the Emperor
falsely with usurpation; Who not beleiving the accusation, but the Persian war
pressing him, sent for Belisarius to make an Expedition that way. Belisarius
left the charge of Italy with Bessas and John, and some others; and he directed
Constantianus to come to Ravenna from Dalmatia. But the Goths inhabiting beyond
the Poe, hearing how Belisarius was called home, at first made no account of
it, not thinking that he would less esteem a Kingdom then his faith to
Justinian: But afterward seeing his preparations to be gone, their chief men
continuing in those parts, went into Picenia to Vraeas, sisters Son to
Vitigis, and after much lamenting, spoke thus. There is none a greater cause of
these miseries of our Nation, then your self. We had long since deposed your
uncle, so cowardly and unfortunate a Prince, as formerly we did Theodatus the
sisters Son of Theoderick, if we had not (respecting your valor) given him the
Title, but in Effect put the Kingdom into your hands. But now our then seeming
good counsel, appears our folly, and the cause of these Calamities. The best
Goths are consumed by the war, and the best of the remainder Belisarius is
carrying, away with all our Treasures; and no man doubts, but we shortly being
few, and enemies, shall suffer the same. In this extremity a glorious death is
better, then to behold our wives and children led Captives to the uttermost
bounds of the earth; and might we have you in the head of us, we may yet do
something worthy the name of valor. Vraeas made this answer* I am of your
opinion to choose danger before slavery; but to make me King I hold it in no
fort convenient. For being the Nephew of Vitigis, a man so unlucky, the Enemy
may despise me, supposing Fortunes ever to run in a blood. Besides I shall seem
dishonest to intrude upon my Uncle, and thereby have many malcontents. My
Sentence is, to make Ildebad King in this danger, a man accomplished in Virtue,
and very valiant, whole Uncle Theudis, King of the Visigoths, in likelihood
will enter into this War for his sake, whereby we may dispute it with more
hope. This advise of Vraeas seemed best; and forthwith Ildebad was sent for
from Verona, whom they invested with the purple Robe, and proclaimed King,
recommending unto him their Affairs Ildebad being thus made King, assembled
the Goths, and spoke thus: Fellow Soldiers, we have had experience of many
Wars, and in likelihood shall not run rashly now into this; Experience brings
Wit; and wit is never Foole-hardy. It is fit now to consult of our present
Estate, by calling to mind the former Accidents. Men by an affected
forgetfulness of things past, and so by foolishly keeping high thoughts, have
been ruined in their greatest occasions. Vitigis, without your opposing him,
has put himself into the Enemies hands; you being tired with cross Fortunes,
and choosing rather (quietly sitting at home) to obey Belisarius, then to
hazard. But he being going to Constantinople, now you resolve to stir; whereas
you should consider, that men speed not always in the way they expect, that
often the Event beyond Imagination is contrary to the appearance; Fortune and
Repentance commonly doing best, unlookt for, which is not unlikely, may be now
the case of Belisarius. Wherefore our best way is, to send first to know his
mind, and to persuade him to what was lately accorded, and so to enter into
action. This counsel of Ildebad they all conceived to be best, and immediately
sent Ambassadors to Ravenna; who put Belisarius in mind of his Agreement,
blamed his infringing the same, and reproached him for not blushing to be thus
a Voluntary Slave, and to prefer Servitude before a Kingdom. Many such
Provocations they used, and animated him to accept the Government, assuring him
that Ildebad would willingly give place, lay at his feet the Purple Robe, and
salute him, Belisarius, King of the Goths and Italians. The Ambassadors spoke
thus, thinking that Belisarius would not be so scrupulous, as to reject the
Title of a King. But he, contrary to their expectations, plainly refused it,
saying; that during the Emperor Justinians life, he would not intrude upon
such a Title. They hearing this, instantly departed, and reported it to
Ildebad. And Belisarius took his Journey toward Constantinople, the Winter
ending, and the fifth year of this War, written by Procopius.

Finis lib. 2. Bell. Goth.
THE CONTENTS OF THE THIRD BOOK Of the GOTHJCK War.
Chap. I. AN Elogium of Belisarius. The ill carriage of the other Commanders in
Italy. Ildebad is chosen King, and the Goths recover. The Roman Soldiers and
Subjects are discontented with Alexander Psalidion the Auditor. Ildebad kills
Uraeas, and is slain himself by Vilas, one of his Guard. Chap. II. Erarick, a
Rogian, is chosen King. The Romans have II. Commanders under Constantianus, and
Alexander Psalidion; They basely run away from Verona, and are routed by the
Poe, through the want of Artabazes, who was hurt in a Duel. Chap. III.
Florence attempted, and mist by Totilas, elected King of the Goths. The Roman
Army makes head, and is routed. Naples besieged by Totilas, who is Master of
Italy. Demetrius, sent from Constantinople, is routed in a Sea Fight, taken
Prisoner, and the Navy ruined by storm. Chap. IV. Totiles takes Naples by
composition: His humanity to the Citizens and Soldiers. His noble punishment
of a Rape. The baseness of the Roman Army. Totilas invites the Roman Senators
to revolt. Chap. V. Belisarius is sent into Italy. Otranto is besieged, and
relieved by Valentinus. Tibur is surprised by the Goths. Belisarius come to
Ravenna. The Illyrians go home. Forces are sent to relieve Auximum. Chap. VI.
Some Romans are slain by an Ambush. Pisaurus is repaired. Belisarius writes to
the Emperor for supplies. The Goths take Spoletum, and Assisium by
composition, besiege Rome, and block it up by Sea and Land. Belisarius
unfortunate, or infatuated, returns to Epidamnus. The Emperor sends him an
Army with John. Narses the Eunuch levies an Army of Herulians; who by chance do
great service against the Slavonians. Chap. VII. A digression of a counterfeit
Chilbudius, a Romam General upon the River Iste^. A description of the
Slavonians, and Antians; inhabiting the further side of the River Ister. Chap.
VIII. Valentinus and Phocas are slain before Rome, by the baseness of Bessas.
Ships of Corn sent by Vigilius, Bishop of Rome, for Rome, are surprised by the
Enemy. Pelagius, a Deacon, is sent Ambassador to supplicate Totilas, but
prevails not. Chap. IX. The miserable Famine in Rome. John recovers Calabria,
Bruttia, and Lucania. He defeats an Army of Goths about Rhegium. Totilas builds
Towers, and a Bridge upon Tiber. Chap. X. Belisarius burns one of the Towers
with a Fire-boat; being ready to relieve Rome, is diverted, by a report of
Isaac's taking, whose madness, and the baseness of Bessas spoiled the Action.
Four Isaurians offer to receive in Totilas, Bessas negligently guarding it.
Chap. XI. Totilas takes Rome by the Treason of the four Isaurians. He spares
slaughter, at the supplication of Pelagius: Whom he sends Ambassador to
Justinian for Peace; and in the mean time spares the demolishing of Rome. A
small defeat of Goths by Tullianus. Chap. XII. Totilas is diverted from
destroying Rome, by the advises of Belisarius, and left it without any man in
it. Martianus by a plot recovers Spoletum. John fortifies an Isthmus at
Tarentum, and makes head. Totilas goes toward Ravenna. Chap. XIII. Belisarius
repaires Rome, and defends it against Totilas; and after some time, beats him
away. The speech of Totilas to the Goths in his own Apology. Chap. XIV. John
rescues the Senators and their Wives, confined in Campania, is beaten out of
his Camp by Totilas, with loss of 100. men. The Emperor sends new Forces into
Italy, Scyllaeum, The bay of Tarentum, Thurium, and Croton. Chap. XV. The
Forces sent by Belisarius to guard the passages are cut in pieces by Totilas,
where Pharas is slain. Belisarius frighted with the news, runs a Shipboard.
The Slavonians overrun Illyrium. Inundation of Nile; The great Whale. Russiana
is taken by Totilas. Conon is killed by his Soldiers. Chap. XVI. Belisarius
dares not relieve Russiana: and the Garrison yields it to Totilas upon their
lives saved. A plot against the person of Justinian, by Artabanes, and others.
Chap. XVII. Artabanes, and Arsaces endeavor to bring in Germanus, and his son
Justinus into the plot against the Emperor. Marcellus, by deferring the
discovery, hazards Germanus, and after by telling the whole truth, saves him.
The Kings of the Francks coin gold Staters, a thing not done by the King of
Persia himself. No gold pieces will go, no not among Barbarian Merchants, but
of the Emperors coin. Chap. XVIII. The Gepaedes and Lombards spoil the
Empire: Fall at difference: Demand aid of the Emperor by both their
Ambassadors. The Lombards arguments have more justice in them. But the Gepaedes
more reason of State. Chap. XIX. The Gepaedes and Lombards make Peace without
the Romans. Belisarius returns to Constantinople without honor. of Ildeges a
Lombard, who was coming to aid Totilas, but returned. Ilauf, a revolter, does
mischief in Dalmatia; and sackes Monecurum, and Laureata. Totilas besieges
Rome, which is bravely defended by Diogenes. Chap. XX. Totitas takes Rome
again by another Isaurian Treason; but demolishes it not, upon an occasion of
being formerly refused alliance with the French King, because he durst not hold
Rome, but demolish it. Paul, a Cilician, makes a gallant composition. Justinian
refuses to see the Goths Ambassadors for Peace. Centumcellae agreed to be
yielded, if succors came not. Germanus, then Liberius, appointed General for
Italy. Verus is slain. Chap. XXI. The Slavonians spoil Thrace, and Illyrium,
beat the Emperors Army, and commit savage murders. Rhegium yielded to the
Goths. Messina besieged. After Liberius, and Artabanes, Germanus is made
General against the Goths; who makes a powerful preparation, frights away the
Slavonians out of Illyrium, and dies at Sardice in Illyrium. John is appointed
to lead the Army. Chap. XXII. Artabanes escapes a storm at Sea. Liberius quits
Syracuse. Totilas is persuaded by Spinus to leave Sicily. The Slavonians do
much spoil; rout a Roman Army, and come up even to the Long walls in Thrace, a
days journey from Constantinople. They are beaten home.
THE HISTORY OF THE WARS of the Emperor JUSTINIAN.
Of the GOTHJCK War, the Third BOOK.
CHAP. I.
THUS Belisarius, leaving Italy yet unsettled, brought Vitigis and Ildebads
children to Constantinople, with all the rich spoils; accompanied only with
Ildiger, Valerianus, Martinus, and Herodian. Justinian was glad to see Vitigis
and his Queen, admiting the Goths for their beautiful tall bodies. Theodericks
treasures (a goodly sight to behold) he took into the Palace, and in private
exposed them to the view of the Senate, glorying much in the greatness of the
things done. He showed not the same to the People, nor allowed Belisarius a
triumph, as after his conquest of Gelimer and the Vandals. Yet was Belisarius
the discourse of all the world, having gained the honor of two unmatchable
victories, brought two Kings Prisoners to Constantinople; and beyond all
expectation, made spoils of War the race and wealth of Gensericke, and
Theoderick, the most illustrious of all the Barbarians. He brought back also
to the Roman State their own wealth from the hands of their Enemies, and in a
short time recovered the Dominion of almost one half of the Land and Seas
thereof. It was a delight to the Constantinopolitans (and they could not be
satisfied with it) to behold daily Belisarius passing from his house, and
returning thither through the Marketplace; His going in the streets being a
kind of triumph; multitudes of Vandales, Goths, and Moors ever following him:
and he was a beautiful personage, tall, and of the goodliest countenance that
could be seen; To suitors ever easy of access, and mild as the meanest man.
Both the Soldier, and the Countryman were ever infinitely in love with his
Government, being to the Soldiers exceeding bountiful; to such as had
mischances in fight, comforting their wounds with large sums, and to such as
did bravely, giving chains and bracelets for prizes of honor. If a Soldier
in fight, lost his horse, or his Bow, or the like, presently he had another
from Belisarius. And he was dear to the Country people, because he used such
good husbandry and providence, that where he was General, none ever suffered
violence, but all where his Army came had the strange fortune to grow richer;
selling their commodities to the Soldier at their own rates, who guarded
still their ripe Corns, to keep off Horse from spoiling them; Neither was any
suffered to take away their ripe fruits. Besides he had a wonderful care of
his chastity, never touching any woman but his Wife; and of so many fair
Prisoners of the Vandales and the Goths (such as none ever saw the like)
suffering not one to be brought into his sight, nor to come at him. He was of a
very sharp wit, and excellent in a doubtful case to devise the best way;
valiant in War with cautiousnesse, and bold upon advise of reason; ever either
swift or flow in his undertakings upon an Enemy, according to occasion. In
extreamities resolute, full of hope, and free from perturbation. In prosperity
he was neither exalted, nor voluptuous: No man ever saw Belisarius drunck. And
thus during his command in Afric and Italy, he was still victorious, and
Master of all in his way: And when he came home to Constantinople, his worth
was yet more taken notice of; For being himself eminent in virtue, and
exceeding all the Generals that ever were in wealth, and in the strength of
his Lanciers, and Targettiers, he was terrible both to Commanders and common
Soldiers. So that no man durst oppose his commands, but readily put in
execution what he directed; both reverencing his worth, and fearing his power.
For he had ready of the Retinew of his House 7000. Horsemen, choice men, and
every one of them thinking himself fit to stand in the first rank at a
Battle, and to challenge the bravest of the Enemies. The ancient men of Rome
at that siege seeing what those men did in the fights then, and taking if for a
great wonder, said, That one man's Family ruined the power of Theoderick. Thus
was Belisarius grown powerful both in dignity and counsel, ever advising the
Emperors best advantage, and cheerfully executing what was resolved.

But the other Commanders (being equal in power, and having no thought but
upon their own private gain) made spoil of the Roman Subjects, and exposed
them to the injuries of the Soldier. They apprehended nothing worthy
themselves, nor had the Common soldiers obedient to their commands; and so
commiting many errors, the Romans affairs were in a short time ruined; and
thus it was.

Ildebad hearing that Belisarius was gone from Ravenna, and upon his journey,
recollected the Goths, and such Roman Soldiers as would revolt; was careful
of the Government, and diligent to recover the Dominion of Italy. At first he
had with him but a thousand men, and no Town but Picenum. But in a while all
who were in Liguria, and Venetia, came dropping in to him.

There was in Constantinople one Alexander, chief Auditor of the public
Treasury, called Logothetes by the Romans, from the Greek. This man's practice
was to inform against Soldiers for wronging the Treasury; and for such
misdemeanors by bringing them to justice, he became of an obscure man eminent,
and of a Beggar very rich. He raised as much money for the Emperor as any man;
but was the greatest cause that the Soldiers were few and poor, and backward in
dangers. At Constantinople they gave him a nickname, Psalidion, for the
dexterity he had to clip away the ring of the gold coin; and though he made it
less, yet to have it keep the circular form it had at the first. The
instrument wherewith this is done, is called Psalidion, or clipping sheers.
This man the Emperor sent into Italy, when he recalled ^elisarius; And he in
Ravenna set a foot Audits without reason, calling the Italians to account, who
never touched the Emperor moneys, and some that never had public employment,
and charging them with wrong done to Theodorick, and the other Gothish Kings,
and compelling them to repay what they had robbed, or fraududulently gained, as
he alleged. The Soldiers for their wounds and bazards he requited with
slender accounts; whereby the Italians grew ill affected to the Emperor, and
the Soldiers would not engage themselves into dangers; but turning wilful
cowards, advanced the Enemies affairs to a great height.

All the Commanders sat still, but Vitalius, who had with him in Venetia many
Herulians, and some other numbers of the Army; he would fight with Ildebad,
fearing (what afterward came to pass) that his growing power might not so
easily be restrained. The Battle was valiantly fought near the City of
Tarvisium; but Vitalius had the worst; and suffering the loss of most of his
men, with a few escaped by flight. Many Herulians fell, and Visandus their
Leader. Theudimund, the Son of Mauricius, the Son of Mundus, a young man, was
in much danger of being lost, but escaped with Vitalius. This Battle made
Ildebad famous with the Emperor, and all men; But afterward Vraeas fell foul
with him, upon this occasion. Vraas had a Wife, for Wealth and Beauty, the
chief of her Nation. She went once to the public Bath bravely dressed, and with
a goodly Train; where seeing Ildehads Wife in a mean Habit, she bowed not to
her, as to the Kings Consort, but slighted, and scoffed at her; for as yet her
Husband was in a low Condition, as having not been Master of any Kingly
Revenue. But the Queen vexed with this gross Affront, came weeping to her
Husband, desiring him to right her, having suffered from Vraeas Wife things not
to be endured. Whereupon Ildebad first accused Vraeas to the Goths, of
purposing a Revolt; and afterward killed him treacherously, and was hated for
it by the Goths, who liked not this killing of Vraas without Examination; and
they gathered together, and railed upon Ildebad for this foul Act; yet none of
them were willing he should suffer for it. One among them, named Vilas, by race
a Gepaede, and a Lancier of the Guard to the Emperor, was a Suitor to a very
fair Woman, and infinitely doted upon his love. But being sent upon some
Service, Ildebad the mean while gave his Mistress to another in marriage;
either ignorantly, or upon some motive: Which Vilas hearing at his coming from
the Army, and being naturally impatient, could not bear the disgrace, but
resolved to kill Ildebad; wherein he thought too to gratify all the Goths. He
observed his time as the King feasted the chief men, when many use to stand by
him, especially his Guards. The King reaching his hand to a dish, and bowing
with his face upon the Couch, Vilas suddenly struck him with his Sword upon the
neck, that the meat being between his fingers, the head fell off, and amassed
all the Company. Thus was the Murder of Vraeas revenged upon Ildebad; and the
Winter ended, and the sixth Incipit Annus 7. Bell. Goth, in anno 15. Justiniani.
year of this War, written by Procopius.

CHAP. II.
AMong the Goths was one Erarick, a Rogian by Nation, but he had gained a great
power with the Goths. The Rogians are a Gothish Nation, formerly a free People;
but Theoderick made them and some other Nations his Confederates, and mingled
them all together, and used them jointly against the Enemy. But these taking no
Wives of any other Nation, preserved their Name in a Posterity of the whole
blood. And the State being in trouble upon the Murder of Ildebad, they
proclaimed Erarick King, which the Goths misliked, whose hearts were now quite
down, and their hopes frustrated. For Ildebad was a man able enough to have
recovered the Dominion of Italy; but Erarick did nothing to purpose; and having
reigned five Months, he was slain in this manner. Totilas, Nephew to Ildebad,
(a wise and a Valourous man, and in much Estimation with the Goths) commanded
then the Goths in Tarvis^um; and hearing how Ildebad was slain, sent to Ravenna
to Constantianus, offering upon assurances of indemnity to deliver up
Tarvisium, and the Goths under his Command. Constantianus most gladly gave
Oath; as Totilas desired, and a day was appointed for receiving into the Town
men sent by Constantianus, and to put the Gothish Garrison into their hands.
All the Goths were weary of Eraricks Government, finding him not capable to
make a War with the Romans; and they railed on him as a hinderer of many good
Designs they were ready to act, when they killed Ildebad. In conclusion, by
common consent they sent to Tarvisium, exhorting Totilus to the Government.
They felt the miss of Ildebad, and turned their hope of Victory upon Totilus,
his Kinsman, hoping therein what they desired. He told them plainly his accord
with the Romans, and that if they shall kill Erarick before his day of
Assignment with the Romans, he will follow them, and do as they desire him. The
Goths upon this resolved the ruin of Erarick. In the mean time, the Roman Army
secure, and enjoying their Enemies troubles, neither drew together, nor had any
design upon them. But Erarick assembling the Goths propounded the sending
Ambassadors to Justinian, for such a peace as was once resolved to be made
with Vitigis: namely, that the Goths holding all beyond the Poe, should quit
the rest of Italy. The Goths all approved the Motion; and he sent Caballarius,
and some other of his Friends Ambassadors, who were to pretend the
negotiation, as aforesaid; but he gave them secret Instructions, to treat only
with the Emperor, to give him a good Sum of money, and to make him a
Patritian, upon condition of his delivering up all Italy, and his laying down
the Royal Habit. The Ambassadors coming to Constantinople, did according to
his directions. In the mean time the Goths kill Erarick by treachery, and
Totilas takes the Government, as was agreed. Justinian advertised hereof, both
of the accident of Erarick, and that Totilas was made King, he could no longer
contain from sharply reproving the Commanders: whereupon John, Vitalianus
Sisters Son, Bessas, Vitalius, and the rest, leaving Garrisons in the Towns,
drew together at Ravenna, where were Constantianus, and Alexander. They
resolved in Counsel to lead the Army first against Verona, which is in
Venetia, and having taken the same, to go against Totilas and Picenum. The Army
was gotten together 12000. men, under eleven Commanders; and Constantianus and
Alexander in chief. Being come within seven miles of Verona, they encamped
before it; the City being compassed with fair Champians, reaching as far as
Mantua, which is a days journey from Verona. In Venetia one Marcianus, a
principal man, dwelling in a Castle not far from Verona, and well affected to
the Emperor, sought means of delivering the City to the Romans. He was
acquainted with one of the Watchmen, to whom he sent a Friend, and persuaded
him for money to receive in the Emperors Army. The Watchman promised, and
Marcianus sent some to the Roman Commanders to negotiate, and to let them know
the Agreement, and to enter the Town by night with them. The Commanders thought
it best to send one of themselves before with a few; if the Watchman open^d
the Gate, to make it good, and then the rest to bring the Army in without
hazarding. All refusing the danger, Artabazes an Armenian cheerfully undertook
it; a very gallant Soldier, who was Captain of those Persians, whom Belisarius
brought to Constantinople with Blischames, after his taking the Castle of
Sisaurium. He settled a 100. men of the Army, and late in the night got near to
the Town. The Watchman opened the Gate; some stood still and sent for the
Army, others mounted the Walls and slew the Sentinels, coming unexpected: And
the Goths perceiving the mischief, ran out at another Gate, and retired to a
high Hill over against Verona (from whence one may discern all done in the
City, and number the men in the Streets, and it has a large Prospect into the
Champian) and here they stayed all night. The Romans being within five miles of
the City, would go no further; the Generals disputing about the Booty of it;
and while they were thus brabling for the spoils, the day grew bright. The
Goths from the Hill discovering the Enemy in the Town, and how great a way the
Army was from it, ran in at the same Gate they ran out; the Romans within being
not able to possess it: who advising together fled to the Battlements, where
the Goths in multitudes assailed, and they stoutly defended, and did wonders;
especially Artabazes. The Roman Commanders, when they had disposed the Wealth
of Verona among themselves, marched against the Town with the Army. But finding
the Gates shut, and the Enemy strongly opposing, they forthwith ran away,
though they saw their Companions upon the Walls fighting, and calling to them
to stay for them. So that Artabazes, and the rest being oppressed with
multitudes, and despairing of Succor, leapt from the Walls; and himself, with
such as lighted upon smooth ground, came safe to the Camp, but they that fell
upon stony ground, perished all. The Roman Army past the Poe, and came to
Faventia, which is a City of Emilia, standing 15. miles from it. Totilas when
he heard what had happened at Verona, sent for most of that Garrison, and with
his whole Army being 50000. he marched against the Enemy. The Roman Commanders
hereof advertised, held a Counsel; where Artabazes spoke thus.

Fellow Commanders, let us not despise the Enemy, as inferior in numbers; nor
as being to fight with men cowed by Belisarius, go on with resolution. False
conceits have deceived and undone many, and their unseasonable despising an
Enemy dissolved their Forces. The former ill success of these men invites them
to some better Fortune; Fortune by making men desperate, brings them to an
excess of daring. I speak not this by gues^e, I have learnt their Courage by
mine own late danger. And let none be offended with me for extolling their
power, having been with a few with me beaten by them. Men's Valor is seen as
well when they are more, as when they are fewer then those they fight with. My
Opinion therefore is, to guard the passage of the River, and when the Goths are
half past over, to fight with them rather, then now with their whole body. And
let no man think that there is no honor in such a Victory. Honor and disgrace
receive their names from the Event. Men commend the Victors, not searching into
the manner of the Victory. Artabazes so spoke; But the Commanders contradicting
one another, did nothing they should do, but there staid, and did nothing. The
Goths came near, and being ready to pass the River, Totilas spoke thus unto
them. Friends and Countrymen; other Battles begin upon the show of equality
in the Armies to fight, but we now stand to fight, having a Fortune most
unequal. If they be beaten, they have means to fight with us again, having
numbers of Soldiers in their Garrisons, all Italy over, and expecting
forthwith the seconds of another Army from Constantinople. But if the same
befall us, the hopes and name of our Nation is lost; being already from 200000.
reduced to 50000. yet is it sit that you be put in mind, that when you took
Arms with Ildebad against the Emperor, you had but 1000. men together, and no
place left but the Town of Picenum. But no sooner were you Conquerours, but
your Armies and Towns augmented: And if you now do bravely, I hope (the War
proceeding probably) we shall vanquish the Enemy. It is the Fortune of
Conquerours ever to grow in numbers, and power. So that resolve to meet the
Enemy cheerfully, and stoutly; knowing, that if you get not the honor of this
day, you can never possibly fight again. Moreover our Enemies Injustice is to
embolden us in this Battle. The Italians subject to them they have so oppressed,
that they need no other punishment for their Treason against the Goths: So (in
a word) have they found all manner of mischiefs from their new Guests. Now
what is more easily caught then an Enemy, who stands not sound with God? Their
fear of us also may encourage us; we going against no other men then those,
who being in the midst of Verona, quitted it without reason, and ran away
shamefully, none pursuing them. Totilas having used this encouragement,
commanded 300. men to pass the River two miles and a half off, and to get
behind the Enemy; and (the Fight being begun) to shoot at their backs, and
being in confusion to gall them. Himself with the rest past there the River,
and went against the Enemy. The Romans encountered them, and both marching fair
and softly, and being near each other, Valiaris, a Goth, tall, and of a stern
Countenance, and very Valiant, rode out from the rest between the Armies, armed
with Corslet and Helmet, and challenged any Roman to fight with him. Artabazes
accepted the Combat. Both rode against each other, and charged their Lances;
Artabazes preventing, ran Valiaris into the left side, who having his mortal
wound, and sincking backward, his Lance resting upon the ground and at a great
stone, kept him from falling: Artabazes with eagerness thrust his Lance into
his belly, not thinking he had his deaths wound already; and the head of
Valiaris Lance standing upright, lighted upon the Corslet of Artabazes, and
gliding over it, peirced his neck, and cut one of the Arteries: He bled
instantly in abundance, but feeling no pain, gallopt to the Roman Camp, and
left Valiaris dead upon the place. The blood could not be stancht, so that the
third day he dyed, and staggered all the hopes of the Romans; for his being not
able to fight in that Battle, was an extreme ruin to them. He attending the
cure of his Wound without Arrow-shot, the Armies joined Battle; in the heat
whereof the 300. Goths at the Romans backs suddenly appeared; the Romans
thinking them to be great numbers, were afraid, and ran away in confusion,
with the Enemy at their heels; who took many Prisoners, and all their Ensigns,
a thing never before happened to the Romans. The Commanders with some few ran
into several Towns for safety, and guarded the same.

CHAP. III.
TOtilas forthwith sent forces against Florence, commanded by Bledas,
Rodericus, and Valiaris, who sat down before it. Justinus within it having
laid in no provisions, sent to Ravenna, praying the Commanders to come to his
succor. The messenger by night slipped by the Enemy, and reported their Estate
to the Roman Commanders in Ravenna, whereupon an army of good importance under
Bessas, Cyprianus and John, Vitalianus his Sisters Son, marched to Florence. The
news of them raised the Goths siege, who retired to Micale, a Town standing a
days journey from Florence. The Roman army left with Justinus some few men,
and went against the Enemy: Upon the way they advised to make choice of one of
the Commanders of most account, suddenly to set upon the Enemy, and the rest to
march after fair and softly; they cast lots, and fortune gave it to John; but
the commanders would not stand to the agreement, so that John with his own
troops only went against the enemy. The Goths understanding their coming, left
the champian, and in fear and tumult ran up to a high hill: John's Troops ran up
also, and began the fight. The Goths valiantly opposed, and many brave men fell
on both sides. Then John furiously giving upon the Enemy with a great shout,
one of his life guard was slain by a dart, whereupon the Romans retired, beaten
back: Then came up the rest of the Roman army, and in the plain put themselves
in batallion, and made an halte: if they had set upon the flying Troops of
John, and with them set upon the Enemy, they had gotten the day, and had them
almost all at their mercy; but an unlucky rumor was spread that John was slain
in the fight by one of his own Lifeguard, so that they would stay no longer,
but made a shameful retreat, not retiring in a whole body, nor yet in Troops;
but every man ran away as he could. Many of them perished, and they who escaped
ran on for many days, none pursuing them, and at last every man as he could
got into strong places, reporting to all they met, that John was slain: From
thence forward they joined not, nor had thought of making head; but every one
kept within his walls, expecting a siege. Totilas gained his prisoners with his
much humanity to serve him willingly against the Romans, and then ended the
winter, and the seventh year of this war, written by Procopius.

Totilas then took in the Castles of Cesina and Petra, Incipit An. 8. bell. Goth
6. Justiniani, Anno domini 542.
came into Tuscany; and the Towns there not yiedling to him, he past the Tiber,
but would not touch upon the Territories of Rome, but went into Campania and
Samnium, and took without labor the strong Town of Beneventum, and laid the
walls flat with the Ground, that the Romans coming from Constantinople might
not from a fortified place infest the Goths. Naples refusing to receive him,
notwithstanding his fair words (having Conon within, with a thousand Romans and
Isaurians) he encamped before it with the most part of his army, and sent out
some forces, who took in Cuma and other fortresses, from whence he raised great
sums of money. The wives of some Senators he found in the fame, who had no
incivility used to them, but were dismissed with much courtesy: from whence he
got a great fame of the Romans of discretion and humanity. He still sent out
small parties (no Enemy appearing against him) and did things of good
importance, taking Bruttia, and Lucania, Apulia, and Calabria, He took up the
Tributes, and from the land-holders received the rents; disposing all things as
absolute Master of Italy. The Roman army hereby received no entertainments, and
the Emperor owed it huge sums; and the Italians mourned, being reduced to so
great danger, The Soldiers also grew more disobedient to their Commanders, and
were glad to lie still in their Garrisons. Constantianus held Ravenna, John
Rome, Ressas Spoletum, Justinus Florence, and Cyprianus Perusia; every one the
place he had fled to. The Emperor hereof advertised, and esteeming it a great
calamity, Praefectus praetorio per Italiam.
forthwith made Maximinus * Prefect of the Palace for Italy, that he might be
over the Commanders, and to furnish provisions to the Soldiers. With him he
sent a navy, having aboard an army consisting of Thracians under Herodian, and
of Armenians under Phazas an Iberian, sisters Son of Peranius, and some few
Huns they had with them. Maximinus from Constantinople, with his Fleet came
upon the coast of Epirus, where he spent the time to no purpose, being no
Soldier, a coward; and an extreme delayer. Afterward the Emperor sent
Demetrius General; who had formerly commanded a company of Foot under
Belisarius: He arriving in Sicily, and hearing how Conon was besieged in Naples
and in great want of victual, had a mind to succor him speedily; but with so
small an army being not able, be freighted a number of ships, (which he got
together from all parts of. Sicily) with corn and other provisions, making the
Enemy believe that he had a great army abroad, who indeed hearing of a huge
navy coming from Sicily, expected a great army with it. If Demetrius had made
directly for Naples, he had frighted away the Enemy and saved the city. But he
was afraid to put in there, and sailed on to the port of Rome, employing
himself there to gather together the Soldiers; Who being already beaten by the
Goths, and extremely afraid of them, refused to follow him against Totilas. So
that with those only he brought from Constantinople, he went toward Naples.
Another Demetrius, a Cephalenian, an ancient mariner very skillful, when he
sailed with Belisarius into Africa and Italy, grew famous for his skill, and
the Emperor made him Procurator of Naples. In the beginning of the Goths seige
there, being a man of a foul intemperate tongue, he used many disgraceful
words against Totilas. the Famine there growing, and the mortality still
increasing, with Conons consent he adventured in a small bark alone to go
secretly to Demetrius, and hardly escaping, he met with Demetrius, and
encouraging him, drew him to undertake the business. Totilas hearing of the
Fleet coming back, prepared many Pinnaces swift of sail, and the enemy being
upon the coast near Naples, he set on them suddenly, amazed them, and put them
to flight; killing many and taking more: They only escaped, who at first leapt
into the cock-boats, among whom was Demetrius the General. The ships the
Goths took with all their men and Lading, and there sound Demetrius the
Procurator of Naples, whose Tongue they cut out, and so let him go whether he
would; such was the punishment of Demetrius for his intemperate language.
Afterward came Maximinus with his Fleet upon the coast of Sicily, where he sat
still in Syracuse, afraid of the war. The Roman commanders, and especially
Conon from Naples (whom all provisions now failed) sent to him to come to their
succors: He wore out the season in this cowardly fear; but at last fearing the
Emperors menaces, and wearied with the revilings of all men, he stayed
himself; but sent the army to Naples under Demetrius, Herodian, and Phazas in
the sharpest of the winter. The Fleet being near to Naples a storm took them,
so great, that Demetrius and the two other yielded to the Sea. The Waves would
not suffer the sea men to use their Oars, nor do any other work, neither
could they hear one another call for the Tempest. Confusion had the victory,
and the storm was the absolute judge, bringing them against their wills to the
shore, where the Enemy was encamped; who clining up into their vessels,
killed men and sunk ships none resisting; many prisoners they took, and the
General himself, Demetrius. Heredian and Phazas, with some few putting in
further from the Enemies camp, escaped.

CHAP. IV.
TOTILAS led Demetrius with a rope about his neck to the Town wall, willing him
to persuade the besieged, not to perish, trusting in Groundless hopes, but by
yiedling to get free of their miseries; that no further succors could possibly
be expected from the Emperor, and that their hopes and power was lost with
that Navy. Demetrius spoke all this unto them, and they being extremely pressed
with famine, and all kind of necessities, and seeing the disaster of Demetrius,
and hearing what he said, dispaired, and lamented, not knowing what to do; and
their City was full of tumult and howlings, Totilas then calling them to the
battlements, spoke thus.

Citizens of Naples, we do not now besiege you upon any quarrel we have
against you; but to disingage you from Masters that hate you, and to have the
power to recompense the service of every one of you to us, and his sufferings
from the Enemy, you of all the Italians having showed greatest affection to our
Nation, and with most unwillingnesse come under the enemy; that now being
necesssarily to besiege you, we blush when we think of your fidelity, though
we besiege you not for your hurt. Think not therefore, as offended with the
accidents of the siege, that you must he ever angry with us. They who study the
Good of their friends, are not to be blamed by them, when they are enforced to
do them good by none of the gentlest means. And be not afraid of the Enemy,
nor think by what has past, that they will conquer at last: strange, unlookt
for, and accidental things melt away in time. We have thus determined of you,
to suffer Conon and his Soldiers to go free without harm, or loss, they
presently surrendering the City unto us; and upon this we are ready to swear
that the Napolitans shall be safe. Both Conon and the Napolitans accepted this
offer of Totilas, being extremely pressed with the Famine; but to comply with
their faith to the Emperor, and having some hope of succors, they promised to
surrender the City within thirty days. Totilas to put such hopes out of their
heads, assigned three Months, in which time he would not assault nor have any
design upon them. But the besieged not attending the day (though assigned
accordingly) urged by their necessitiess, received a while after Totilas into
the City. The winter also ended, and the eighth year of this war, written by
Procopius. Totilas used humanity to the Napolitans, not like a Barbarian Enemy.
For fearing least the languishing Romans with Famine, coming suddenly to eat
their fill, Incipit an bell. Goth 9.17.
might surfeit themselves with fulness; He commanded guards at the Gates,
Justinian^ and An. Dom. 544.
and the port, to suffer no man to go out, and with a provident sparingnesse he
gave them food more scarcely then according to their appetite; adding thereunto
every day unsensibly. Then having restored them to strength, he set open the
Gates, and let them go that would. Conon, and such Soldiers as would not stay
with him, he shipped, and bade them sail whether they pleased: They were
ashamed to return to Constantinople but making toward Rome, the wind came
cross, and being not able to get away, they feared least Totilas might neglect
his agreements, and do them mischief: but he perceiving their trouble, called
them to him, comforted and cheered them, and invited them to join with the
Goths, and buy what they wanted, or take it as from friends. The wind
continuing contrary a long time, he furnished them with horses, wagons, and
provisions, and gave them a convoy of Goths to Rome: But the walls of Naples he
threw to the Gound; that the Romans might not (surprising the Town) infest the
Goths from it: his desire being rather to determine the war at once by a
battle, then to be ever skirmishing against artifices, and stratagems: yet he
left a good part of the said walls standing.

There came to him at that time a Roman of Calabria, complaining, that one of
his Life Guard had forced his daughter, a Virgin; he in great anger put the man
in prison, not denying the fact, and was eager to punish him; but the chief
Goths fearing in the man's behalf, being valiant, and a good soldier, assembled
themselves in his presence, and besought him to pardon the crime; he mildly,
and without any perturbation, made them this answer. Fellow soldiers, I shall
speak to you, not from any humor of cruelty, or delight in my countrymens
misfortunes; but from my fear of some ill consequence unto us. I know that
most men shift the names of things to their contrary; they call the
inobservation of Laws, Mercy; and hence all good things come to be corrupted,
and confounded. On the contraty, to pinch upon Laws too exactly, is perverse
and grievous, and also to use specious names, as a veil to a lincentious
power, thereby to act wickedness with more security. But you I advise by no
means to exchange your own safety for the guilt of another man's sin, nor to
share in his impiety, having done no ill your selves: For to commit an offense,
and to hinder the offenders punishment is equal. Consider thus the business
now presented, and determine accordingly; you have the choice offered you,
whether this man shall escape the just punishment of his offense, or our nation
be preserved, and conquer in this war. Think what numbers of Soldiers we had
in the beginning of it, how famous, how well experienced in war; in a word, our
endless wealth, abundance of horse and arms, and all the strong holds of
Italy, and these were important preparations for a War. But when under
Theodatus, a man that valued riches more then right, we made God angry with us
by our lawless living; how we sped you all know, and by what kind of men, and
by how many we were beaten. Now God, having sufficiently punished our faults,
frames our life to his own will, and conducts our affairs beyond our hopes.
And being such now, and having vanquished our Enemies, not proportionably to our
powers, it will be more advantageous for us, to prepare a fair occasion of
victory by doing that which is just, then by the contrary to appear envious of
our own Good For it cannot, it cannot be, that he that practices wrong and
oppression; should get honor in the day of battle: the fortune of the War is
adjudged to man's good or bad lives. The chief Goths upon this speech of
Totilas, ceased to intercede for the offender, and left him to him; who soon
after put him to death, and bestowed his Estate upon the ravished maid.

In this mean time the Roman army preyed upon the Subjects, leaving no
insolence unacted. Their commanders in their Garrisons with their Mistresses
lived riotously; having the Soldiers disobedient, and full of all kind of
disorders: between both the armies, the Italians suffered the hardest measures;
the Enemy took their lands from them, and the Emperors army their goods: they
were basely beaten for nothing, and perished for want of food. The Soldiers
could not defend them from the Enemy, and were so far from blushing to see
their miseries, that by their wrongs they made the Barbarians dear unto them.
Constianus troubled at this, wrote to Justinian, professing his disability to
encounter the Goths: and the Commanders signed the Letter, being a confession
of their base fear to fight.

Totilas also sent this Letter to the Roman Senate. When men ignorantly, or upon
forgetfullnesse do wrong, the wronged are to be easy to grant pardon: The
cause of the offense concurring in such, excuses the heaviest of the
accusation. But a man that does wrong upon malice, is not to be admitted so
much as to plead; seeing he is to bear the blame not only of his fact; but of
his intent. Which being so, what can you apologize for your actions against the
Goths? Can you be ignorant of the favors of Theoderick and Amalasuntha? or can
time wear them out of your remembrance? neither is possible. The benefits have
not been mean, nor are of an ancient date; but in the most important things,
and lately done. For the Greeks Goodness to their subjects, your selves have,
heard of it, and you have had trial of it, and you have known how the Goths
and Italians have sped under them. What Guests and friends they have been to
you, the Audits of Alexander may inform you, to say nothing of their Soldiers
and Captains; you have enjoyed their noble usage, by which their affairs are
come into this case now. Think not this to be the reproaches of an insolent
young man, nor the vaunts of a Barbarian Prince. I say not, that our subduing
of these men is a work of my valor; but that due vengeance for the injuries
done to you has overtaken them. And how absurdly it shows, that God should
punish them for you, and yet you adhere to their folly, and refuse deliverance
from the miseries arising from thence. Make therefore some introduction of an
apology, and of our pardoning you; which will be, if while you have some hope
(though a poor one) you choose what is best for you, and repair what you have
done amiss against us.

Totilas gave this letter to some prisoners, to deliver to the Senators in
Rome; which they did; but John forbade them to answer it. Totilas wrote many
other Letters to them, wherein were strong oaths, that no Roman should receive
hurt from the Goths I cannot say who were the Messengers, all of them were in
the night, and set up in the most public places of the City, and discovered in
the morning. The Roman Commanders suspected the Arian priests, and put them out
of Rome. Totilas hereupon sent part of his army into Calabria, to summon the
Castle of Otranto; and (the Garrison refusing to yield) to besiege it: Himself
with his main forces went against the towns about Rome.

CHAP. V.
THE news of these things troubled the Emperor; and though the Persian War
lay heavily upon him, he was constrained to send Belisarius against Totilas;
and the Winter ended, and the ninth year of this War, written by Procopius;
when Belisarius went the second time into Italy. Incipit Annus 10. Bell. Goth.
in anno 18. reg. Justiniani, and Anno Dom. 544.
Having but few Soldiers, (as being not able to withdraw his own Forces from
the Army in Persia) he levied with his own money Voluntaries in Thrace, being
assisted by the Emperors direction with Vitalius, General of Illyrium, lately
returned from Italy, where he had left the Illyrian Cohorts; they both raised
4000. men, and came to Salona, determining to go to Ravenna, and thence to make
the War: For about Rome they found they could not land unespyed, (the Enemy
being in Campania and Calabria) nor yet force their landing, being inferior in
powers.

In the mean time, the Garrison in Otranto (the Victual being absolutely
failed,) capitulated about the surrender of the Castle, by a day assigned.
Belisarius put a years Victual aboard Ships, and commanded Valentinus to
transport it to Otranto, and to take out the former Garrison, pined with
Sickness, and Famine, and put in the Soldiers he had with him aboard, being
fresh and well supplied. Valentinus with a fair wind got to Otranto four days
before the time assigned, and finding the Harbor unguarded, was Master of it,
and entered the Castle without resistance. The Goths being careless, and lying
still under their confidence in the Capitulation, and imagining no opposition,
and then seeing the Fleet enter, ran away in fear, and encamped themselves
some distance from the Town, and advertised Totilas of what happened. Some
Troops of Valentinus from Otranto made in-roads into the Country, and meeting
the Enemy upon the Sea shore, they fought, were beaten, and most of them fled
into the Sea; where having lost 170. men, the rest retired into the Castle. But
Valentinus, as Belisarius commanded, took out the old Garrison, (being men
half dead) and leaving fresh men with a years Victual, he went to Salonae
with the rest. Belisarius from thence came with the Fleet before Pola; where he
staid, and ordered the Army. Totilas hearing of his coming, and being desirous
to know his Forces, he wrote Letters to him in the name of one Bonus, Nephew to
one John, and Commander of the Garrison in Genoa, entreating his speedy repair
to him, as being in much distress and danger. This Letter he delivered to five
witty fellows, directing them to spy what Forces Belisarius had, and to give
out that they came from Bonus. Belisarius used the men courteously, (as his
manner was) perused the Letter, and bad them tell Bonus that he would be with
him with his Army. They having spyed into every thing, returned to the Camp to
Totilas, assuring him that Belisarius powers were not considerable.

In the mean time Totilas took Tibur, which had in it a Garrison of Isaurians:
Some of the Townes-men, guarding the Gates with the Isaurians, fell into an
idle brable with them, and upon that ground drew in the Enemy by night. The
Isaurians rallyed themselves (seeing the Town taken) and almost all got away;
but of the Townes-men the Goths spared not a man, and killed the Bishop of the
Town in a fashion, which I will conceal, not to leave to Posterity Monuments
of Inhumanity: And one Catellus, a man much esteemed in Italy, perished also.
Thus the Goths having Tibur, the Roman Citizens could no more import Provisions
out of Tuscany, by the River of Tiber, the Town being upon the River 15. miles
above Rome, and commanding the passage thither. Then came Belisarius to
Ravennae with his Fleet, and calling to him the Goths there, and the Roman
Soldiers, he spoke thus.

It is not now only, that Vice has ruined, what has been built by Virtue;
from the beginning it has been so in humane Affairs. The lewdness of bad men
has been still able to demolish the Actions of the good. This has overturned
the Emperors Affairs; who to repair the Error, has made less account of
subduing the Persians, then of it; and has sent me to cure the Faults
committed by either Captains, Soldiers, or Goths. It is above humane
condition not to err, but it becomes the Emperor to repair the Errors of
those, whom from his Soul he loves; whereby you shall be also eased of your
grievances, and both perceive and feel his good affection toward you, then
which what Wealth is more valuable. My coming therefore being to this purpose,
it behooves you to endeavor the obtaining of that Fruit, which will arise from
thence. If any of you have Friends, or Kinsmen with Totilas the Usurper, let
him send for them, acquainting them with the Emperors intention. Thus you may
find good both from a peace, and the Emperors Favor for me: I come not to
pick Quarrels, nor to be an Enemy to the Emperors Subjects by my good will:
But if some will still make slight the choosing their own good, and others take
Arms against us; we must, though most unwillingly, use such as Enemies.
Belisarius spoke thus; but no Goth, nor Roman came into him; so he sent
Therimuth, one of his Lifeguard, with some of his own Retinew, and Vitalius
with the Illyrian Cohorts into Emilia, to attempt the Towns there: Vitalius
came to Bononia, and after the taking of some Castles by composition, lay still
there. Soon after the Illyrians retired home upon the sudden, having suffered
nothing, nor so much as heard any ill. They sent Agents to the Emperor, for
pardon of this Retreat, in regard they had long served in Italy, and received
no pay, and much was due to them from the Treasury. They heard besides of an
Army of Hunnes, which in Illyrium made Captives their Wives and Children, which
caused them (wanting necessaries also) to go home all in one Troop. The
Emperor was troubled at the proceeding, but at last pardoned them. Totilas
hearing of the Illyrians Retreat, sent Forces to drive Vitalius and his Troops
out of Bononia, who with Therimuth laid an Ambush for them, killed many, and
routed the rest; where Nazares an Illyrian Captain of good quality, did
Miracles upon the Enemy. Therimuth then returned to Belisarius, who sent him
Nicetas, and Sabinianus with 1000. men to Auximum, to re-enforce Magnus there
beseiged. They by night got into the Town unseen by Totilas and the Enemies
Camp. The next day at noon, they sallied to encounter a party of Enemies they
had notice of; sending before avantcoureurs to discover their Forces, that they
might not blindly set on them. Ricilas of the Lifeguard to Belisarius, being
in drink, would himself go upon the discovery, and gallopt on alone. In a
rough stony way he met three Goths, and made a stand, as to fight with them,
being very Valiant; but when he saw more coming in from all sides, he ran away.
His Horse in the rough ground came over and over with him, at which the Enemy
gave a great shout, and darted all their Javelins at him; the Romans perceiving
it, went to his rescue, but he was covered with Javelins, and dyed upon the
place. Therimuth took up his dead body and carried it into Auximum, having met
with a conclusion of life not suitable to the Valor of the man.

CHAP. VI.
SAbinianus and Therimuth upon conference with Magnus, and consideration of the
inconvenience of their longer stay, being so far under-matcht to the Enemy, and
by consuming the Towns Provision making it more ready to be lost, they
prepared to be gone, and to begin their journey in the night: But a Soldier
ran out to the Enemies Camp closely, and revealed the design. Totilas chose
out 1000. good men, and laid them concealed three miles and three quarters from
Auximum. These perceiving the Enemy at midnight upon the way, fell to work with
their Swords, and killed 200. but being dark, Sabinianus and Therimuth got away
to Ariminum; all the Baggage, Arms and Apparel, the Goths took. Between
Auximum and Ariminum are two small Towns, Pisaurus and Phanus upon the Jonian
Gulf. Vitigis in the beginning of the War had burnt the houses, and broken
down half their Walls, that the Romans surprising them, might not infest the
Goths. Pisaurus Belisarius resolved to seize, as a place fit for
Horse-pastures; he sent some in the night to take the exact measure of the
Dimension of each Gate, then framed Gates lined with Iron, and sent them
thither by Sea, commanding Sabinianus and Therimuth to set them up, and to stay
in the Town; and being secure, to repair the Walls with stones, and earth, as
they could. This they did; and Totilas upon the news came against them with a
great Army. But failing to take the Town, after much time spent in the
attempt, he retired to his Camp before Auximum: Where the Romans sallied no
more, but kept close within their walls. Belisarius sent Artasiras a Persian,
and Barbation a Thracian, two of his Lifeguard, to guard Rome with Bessas,
being there already, directing them not to sally at all.

But Totilas finding Belisarius not able to fight with him, fell upon the
strong Towns; in Picenia he blocked up Firmum, and Asculum: and so ended the
Winter, and the tenth year of this War, written by Procopius.

When Belisarius, Incipit annus 11. Bell. Goth. in Anno 19.
having no means to relieve the besieged Towns, sent John to Constantinople,
Justiniani, and Ann. Dom. 545.
making him swear to return speedily, and to importune the Emperor for an
Army and money, horses, and arms; the Soldiers being few, and refusing to
fight, because of their wants, the Treasury owing them much money. And he wrote
of these particulars to the Emperor in these words.

Most mighty Emperor! We are come into Italy, wanting men, horses, arms, and
money; And without a competent preparation of these, no man can make War. Our
Thracians and Illyrians we behold here few, wretched, and straggling without
Arms, and unexercised for any fight; The rest deficient, fearful of the Enemy,
with spirits dejected by their often beating, and not simple running away only,
but quitting their Horses, and throwing down their Arms. To raise contribution
in Italy is not possible, it being possessed by the Enemy; And being behind with
the Soldiers for their Pay, we cannot lay commands on them, the debt taking
away our confidence. And the most of those that served your Majesty are run to
the Enemy. If nothing therefore needed, but the sending Belisarius into Italy,
the War is excellently prepared; for I am in the midst of Italy. But if you
mean to vanquish your Enemies, there must be other preparations. No General
can subsist without men to follow him. Above all things it behooves therefore,
that you send me mine own Lanciers and Targettiers, and store of Hunnes and
other Barbarians, who must have present money.

Thus wrote Belisarius: But John staying long at Constantinople, effected
nothing for what he came thither, but married the Daughter of Germanus,
brothers son to the Emperor.

In the mean time Totilas took Firmum and Asculum by composition; and in
Tuscany besieged Spoletum, and Assisium. Herodian commanded the Garrison in
Spoletum; and that of Assisium, Sisiphris a Goth, but well affected to the
Romans. Herodian agreed to render the Town with himself and Soldiers within
thirty days, if no succor came, and gave his son for Hostage. And the day
presixed being come, and no Romans appearing, Herodian and the Soldiers
yielded themselves and the Town to Totilas. Some say that Herodian did this
upon hatred to Belisarius, who threatened to question him for his rapines and
oppression. Sisiphris in Assisium made some sallies, and in the end most of his
men and himself were slain; whereat the Townsmen despairing, rendered the
Town. Totilas also sent to Perusia, threatening Cyprianus there, if he would
not yield the Town to him, and promising him money to do it. Not prevailing
with him, he practiced with Vliphus, one of his Lifeguard, for money to murder
him; who watched him when he was alone, and having killed him, ran to Totilas.
Yet the Garrison kept the Town for the Emperor, and the Goths retired from it.
Then went Totilas to Rome, and besieged it. To the Husbandmen of Italy he did
no damage, letting them securely manure their Land, paying to him the rents and
tributes reserved to the Treasury, or the Owners At Rome, some Goths
approaching the walls, Artasiras and Barbation (against the opinion of Bessas)
sallyed with some Troops, and killed many, routing the rest; whom pursuing too
far, they fell into the Enemies Ambushes, where they lost most of their men,
and escaped narrowly themselves, and afterward for bare to charge the Enemy,
though they pressed upon them.

Hence the Famine grew sore in Rome, no Victual coming in by Land, and being
shut from the Sea. For the Goths, after they had Naples, kept a kind of a Fleet
of small Barques about the Islands of Aeolus, and other Islands in that Sea,
which guarded exactly the passage of ships; that all from Sicily, sailing to
the Port of Rome, fell among them.

Totilas sent also an Army into Emilia, to take Placentia by force or
composition, being the chief City of that Province, and well fortified, and
standing upon the Poe, and only remaining obedient to the Romans. This Army
summoned the Garrison to yield upon composition; and not prevailing, fell to
besiege it, finding they wanted provisions. And at the same time the Commanders
in Rome were jealous of Cethegus, a Patrician, that he betrayed them; who
thereupon fled to Centumcellae.

Belisarius fearing the loss of Rome, and of all the rest; and from Ravenna,
and with so small an Army, to relieve them being not able, he resolved to rise
from thence, and to surprise some places near Rome, from whence he might aid
it in distress. He repented his coming to Ravenna, upon the persuasions of
Vitalius, disadvantageously for the Emperors service; For being shut up there,
he gave the Enemy free scope to advance their affairs. Either Belisarius chose
the worst, that the Romans might have a mischief; or he chose the best: but
God crossed it, purposing to favor Totilas and the Goths, and turning Belisarias
good counsels to the quite contrary. So when Fortune blows a fair gale, men's
worst counsels meet no disaster, being wasted by the higher power to all
advantages. Unfortunate men either advise nothing well, their fate hiding from
them all knowledge and right apprehension of things: Or advising well, fortune
with a cross wind turns their good advises to bad events.

But Belisarius left Ravenna, committing the guard of it to Justinus; and
through Dalmatia came to Epidamnus, where he staid, expecting an Army from
Constantinople, and by his letters acquainting the Emperor with his condition.
Who sent him an Army of Barbarians and Roman Soldiers under John, the Nephew
of Vitalianus, and Isaac the Armenian, Brother to Aratius, and Narses; who
coming to Epidamnus, joined with Belisarius.

He sent also Narses the Eunuch to the Herulian Princes, to obtain aides of
them for Italy. Many Herulians came along with him, under Philimuth and others,
to the confines of Thrace, there to Winter, and at the beginning of the Spring
to be sent to Belisarius. With them was John Phagas In this journey they did
the Romans a great service by chance. A multitude of Slavonians had passed the
River Ister, and sacked the Towns thereabout, and taken abundance of Roman
Captives. The Herulians fought with them, and though inferior in numbers,
beat them, and killed many, and freed the captives, and sent them home.

CHAP. VII.
AT that time Narses discovered the imposture of one naming himself
Chilbudius, who had been a famous General of the Romans. This Chilbudius was
first of Iustinian's Retinew, a valiant Soldier, and so great a despiser of
wealth, that it was his greatest riches to possess nothing. Justinian in the
fourth year of his Reign made him General of Thrace, and gave him the guard
of the River Ister, to hinder the passage of Barbarians; the Hunnes formerly,
Antians and Slavonians having come over, and done much mischief to the Romans.
Chilbudius grew so terrible there, that in his three years continuance in that
charge, not a Barbarian durst pass the River; and the Romans under Chilbudius
invaded the other side, and killed and took many Captives. After three years
he passed over the River with a small Army; the Slavonians in a Battle stiffly
fought, killed many Romans, and Chilbudins the General. From thence forward
the Barbarians came over at pleasure, and the Provinces lay open to them; all
the Roman Empire in this not countervailing the valor of one man. After this
the Antians and Slavonians fell out, and in a Battle the Antians were
vanquished. Wherein a Slavonian took a youth of the Enemy named Chilbudius, and
led him home. This man in time became very affectionate to his Master, and
valiant against the Enemy; having often fought singularly well, hazarding for
his Master, and so getting a great reputation. About the same time the Antians
entered Thrace, which they pillaged, and took many Captives; one of whom Fortune
brought to a gentle Master. But the fellow being a knave, and cunning to
deceive, and desirous withal to return to his own Country, came once to his
Master, and commended his humanity, which God (he said) would reward, and
himself would not be ungrateful to so kind a Master; but if he would follow
his advice, he would make him a rich man. For among the Slavonians was one
Chilbudius the Roman General, unknown, and reputed a slave; whom if he would
ransom, and conduct into Roman Land, he should get the Emperors favor, and a
great reward. Thus this Roman persuaded his Master, and with him went into
Slavonia, there being truce then between them, and safe intercourse. He paid
the ransom to this Chilbudius Master, and took him home; where he asked the
man if he were Chilbudius the Roman General. He told him all the truth; that
he was an Antian, and taken Prisoner by the Slavonians then Enemies, but now
being restored to his Country, he claimed freedom according to the Law.

The man who had laid out his money, stood mute, and vexed to fall from his
hopes thus. But the Roman cheered him up, and to outface the truth, that it
might not cross his return home, confidently said that it was Chilbudius; but
being among Barbarians, he was afraid to reveal himself; Were he once upon
Roman ground, he would be proud of the name, as he had reason. In the end the
business came to the knowledge of all the Antians; who stird in it, pretending a
public interest, and imagining to make a great advantage, of having
Chilbudius the Roman General.

These people both Antians and Slavonians, are not under a Prince, but
anciently are a Democratie: whence all things are brought to the common vote.
They have almost the same Laws and customs: They hold one God, who makes the
lightning, and is only Lord of all things. To him they sacrifice Oxen and other
victimes. They acknowledge no destiny to govern among men; when Death threatens
either in a sickness, or in a War; they promise if they may escape, to offer
to God a sacrifice in recompense for their life: And if they escape, they pay
their vow, and think they have bought their safety. They worship also Rivers,
Nymphs, and other Spirits, to whom they sacrifice too; and by those sacrifices
make their predictions. They dwell in poor wretched Booths, scattered, and
still shifting their habitations. In fights the most part serve on foot, with
Shields and Javelins, having no Corselets, and some not so much as a Coat, or
Mantle; but they tie up their Trouses above their Privities, and so enter into
the fight. They both use one Language, and that a very barbarous one: And they
differ not in shape, being all tall and very strong. Their hair is neither
very white, nor yellow, nor yet black at all, but inclining to red. They live
hardly, and slovenly like the Hunnes; wicked they are not, nor cunning, but in
their simplicity much of the Hunnish disposition. They had both formerly but
one name, and were called Spori, because they pitch their booths (...)
scatteredly; and so they take up much space of Land, holding the most part of
the other side of the River Ister.

But then the Antians in their Assembly urged the said man to acknowledge
himself to be Chilbudius, and denying it, threatened him. In the mean time
came Ambassadors to them from Justinian, who offered to plant them in Turris,
an ancient City built by Trajan; which had been sacked by Barbarians, and layen
long wast. Justinian offered them this City, and the Country about, formerly
belonging to the Romans, and to plant them in it with his powers; and besides
to give them great sums of money; Conditionally they should keep a perpetual
league with the Romans, and hinder the Hunnes from overrunning the Empire that
way. They liked the Proposition, and promised to do so, if the Emperor would
make Chilbudius his General, to settle their Plantation, affirming that man to
be Chilbudius: And the fellow exalted with these hopes, had now a mind to it,
and took the name upon him. So he was sent to Constantinople, and upon his way
thither, Narses met him; and upon speech with him, found him a counterset; yet
he spoke Latin, and had many marks of Chilbudius, which he cunningly assumed.
Narses kept him close Prisoner, and at last got out of him all the matter, and
took him with him to Constantinople.

CHAP. VIII
IN the mean time Belisarius sent Valentinus, and one of his life Guard named
Phocas, an expert Soldier, with forces to the Haven of Rome, directing them to
guard the castle of Portus, with the Garrison already there, commanded by
Innocentius, and by excursions from thence to infest the Enemies camp. They
accordingly sent word to Bessas in Rome, that they were ready to give a sudden
alarm to the Enemies quarters, praying him when he saw the fight begun, to
ride out to second them with some of his choice men; that so both together
might do some service upon the Enemy. Bessas, though he had 3000 Soldiers,
liked it not: yet Valentinus and Phocas with 500 charged of a sudden, and
killed some. The besieged saw the stir and tumult, but sallied not; so that the
other retired safe to Portus. Again they sent to Bessas, complaining of his
unbeseeming sloth, and that they would make another Excursion, praying him to
charge at the same time with all his army; but he refused to hazard a sally. So
Valentinus and Phocas resolved to charge with greater forces. But a Soldier of
Innocentius ran away to Totilas, advertizing him how from Portus he would be
assaulted the next day. Totilas laid ambushes in their way, into which the next
day they fell, and with the loss of most of their men were slain themselves;
few escaped to Portus.

Vigilius Bishop of Rome, being then in Sicily, sent some ships laden with
corn, by some means to be put into Rome. The Enemy saw them coming into the
harbor, and hid themselves in houses, to surprise them so soon as they put to
land; which the Garrison in Portus perceiving, from the battlements, they waved
their Garments to those in the ships, to come no nearer, but to turn some other
way. But they understanding not their signs, took them for rejoycings at their
coming, and invitings into the harbor; and the wind being fair they soon got
in. There were Roman passengers aboard, and Valentinus a Bishop; and the Goths
from their Ambush seized upon the ships, none resisting, and put all to the
sword save the Bishop, whom they brought prisoner to Totilas: and he, after he
had questioned what he would, cut off his hands, charging him that he had not
spoke truth. And then ended the Winter, and the eleventh year of this war,
written by Procopius.

Vigilius also, Bishop of Rome, left Sicily, Incipit anus 12. bell. Goth. in
anno 20. Justinian and anno Dom. 546.
being sent for to Constantinople by the Emperor, and having staid long in
Sicily upon that occasion.

In Placentia, the besieged Romans wanting victual fell to food abominated,
and in the End to eat one another; so that they rendered upon Composition. Rome
also was destitute of all provisions; where was Pelagius, a Deacon of the same,
who had long dwelt in Constantinople, much favored by Justinian, and was grown
rich; and lately come to Rome, he spent most of his riches upon men in want in
this siege, and for his bounty got a great fame; being famous before through
all Italy. The Romans having suffered under the famine incredibly, sent this
Pelagius to Tetilas to obtain some few days of cessation, conditionally, that
if during the same, no succors came from Constantinople, to render themselves
upon a Composition. Pelagius accordingly came to Totilas, who saluted him with
much reverence and courtesy, and first spoke to him thus. Almost all Barbarians
reverence Ambassadors, but I besides, have from my youth honored virtuous men
like your self. And I know that the honoring or disgracing an Ambassador, is
discerned not by fair countenances and hollow-hearted complements, but by true
and real dealing; he is most honored who has the plain truth told him, and is
so dismissed: and he most affronted, who carries home nothing, but fained,
deceitful words. So that Pelagius, there are three things, which if you ask
not, you shall obtain all the rest; and it is good you should not mention them,
least being the cause of your own effecting nothing, you lay the blame on us;
the not asking things suitable to the condition of affairs producing commonly
want of success This then I say, move not for any Sicilian, nor for sparing
the walls of Rome, nor for restitution of your fugitive servants. For it cannot
be, that the Goths should favor a Sicilian, that these walls should stand, or
that our Soldiers should return again to be slaves to their Masters. And I
will tell you my reasons of these propositions, that they may not seem to
proceed from a wilfulness. Sicily has been ever happy, rich, and most
fruitful, not supplying only the Inhabitants; but transporting also to you of
Rome, yearly sufficient for your uses; whereupon you besought Th^od^rick not to
place Garrisons in it; least it might decay in the Liberties and happiness
thereof. Things being thus, upon the coming of a Fleet of Enemies upon the
Coast, not comparable to our powers, the Sicilians neither advertized the
Goths, nor shut their Gates, nor opposed them in any sort, but with all
alacrity received them with open arms, like persidious slaves, who long had
watched an opportunity to run from their old masters to strangers. Hence the
Enemy issued and got all Italy, surprising Rome, and maintaining it against
more then a years siege, with the abundance of corn brought out of Sicily.
Thus it stands with the Sicilians, whom the Goths cannot pardon, the
heinousness of their crimes making them incapable of mercy. These walls when
the Enemy had once got into, they could never be drawn to a battle in open
field: with stratagems and circumventions they cluded our powers, and became
strangely Lords of all we had: And now we must prevent the like hereafter. Men
ignorantly undone, to fall again into the same ruin whereof they had experience
before, is not to be attributed to the crosnesse of Fortune, but to their own
gross Folly. Besides, the demolishing your walls is your own advantage;
Neither part hereafter being to be shut within them, and starved by the
besieging adversary. So that both will put it to the fortune of a battle, and
you without incurring danger, will be the prize of the victor. Touching your
fugitive slaves, who have fought for us, and have our promise not to abandon
them to their former Masters, if we should now betray them, even your selves
will never trust us; it being impossible that he that neglects his Engagements
to men of all the most to be pityed, should be constant to any: It will be a
Character of his falsehood to all that meet him. To this Speech of Totilas,
Pelagius thus answered. Great Sir, having intimated your respect of my Person,
and of the quality of an Ambassador, yet have you ranckt both in the basest
condition. I conceive him to affront more his Friend, and an Ambassador, who
resolves to send him away without his business, then he that strikes, or
otherwise abuses him. Ambassadors come not to receive honors from those who
admit them, but to get dispatches for their good that sent them. It is better
they were affronted at first, and at last effect that they come for; then after
many Caresses, to return without their hopes. So that to what purpose should I
supplicate you in these things, or importune one that denies us, before he
hear us? Only this I must say; that you show what mercy you mean to use to the
Romans, who have taken Arms against you; who resolve an irreconcilable hatred
