give assurances for the same: But they rejected them, and resolved to oppose,
though they had no thought of subsisting long; but they chose to dye bravely.
Bessas was desirous to draw them from this Opinion, and to persuade them to
live. He commanded a Roman Soldier to speak to them to that purpose, as he
dictated it unto him; who being near, said thus.

Valiant Persians, what mean you thus to pull on your own destruction? using a
senseless endeavor to dye, and shaming the profession of Valor; which never
opposes unresistible necessities, but wisely yields to the Conqueror. It is
not dishonorable to obey your Fortune, and Live; Necessity having left no
hope, excuses the dishonor, although one be put to the poorest Actions; pardon
ever attending that which cannot be avoided. Insoevident a danger, affect not
therefore pride, nor sacrifice your lives for a little vainglory. Think how
men once dead revive not again; but that the living may in time recompose
themselves. Consult therefore your last consultation, and study your own good:
Those Counsels are ever best, wherein the advisers have left it in their power
to repent. We pity this your struggling under the Yoke, and spare you, so fond
to dye. And while you are wanton and foolish in a case of life; we, as Romans,
and Christians, commiserate you. If you live, the worst that shall befall you,
will be to change your Commonwealth for a better, and to have Justinian your
Lord instead of Chosroes; and for this we give you our Faith. Murder not
therefore your selves, having means to live; It is not excusable thus to no
purpose to be in love with dismal things, which is not to be valiant, but to
be weary of life. The valiant man endures, while from his sufferings he expects
advantage. Men commend a willing death, when some gallant hope is built upon
it; But a precipitate end, is a rash and useless folly, and a vaineglorious
dying foolish: Wise men condemning such a fond pretext of brave spirit.
Consider moreover, if herein you be not unthankful to God; who if he Would
have you destroyed, would not have delivered you to men, who desire your
preservation. Thus it is; and do you advise, whether you be worthy to live or
no.

The Persians would not so much as afford attention to this Counsel, as men
willingly deaf. By the Generals direction therefore the Romans threw fire into
the Cittadell, thinking so to bring them to yield. But they, though beholding
the mischief, and knowing that certainly they would be all consumed, and
having no hope by resisting to escape, yet would not come into their Enemies
hands; but perished all with the Cittadell; the Romans wondering at it. How
serious a business Chosroes held Lazica to be, appeared by this his putting
into Petra the choice and the bravest of his men, and by storing the same with
so great a proportion of arms, that to every Roman soldiers share upon the
pillage fell five men's furnitures, besides much burnt in the Cittadell. There
was also found corn, and other salted provisions for five years siege: Wine
there was none; but some Beveridge, and store of beans. The Romans wondered to
find water coming from the Aquaeduct, till they understood the mystery. For
Chosroes having taken Petra, and placed a Garrison in it; foreseeing the siege,
and that doubtless the Romans would attempt the Aquaeduct, divided the water,
brought from it to the City, into three parts, by making a deep Sewer, and by
building three several Aquaeducts; the one at the bottom of the Sewer up to
the middle of it, covered with stones and Earth; above that a second covered
also, and a third above Ground and visible. The Romans not understanding those
close conveiances, spoiled the uppermost at the beginning of the siege, not
working downward to the other, thinking the water did fail the City by what
they had done; and from their loathnesse to work, their wits failed them. The
siege continuing, the Romans understood by some prisoners, that the besieged
had water from the Aquaeduct still; whereupon digging, they found the second
Conduit and cut it, and in their second Error were not admonished by their
first. But now the city being taken, and finding the water still coming in, and
from their Prisoners, hearing how it was done; they saw too late their Enemies
providence, and their own negligence. The Prisoners Bessas sent all to the
Emperor, and threw down the Walls of Petra, that the Enemy might put them to
no more business about it: which the Emperor approved, and commended him both
for his valor, and this wise counsel of his. Thus Bessas, by his good
fortune, and the great valor showed in this action, grew into a great
reputation again: when he commanded Rome, there was great hope of him, having
done very valiantly in former employments. After his ill fortune at Rome (the
same being sacked by the Goths, and the whole strength of the Romans there being
well nigh destroyed) yet at his return to Constantinople, the Emperor made him
General against the Persians; though the world flouted the Emperors
resolution herein, in committing the Persian war to an old man almost in his
Grave, and one who had been so grossly beaten by the Goths; but notwithstanding
this general opinion, Bessas used the valor, and found the good fortune, I
have said. So are humane affairs determined, not as men imagine; but as God
swayes the Balance: And this men call Fortune; finding accidental things to
succeed in a way by them not discerned, and so attributing a name of Fortune to
things above their own reason.

CHAP. VIII.
IN the mean time Mermeroes, afraid of Petra, was coming with his army thither
so soon as the winter was done, and the season was sit; but hearing what was
become of it, he staid his journey, knowing how on that side of the Phasis the
Lazians had no Town, but Petra. So that he marched homeward, having pre-possest
the passages in Lazica, from Iberia: and he past over the Phasis, where he
found it fordable, and over another River called Reon. Having now the Phasis to
his right hand, be led his army to Archaeopolis (the chief city of Lazica)
being most horse, and with eight Elephants, which the Persians use as a Tower
to stand upon, and shoot upon the Enemies heads. The Persians industry also is
worthy admiration; having made the way between Iberia and Lazica (which was
unpassable for rocky places, covered with thick woods and bushes; that there
was no going for a man a foot) now so plain and easy, that not only their
Horses, but their Elephants may pass. There came also 12000 Sabirian Hunnes to
Mermeroes; who fearing least their multitude would not obey him, but might do
him some mischief rather, he kept 4000 of them, and sent the rest home with
good store of money: The Roman army ^ounted in all to 12000, whereof Odonachus
and Babas two expert Commanders, had 3000. and the rest encamped near the
Phasis (with intention to succor any place where the Enemy should fall on)
commanded by Bonilus and Vligangus: there was also Varazes the Persamenian with
them, wholate came out of Italy followed by 800 Tzanians. Bessas was retired
into Pontus and Armenia, his Government, meaning to toil no more, but to get
what he could by his place; and by his avariciousnesse he again ruined the
Roman affairs. After his victory at Petra, if he had made haste to fortify
the passages into Lazica from Iberia, the Persians had not entered Lazica, which
he even as good as delivered to the Enemy by his neglect, and carelessness of
the Emperors indignation. Who indeed used much to connive at the Errors of
his chief Ministers, and they from thence committed many, both in the courses
of their lives, and in their Governments. The two Castles of Scanda and
Sarapanis, in Lazica, about the frontier of Iberia, standing upon two passages
very hard to get through, the Lazians had demolisht. These Castles Justinian in
the beginning of the War guarded with Romans, taking out the Lazians formerly
in it; but the Romans wanting victual, and being not able like the Lazians to
live long upon Elymus, a kind of pulse like mill-seed; the Lazians also being
weary of bringing Provision upon their backs (there being no passage for
horses) the Romans there abandoned them, and the Persians took them; but upon
the truce restored them to Justinian for the Forts of Bolum and Pharangium, as
I have said before. But the Lazians having demolisht them now, the Persians
repaired Scanda, and held it at this coming of Mermeroes into Lazica. And
entering the same from Iberia, the first Town you meet with in the Plain, is
Rodopolis, very assaultable; whereupon the Lazians demolisht it, fearing the
Persian Invasion; so that now Mermeroes marched on to Archaeopolis. But he would
not sit down before it, fearing the Romans Army at his back, encamping near
the Phasis. Toward them he went first, and passing by Archaeopolis told them,
That he meant to make a visit to the Romans upon the Phasis, and that done,
would come to them again. They answered him bravely, and bade him go, and that
if he spoke once with the Romans there, he would never come back to them. But
the Commanders of the Roman Army hearing the news, and finding themselves too
weak, went aboard their Darks, carrying with them what they could, and throwing
the rest into the River. Soon after came Mermeroes, and was very melancholy to
see the Romans Camp with not a man in it; he burnt the same, and in much anger
led his Army back to Archaeopolis.

This City stands upon a kind of Rock, and by it runs a River descending from
the next Mountains. The Low Gate opens near the foot of the Rock, and the
ground to it from the Plain rises only, but makes no difficulty of access.
The Gate opening toward the Rock is very hard to approach, having also for a
great way thereabout great Thickets. The town Walls were built up to the
River, that they may draw up their water, having none within the Town.
Mermcroes was eager to assault, and finding it rising ground, not to be meddled
with by ordinary Rams, he caused his Sabirians to make Rams portable on men's
shoulders, using the advantage of his Enemies experiment thereof at Petra,
which he had heard of. And these Sabirians made such Rams as their Contrymen
in league with the Romans made then. Mermeroes set against the rocky part of
the City the Delomites, a people dwelling in the midst of Persia, among
unaccessable Mountains, and so not subject to the Persian, but free; and in
the Persians wars they serve them for pay, being all foot men, with sword and
shield and two Javelins; and are nimble to climb rocks, and to run along the
sides of mountains, as upon plain Ground. These being there ordered, Mermeroes
with the rest of his army assaulted at the lower gate, and with his new Rams,
and his Elephants. Where the Persians and Sabirians galled the Romans with
their shot, making them almost to quit the Battlements, and the Delomites did
as much on their side with their Javelins, that the Romans were in much
extremity. Odonachus and Babas (were it to show their own, or try the Romans
resolution, or by some instinct) leaving some few upon the Battlements, drew
together the rest, and said thus to them.

Fellow Soldiers! you see our danger; but nevertheless you must nor yield to
it: Nothing preserves men despairing of life, but not to be in love with life:
which sond love is commonly attended with destruction. Consider how in such a
difficulty as this, it is not safe to resist an Enemy from the Battlements of a
Town: We may do it bravely, but the distance of place will not permit us to
use our valor: The best we can get, is, to get off and retire: But if we fight
body, to body, courage is it gets the better there, and the Victory goes with
valor. They who get the better from a Wall, gain not much; for the next day
the danger renues as fresh as ever, and so they perish by little and little,
and loose at last their defended Fortresses. But who overcome in a standing
fight, are ever after secure. Taking this into our thoughts, let us make a
brave sally, trusting in Gods assistance, and hoping well even from the
despair we are in. God preserves those most, who have no hope left in
themselves.

CHAP. IX.
ODONACHVS and Babas having thus fayd, led out the Army: Some they left
behind, having suspicion of one of the chief Inhabitants of the City, a
Lazian; who had been treated with by Mermeroes in the heat of the assault, to
set the City-Magazines on fire. Mermeroes by this thought either to enter the
Town with less opposition, the Romans being busy to quench the fire, or if,
being eager to defend the Town, they neglected the fire, he should deprive
them of their stores, and so easily in time get the Town by Famine. The Lazian
according to his promise to Mermeroes, when he saw the assault at the hottest,
fired the Storehouses. The Romans left behind, seeing the flame rise, ran to
it, and with much toil, and some hurt, put it out. Those who sallyed, frighted
the Enemy with the suddenness, and killed them without resistance. For the
Persians suspected no sally from so few Defendants, and were scatterd, and in
disorder as upon an assault: Some with the Ramms upon their shoulders, and
without their arms: others could do no Execution with their bows, the Romans
at the first running up close unto them; who slasht with their Swords on all
sides, and cut them in pieces. One of their Elephants also, either wounded, or
otherwise starting, flew back, and cast his riders, breaking the rancks, and
driving the Persians backward; whise the Romans securely cut off all in their
way. It may seem strange, that the Romans knowing so well the means of
resisting Elephants, did nothing now; confounded (it seems) with the present
business. The means is that, which was practiced upon Chosroes at Edessa: an
Elephant there was brought close to the walls, with many of the gallantest
Persians upon it: and appearing like a Tower, and the shot from it being made
directly upon the Defendants heads, the taking of the town was certainly
expected: when the Romans escaped this danger, only by hanging out a Hog from
the Bulwark, which with his squeaking scared the Elephant so, that he turned
about and retired fair and softly home. This now was omitted by the Romans; but
their good fortune supplied their negligence. Having mentioned here Edessa, let
me tell a strange prodigy which happened in that City a little before the
breaking of the Perpetual Peace; which was, the delivering of a woman with a
child having two heads: the events since have made the meaning manifest. For
the East, and much of the Roman Empire besides, have been disputed by two
Emperors; but to return to the fight. The Persians being thus disordered, and
they in the rear seeing the confusion in the van, and not knowing the matter,
ran away in fear. The Dolomites also, who were upon high Ground, and saw all,
ran away shamefully, and the overthrow was clear. Four thousand Persians were
slain, and three principal commanders, and four Ensigns were taken, which
were sent to Constantinople. They lost 20000 horses, not all in fight; but
being spent with running away, and not getting a belly full of meat in Lazica,
they dyed with famine and weakness

Mermeroes having failed at Archaeopolis, was nevertheless master of the field
in Lazica, and led his army into Muchirisis, a country distant from
Archaeopolis a days journey, having many populous villages, and the best land
of Lazica, full of vines and other fruits, through which runs the River of
Reon, upon which anciently the Lazians had a Castle; but they demolisht it,
because standing in a plain it was easy to be taken. The Castle was called by
the Grecians Cotyaeum, but now by the Lazians Cotaesis, as Arrianus in his
history. Others say, it was anciently a City named- Coitaeum; where Aeaetes was
born, whom the Poets call Coitaeensis, and Lazica, Coytaitis. This Castle
Mermerces was desirous to re-edifie, and wanting materials, he staid till the
winter was past, purposing to repair it with Timber. Near unto Cotaesis,
stands Vchimerium, a strong Castle, guarded by Lazians with some Roman
soldiers intermingled: Hereabout Mermeroes lay with his army, possessing the
best land of Lazica, and cutting off the Romans from bringing victual to
Vchimerium, and from marching into the countries of Suania, and Scymnia,
subject to the Persians; an Army in Muchirisis, crossing the passage into those
countries. These were the successes of the armies in Lazica.

In Constantinople, in the mean time Isdigunas the Persian Ambassador, had many
conferences with the Emperor touching a peace. And after a long time spent in
disputes, at last they came to this agreement: That in their proper Dominions
there should be a cessation of arms for five years, and during the same, that
sending to each other they should endeavor to compose the differences
concerning Lazica and the Saracens; and that the Romans should pay to the
Persians twenty Centenaries of Gold for this Cessation of five years, and for
the eighteen months passed between the end of the first Quinquenniall
Cessation, and their sending Ambassadors to each other six Centenaries more;
the Persians alleging, that they yielded to a conference for truce upon that
Condition. These twenty Centenaries, Isdigunas would have presently paid, and
the Emperor demanded to pay them by four Centenaries every year, and thereof
to give caution; but in the end the Romans paid down the whole sum, that they
might not seem to pay a yearly Tribute to the Persians.

Thus men are ashamed more of the dishonor of names, then things. Barsabes
also, a Persian of great quality, and much favored by Chosroes, whom
Valerianus had taken prisoner in a fight in Armenia, and sent to
Constantionople, and for whom Chosroes had offered a great ransom, was now set
at liberty upon the suit of Isdigunas, who promised to persuade Chosroes to
remove his army out of Lazica. This Cessation concluded in the twenty fifth
year of Justinians Reign, much discontented the Romans, whether unreasonable
or no, (as Subjects use to censure the actions of their Princes) I will not
determine. But they alleged, that the Persians being now strong in Lazica,
they might securely without the interruption of any, for five years to come,
hold the fairest pieces of it, and that the Romans would never afterward be
able to drive them out of it, but the Persians have easy access even to
Constantinople it self. These considerations troubled most men, but they could
not help it; and likewise to see the ancient endeavor of the Persians, to make
the Romans tributary, which by war they could never hope to effect, now
established by the color of a cessation of arms; Chosroes now taxing the
Romans with a tribute of four annual Centenaries upon this fair pretense,
until his forty six Centenaries were paid, calling his Tax a Truce, and
showing apparently to have plotted it from the beginning of the War. And yet
still he used hostility in Lazica, as has been said. From this Taxation the
Romans had no hope ever to be freed, but saw themselves in the quality of plain
Tributaries to the Persians. Isdigunas also having gotten more wealth then ever
Ambassador did, and received the highest honors from the Emperor, together
with immense gifts, was sent home the richest man (I think) in Persia. This
only Ambassador had no Guard put upon him; himself and his followers freely
conferred, and kept company with whom they would; and in the city bought and
sold, and made any contracts, and were present at them, with all manner of
license, no Roman attending them to observe their doing, as was wont to be.

At this time also were Heats, such as none ever remembered the like, the Roses
toward the winter growing in abundance, as in the spring, with no manner of
difference, and the weather as hot as at midsummer: And the vintage being long
past, new Grapes came up. Some divined from hence at great accidents likely to
succeed; but the natural cause of it was the continuance of the Southerly
winds, longer then was ordinary, from whence came those unusual heats. If any
strange matters were signified by them, we shall know the certainty by the
Event.

CHAP. X.
DUring the said Negotiation at Constantinople for a truce; in Lazica King
Gubazes affected the Romans, because he found Chosroes to plot his death; but
the generality of the Lazians offended with the Romans oppressions; and
discontented with their Commanders, did for the most part favor the Persians,
not for love of the Persian Government, but to be rid of the other, of two ills
choosing that rather which they felt not. And Theophobius a chief man among
them, treated with Mermeroes to deliver to him the Castle of Vchimerium, who
animated him to the action with large hopes of being a Favorite of Chosroes,
and naturalized a Persian, and of getting great wealth and preferments. There
were no Forces joined of Romans and Lazians, and the Persians visited all the
Towns at their pleasure. The Emperialists lay concealed, some near the Phasis,
others in Archeopolis, and other Fortresses; and King Gubazes lay quiet upon
the tops of Mountains: So that Theophobius without any difficulty appearing,
came to the Castle and told the Imperial Garrison there, That the Roman Army
was cut in pieces, King Gubazes ruined, and Lazica wholly under the Persians,
without any hope of recovering the same for the Romans or Gubazes. Mermeroes
with seventy thousand Persians had done all this, and with great numbers of
Sabirians; And that Chosroes was now also joined suddenly with an innumerable
Army, that all Lazica would scarce contain them. With this terrible news
Theophohius so frighted the Garrison, that they besought him even by the God of
their Fathers to find some accommodation for them. He promised to procure
their safety from Chosroes; and returning immediately to Mermeroes, obtained of
him some principal Persians with Commission to repair to Vchimerium, and
having given assurances to the Garrison for their lives and Goods, to take
possession of the Castle; by the having whereof the Persians were absolute
Masters of Lazica. They subdued also Scymnia and Suania, that all places from
Muchirisis to Iberia were unaccessible to the Romans and King Gubazes. And nor
Romans nor Lazians durst meddle with the Enemy, nor come, the one from their
Fortresses, the other down from the Mountains. Mermeroes during the Winter,
repaired with timber the Walls of Coitaesis, and placed in it three thousand
Persians; he put also a competent Garrison in Vchimerium, and repaired another
Castle called Sarapalis, upon the Frontier of Lazica. Then he martcht toward
the Phasis, where he understood that the Romans and Lazians had newly made head
and were encamped. But Gubazes and the Roman Commanders at the first news of
his coming disbanded, and every man saved himself as he could. Gubazes ran up
again to the Mountains, and there with his Wife and Children made an end of
the Winter, fighting it out with poverty and the hard weather, and comforting
himself (as men use) with hopes from Constantinople. And the other chief
Lazians in their respect to their King were contented, as he, with hard winter
lodgings in the holes of Rocks. Enemy they feared none in those Mountains,
being (especially in the Winter) not to be meddled with; but famine and other
misery made them weary of their lives. Mermero^s in the mean time built
Storehouses in the Villages of Muchirisis, and furnished the same with
Victual; and by sending Fugitives to the foot of the Mountains, and promising
conditions of safety, he drew many down, supplied them plentifully with what
they most wanted, and used them as his own people. In all things else he ruled
the Country at his pleasure, and to Gubazes wrote this Letter.

Power and wisdom are the two composers of humane affairs; and they who in
power excel others, live as they list, and bring the weaker to what terms
they please, who being slaves to the stronger cure their want of power with
wisdom, and by soothing their Conquerours, hold that with comfort, whereof
their infirmity deprives them. This is generally in all Nations, and is fixed
in the nature of men. So that gentle Gubazes! if you think you can vanquish
the Persians, delay not your own good, but come to Battle, you shall find us
in what part of Lazica you please, ready to fight with you for the Country.
With us you may now try your power, who can never think afterward to oppose
the whole power of Persia. Or you may take the second course, which is to know
your self, and to adore Chosroes as your Master, King, and Conqueror; by
supplications you may be rid of your present miseries; I undertake that the
King will be gracious to you, and will give you of the best Hostages in Persia
for the perpetual assurance of your life and Kingdom. If neither of these
please, suffer the Lazians, made miserable by your bad counsels, to raise
themselves from the difficulties that press them; and see them not crushed with
an endless ruin, while you trust to the slippery hopes of Roman Succors, who
can vindicate you no more then hitherto they have done.

Gubazes was not persuaded by this Letter, but still stayed upon the Mountains;
his hatred of Chosroes not suffering him to despair in the Roman Succors.
Men's judgments ever thus tune to that which pleases their wills, admitting all
reasons of that side, without examination of the soundness of them; and
obstinately not crediting, nor weighing the arguments which cross their
desires.

About this time certain Monks came out of India, and getting access to the
Emperor, promised to effect his long desire, that the Romans should no more
buy the Metaxa, or Raw-silke from the Persians their Enemies, nor any other
Nations. For having remained long in those Countries, they had learnt the way
how the same might be had in the Roman Provinces. They told him that certain
Worms, taught by nature, did spin this Raw-silke; to bring the Worms alive,
that it was not possible, but easy to get their Bags, wherein were innumerable
Eggs, which being covered in Dung, and thereby heated, produced the Worms. The
Emperor promised them a great reward to bring their undertaking to effect; who
returned into India, brought those Eggs to Constartinaple, and being by the
means aforesaid grown to Worms, fed them with Mulbery leaves, and so caused
the making of Raw-silke in the Roman Territories.

The Winter being ended, Isdigunas came to Chosroes with the Money, and the
Treaty agreed upon, who sealed the same and took the Money; wherewith levying
agreat Army of Hunnes, he sent them to Mermeroes, resolving not to quit Lazica.
Mermeroes with these Hunnes and his Persians and Elephants marched against the
Towns of Lazica, whom the Romans encountered not, but under the command of
Martinus fortified themselves about the mouth of the Phasis; and lay quiet, in
the company of King Gubazes. Mermeroes led the Army first against a Castle
where he understood the Sister of Gubazes to be; but the Garrison; and the
strength of the place beat him from thence, and caused him to retire without
doing any hurt in that journey either to Romans or Lazians. Marching into
Abasgia, he found the narrow and rocky passage into the same possessed by a Roman
Garrison, who opposed his entrance. So that he drew back, and went against
Archaecpolis; and not prevailing there neither, he retired with his Army: which
the Romans followed, and in that fast Country intercepted many, and killed the
chief Commander of the Sabirian Hunnes. But fighting about the dead body, the
Persians forced away the Enemy, and retired to Coitaisis in Mucheirisis. Such
were the successes of the Armies in Lazica.

CHAP. XI.
IN Asrica all things proceeded fairly for the Romans, by the incredible
successes of John the General, who had drawn to his party Cutzinas, a Prince
of Numidia, then vanquished all the other Numidians in a battle, and soon after
brought Antalas and Jabdas, (who were Princes of Moors in Byzacium and
Numidia) to follow him in the quality of slaves. So that in Africa the Romans
had no Enemies, and not many subjects, whom the former wars and mutinies had
almost wasted.

In the mean time in Europe, the Gepades, who (as I said formerly) made a truce
with the Lombards, not ending their differences, resolved upon a war again,
which grew as hot as ever: The Gepades being led by Thorisin, and the Lombards
by Anauin; followed by great multitudes on both sides. They came near, but the
armies discerned not one another; when a sudden Panick fear, without any cause
appearing, frighted both the armies so, that they ran away, leaving their
Commanders with some few only behind: who neither with fair words nor threats
could stopp them. Auduin not knowing the Enemy was in the same case, sent an
Embassage to the Enemy for truce. The Ambassadors, finding the Gepades to have
had the same fortune with themselves, demanded of Thorisin, whether his people
were gone; they are fled (quoth Thorisin) none pursuing, and so are the
Lombards, said they: since you deal truly with us, we will conceal nothing from
you. And since God is pleased that these nations shall not perish, and has cast
on us both this saving fear, let us concur with that gracious sentence, and
make an end of the war. Be it so, quoth Thorisin, and so a Cessation was
concluded for two years, and in the mean time to send their Heralds, mutually
and fully to compose the differences: but not being able to end the same, they
fell again to the way of hostility. The Gepados feared that the Romans would
join with the Lombards, and therefore they sent to the Cuturgurians, Hunnes
inhabiting on this side the Lake of Maeotis, to assist them in this war against
the Lombards. They sent them twelve thousand men, commanded by Chinialus, an
experienced Soldier. But one year of the Cessation being yet to come, and the
Gepaedes having no occasion to use such a multitude, persuaded them in the
interim, as upon the by, to invade the Romans, who keeping no exact Guards upon
the Ister, into Illyrium and Thrace, the Gepaedes transported the Hunnes into
the Empire; who spoiled the country, and sacked the Towns. The Emperor hereupon
sent to the Vfurgurians, Hunnes planted beyond the Lake of Maotis, blaming
their unjust lying still, it being most unjust to neglect their friends
perishing; alleging how the Cuturgurians being their neighbors, and
receiving great pensions yearly from Constantinople, ceased not to wrong them,
but made daily inroades and spoils upon them: and they, the Cuturgurians
getting no share of the same, were careless of the Romans their ancient
friends, and saw them spoiled and ransackt by the Cuturgurians, without
vindicating them from those oppressions. The Vturgurians upon this remonstrance
of the Emperor, and of the many presents they had received from him, and upon
receipt of more money now, were won to invade the Cuturgurians country. They
passed the Tanais, accompanied with two thousand Tetraxite Goths, who dwelt
near them, and the army was commanded by Sandill, a wise and a valiant man, and
experienced in many wars. The Cuturgurians incountred them in a battle long
fought; but were routed, and many were slain. And the Vturgurians took their
wives and children captives, and went home. During the battle, some thousands
of Romans, who had been taken captives by the Cuturgurians, slipped away, and
recovered their native countries unfollowed, and getting so in that which most
concerned them, the benifit of the others victory. The Emperor sent Aratius to
Chinialus, General of the Cuturgurians, to tell him the news of his own
country, and to persuade them with money to quit the Roman territory, who
hearing what the Vturgurians had done, took the money, and came to this accord:
That without killing, or taking prisoners, or other hurt doing, they should
retire home through the Roman Subjects, as friends: That if they could continue
in their country, they should observe says to the Romans, if they could not,
they should come back, and have towns given them by the Emperor in Thrace;
and being Confederates with the Romans, should guard the provinces from all
Barbarians whatsoever. Of them already two thousand were come into Roman Land
with their wives and children, after receiving that overthrow, from the
Vturgurians; and were led by Sisinnion, who served formerly under Belisarius,
against Gelimer, and the Vandales. They became servants to the Emperor, and
were seated in Thrace. Sandill, King of the Vturgurians grew angry at this;
that he should punish the Cuturgurians of the same Race, and expel them for
wrongs done to the Romans, and that now the Emperor should entertain them to
live among the Romans, and better then ever they did. He sent Ambassadors to
the Emperor to expostulate; but without Letters: for the Hunnes know no
letters, nor Grammar, nor breed their Children in the toiles about learning.
The Ambassadors having access to the Emperor, told him as they were directed.

That their King Sandill bade them say, that he heard an old saying, when he
was a boy, how a Woolfe may change the color of his hair, but not his nature,
which will never be mended: that he knew by his own experience also, as a
rusticall Barbarian could observe it, how shepherds breed their Dogs in their
houses from little Puppies, who have the good nature to remember the kindness
of them who seed them: and the Shepherds do this, that they may have the Dogs
to chase away the Wolves, and to protect the poor sheep. That this is used
every where, no where Dogs invading the stock, nor Wolves defending it. And he
does not think that in the Emperors Dominions, (though abounding with so many
strange things) there is any varying from this constant Law of nature; which
se^ing it is universally the same, that he conceives it not good for the
Emperor to harbor this wolvish race of Cuturgurians, nor to bring in such
turbulent neighbors; nor to take them as sojourners, whom he could not bear
being strangers, and that they will shortly snew their nature to the Romans.
That the Romans shall never want Enemies to destroy them, when even those who
shall be beaten may hope to be in a better Condition; nor will their friends
hinder inreads into their country, when the vanquished shall have more respect
from them then they, after the best they can do. As themselves live now in a
barren country, while the Cuturgurians have plenty of corn, and surset in their
Wine sellars, and seed upon every dish. The wanderers are now admitted to the
Bathes, and have their Jewels, their silks and imbroyderies of gold to wear,
and yet they carried innumerable Romans into their country captives; where they
inflicted on them the basest abuses, scourging them, nay killing them without
any offense committed, and in other things acting upon them the humor and
power of Barbarian Masters; but that the Uturgurians set them at Liberty, and
restored them to their country by the sweat and ^^ile of a war. And now that
the rewards of them both are very unequal; while themseives still enjoy the
miseries of their poor country; but the Cuturgurians share a part of the
country of those very men, who by the valor of the Uturgurians were delivered
from thraldom under the other.

Thus spoke the Vturgurian Ambassadors, whom the Emperor soothed with store of
gifts, and shortly sent them home.

CHAP. XII.
IN these times was a great War between the Varnians and the Islanders of
Brittia: The Varnians are seated beyond the River Isler, and extend to the
Northern Ocean, and the Rhyne, which River divides them, and the Francks, and
the other Nations inhabiting those parts. All which Nations on both sides the
Rhyne are named Germans. Brittia lies on the Ocean Sea, distant from the
Continent but twenty five miles, opposite to the mouth of the Rhyne, and lying
between Brittany and * Thule. Brittany lies to the West of Spain five hundred
miles, Thule with this Author is Norway and part of Denmark.
but Brittia lies at the bottom of Gaul upon the Ocean, Northward to Spain
and Brittany: And Thule lies in the uttermost bounds of the Ocean, Northward.
This Island of Brittia is possessed by three populous Nations, and over each is a
King, and they are named Angli, Frisons, and Brittians. The people are so
fruitful, that yearly they transport many Families to the Francks, who plant
them in desert Countries, and upon that ground pretend an interest to the
Island; and lately in an Embassage to the Emperor Justinian, sent some Angli
in company, as if the Island were theirs. Over the Varnians one Hermegis^lus
lately reigned, who took to Wife a Sister of Theodebert King of the Francks,
his former Wife being dead; by whom he had a Son named Radisis, betroathed to
the Sister of the King of the Angli in Brittia: This Hermegliscus riding to
take the avre, a Raven from a tree croaked at him; he told his Noble men
attending him, that the Bird in her language did foretell his death to be
within forty days after: And I (quoth he) for your peace and security made an
alliance with the Francks by mine own Wife, and contracted a Brittian Lady to
my Son: But now being suddenly to dye without Issue from my now Wife, and my
Son being yet without his Bride, let me communicate my thoughts to you, and
when I am dead, if you like my advise, put it in execution. I hold it more
advantageous for you, to have alliance with the Francks then with the
Brittians; who being Islanders, cannot join with you in time, nor easily:
whereas nothing severs the Francks, but the Rhyne, from you. And being so near
and so powerful, they are at hand both to help and hurt you; and hurt they
will, if this alliance restrain them not: An overgrowne neighbor proves
heavy, and apt to do wrong, and the means of a War are easy against men at
the next door. Quit therefore that betroathed Islander, and the Money she
has received restore, according to the Law of Nations, for a reparation of the
refusal of her: and let my Son Radisis marry his Mother-in-law, which our
Laws permit.

Hermegisclus gave this advise, and at the fortieth day dyed; and his Son
taking the Kingdom, renounced his betroathed Spouse by the persuasion of his
Nobles, and took his Mother-in-law to Wife. The contracted Lady could not
brook the scorn done her, but was eager to revenge it. For so tender of their
honor are the Barbarians of those parts, that after the name only of a
marriage without consummation, if the woman be refused, she thinks her self
professed a Strumpet. First she sent Messengers to demand the reason of this
rejection, seeing he could not charge her with incontinence, nor any other
offense; but that way prevailing nothing, with a manly courage she resolved
upon a War: She got four hundred Ships and an hundred thousand men, whom her
self led, with one of her Brothers to assist her. The Brittians are the
bravest Infantry we know, but so unexercised in Horsemanship, that they know
not what a Horse is, nor ever saw in Brittia the Picture of any, where never
any was bred.

When upon Ambassages they come abroad among the Romans, or Francks, and are
put to necessity of riding, men lift them up, and set them upon their Horses;
and so take them down again when they are to alight. The Varaians also are
all Footmen. Aboard the aforesaid Fleet were none but rowers, for the Brittians
have no Sails: Being landed upon the Continent, the Virgin-Generall encamped
at the mouth of the Rhyne, where staying her self, she sent out her Brother
against the Enemy: He finding the Varnians near the Sea shore encamped, had a
battle with them and defeated them, where many fell, and the rest with their
King fled, and were followed by the Angles as far as footmen could; who
retyring to the Camp, were by the Lady chid, and especially her Brother, for
having nothing worthy such an Army, seeing he brought not Radisis to her alive.
She selected then her best men, and charged them to bring the man to her: who
in the end found him concealed in a Wood, and brought him bound to the Lady. He
stood before her trembling, expecting some cruel death: But she only
reproaching to him the unjust affront he had done her, asked him why he would
neglect his Vow, and bed another Woman, his own Spouse not having committed
whoredom. He excused all upon the injunctions of a Father, and the importunity
of his Nobles, mingling his apology with supplications, and imputing the crime
to necessity, promising now, if it were her pleasure, to live with her, and by
his future services to cure his former injury. The Lady was pleased, and
Radisis loosed from his bonds was vouchsafed all manner of courtesy: And
immediately he sent home the Sister of Theodebert, and married this Brittian
Lady,

In Brittia also is a Wall dividing a great part of the Island in two; the
reason of it is, because to the Eastward is good air according to the seasons,
and many civil Inhabitants, and they have Corn and Fruit Trees in abundance,
and are well stored with waters. But to the Westward all is so contrary, that a
man cannot live there half an hour, the Country being possessed with Adders
and Snakes, and all sorts of venomous creatures. The natives affirm, that so
soon as a man passes to the other side of the Wall, he instantly falls dead
with the pestilentiall air; and the like happens to Beasts.

In this description I am to mention a Story, or rather a Fable; I cannot think
it true, though many men affirm to have seen it and been actors in it, neither
must I absolutely reject it, least professing to write of the particularities
of this Island, I be thought ignorant of the things done in it. They report
that to this part of the Island are transported the Souls of the departed, by
a means, which though I have heard in very good earnest related, yet I
conceive that the first rumor of it sprung from some dreaming heads. Along the
Ocean shore, over against Brittia, are many Villages, inhabited by Fishermen,
Husbandmen, and Boatmen, who traffic in the Island; subjects they are to the
Francks, but pay no Tribute, the exemption from which is granted unto them for
a service which I will now relate. They have the employment of conducting
Souls departed imposed on them by turns; when any man's turn comes, they go
home to bed toward night, expecting their fellow conductor; and at midnight
they find the door opened, and hear a softly voice calling them to the
business: Instantly they rise, and go down to the Seaside, finding themselves
constrained to go on, but they perceive not by whom: Boats they find ready,
with no men in them, and aboard they go and sit to their Oars. They perceive
the Boats loaded with Passengers even to the Deck; and the place of their Oars
not an inch from the water: They see nothing, but after an hours rowing, come
a Land in Brittia, whereas in their own Boats they have much ado to pass
over in a day and a night, having no Sails, but rowing only. They instantly
land their Fare, and are gone away with their Boats suddenly grown light, and
swimming with the current, and having all save the Keele above water: They see
no men leaveing the Boat, but they hear a voice, relating to some, who it
seems stays there for them, the names of the Passengers, with their Titles,
and additions of what Fathers they were; and (if women) of what Husbands. But
to return to my History, and to the Gothic War, having already spoken of the
successes of other Provinces.

CHAP. XIII.
THE Emperor, as I said before, had sent for Belisarius home, where he held
him in honor, upon the death of Germanus: yet he would not send him into
Italy; and though he were General of the East, he made him Commander of the
Guards of his body, and kept him at Constantinople: And Belisarius was the
chief of all the Romans in dignity; some indeed had the priority of being made
Patricians and Consulls before him but yet they yielded the precedence to him,
and were ashamed to make use of the Law, and to assume the right, which that
gave them, against so eminent a virtue; and the Emperor took it well of them.
But John, Sisters son of Vitalianns, past that Winter in Salonae, whom the
Roman Commanders in Italy expecting daily, forbear any action. And the Winter
ended, and the sixteenth year of this War wrirten by Procopius.

The next year John resolving to lead the Army from Salonae against Totilas,
In^ipit Annus 17 bell Goth man 25 Justice Anno dom. 551.
the Emperor commanded him to stay the coming of Narses the Eunuch, whom he
had made his absolute General in this war. The reason of this determination
of the Emperor was not known; for who can declare the counsels of his heart
without his consent? But men did conjecture that his Majesty did consider how
the rest of the Commanders would grudge to have their power lessened, and to be
made subordinate to John; whereupon either by contrary opinions, or through
envy, they might purposely prejudice his affairs. I heard also this story at
my former being at Rome from one of the Senators, That in the Reign of
Atalaricus, a heard of Cattle about evening came into Rome, and past through
the Market place, called Forum pacis, where stood the ancient Temple of peace,
and was thunder-strucken. Over against this Market place stands an ancient
Conduit, and upon it a brazen Bullock, the work of Phidias the Athenian, or of
Lysippus; there being in the same place many Statues of their making, and upon
one the name of Phidias is engraven. There is here also the Bullock made by
Myron: The ancient Romans being most studious to make all the fairest pieces of
Greece the ornaments of Rome. But the Senator told me, that an Ox of this
Heard was left behind the rest, and got up to the Conduit, and stood above by
the brazen Bullock; and that a Tulcan passing by, a plain country fellow in
appearance, but a pretended Soothsayer (as all the Tuscan are) said, That one
day an Eunuch should depose the Prince of Rome. The Tuscan and his Divination
was then laughed at, as all predictions are, before they be justified by the
event, seeming till then ridiculous and fabulous: But now all men admire that
his interpretation, being convinced by the event. So that Narses was chosen
General against Totilas, either the Emperor wisely foreseeing the success,
or fortune determining the same: And Narses with a Gallant Army, and store of
Treasure was dispatched. He stayed a while in Thrace at Phillippopolis. his way
being stopped by an army of Hunnes, who drove and carried all away without
opposition; but they being gone some toward Thessalonica, some toward
Constantinaple, he marched on, being hardly disengaged from them.

While John thus staid for Narses at S^ilonae and Narses entangled with those
Hunns marched slowly: T^tilas looking for Narses coming, placed in Rome some of
the Senators, confined in Campania, and other Romans, Commanding them to guard
the City, and professing to repent for what he had done to it. He had burnt the
most part of it, especially beyond the Tiber; and these men being grown little
better then Slaves, and stripped of all they had, were so unable to vindicate the
public, that they could not get every man his ownpeculiar right: and yet are
the Romans the best patriots in the world, studying to recover from all parts,
what belongs to their City, and to save all the ancient Ornaments of Rome from
perishing. During so long a subjection to Barbarians, how did they preserve
their public buildings and ornaments of their City! Even the orginall
monuments of their race do yet last, the sufficiency of those ancient workmen
holding out against the ruins of time, and the negligence of men Among which
there yet stands a miraculous spectacle, which my self have seen; the ship of
Aenaeas the founder of their City: it is for one row of oars only, and of a
huge length, being 120 foot long, and 25. broad. It is so high only, as that
men may row in it. The Timbers in it are not mortessed into one another, nor
fastened by iron; but are every one of a piece, such as were never heard of, and
are only found in this ship, that we can learn. For the keele being all one
piece, reaches from the stern to the foreship, and bows by little and little
into a convenient crookedness, then strangely turns straight again, and most
aptly in proportion. The ribs also of the ship reach from side to side,
crooking downwards, and bowing so handsomely, that one would think the hollow
bulk of the Ship to be made round and turned with instruments; either nature
providing such a crookedness in the Timber for the present use, or else those
uneven ribs were fitted by men's hands, or Engines. Every planck also reaches
from the stern to the foreship, being all of a piece, and have only spikes of
iron to fasten them to the ships ribs, and to make up her sides. Thus does
this ship affoard a sight beyond expression; strange workman-ships naturally
rising above discourse, and as they subdue common things by thenew invention,
so over-mastring evenspeech it self. And the ship is strong and lusty yet, and
sound all through, none of the Timbers having any rottenness appearing; as if
the ship-wright (whatsoever he were) had lately built it.

Totilas also manned 300 Galleys with Goths, whom he commanded to pillage, and
spoil the coast of Greece. This fleet hurt nothing, till it came to Corcyra,
anciently the country of the Phaeacians; being the only inhabited Island in
this passage from the straits of Scylla. Having been often upon that Sea, I was
curious where the Island of Calypso was: I found only three small islands, some
thirty seven miles from Phaeacia, (now Corcyra) called Othonae, from whence one
may imagine Ulysses to have past to Corcyra, being no farther off, either in a
boat made of a sudden, or otherwise; this is but my conjecture only. It is
hard to discourse exactly of things so ancient: Time changes the names of
places, and the opinion formerly held of them. Upon the Sea shore in Corcyra
stands the model of a ship made of white stone, compounded of many several
stones, which some suppose to be the model of that which transported Ulysses
into Ithaca, after his entertainment with the Phaeacians. Neptune turned the
ship worch carried home Ulisses into a rock, so that it must be of on pu^^.
But * the being not of one stone, and the Letters engraven upon it, proclaim
the same to have been set there by some Merchant in ancient time, and dedicated
to Jupiter Casius; the town also where this ship stands being yet called
Cas^^pe. In Euboea at Geraestum, there is also such a model of a ship,
dedicated by Agamemnon to Diana, to please her with this also, as he had, by
the sacrifice of his Daughter Iphigenia, obtained of her a passage for the
Grecian army to Troy. Which is testisied by Letters engraven upon it either
then or afterward; the most of which time has defaced, but at the beginning of
the verses, they appear thus.

-- (...)
(...),
(...).
Here Agamemnon placed this black-pitcht Bark,
Of the Greeks Army now at Sea a Mark.
And the Inscription thus, (...).
(...) --
Tenichus built
This to Diana Bolosia. --


For so anciently they called Eileithuia, or Lucina; terming the Throws and
pangs of Childbirth, (...). But I return from whence I digressed.

CHAP. XIV.
THE Goths with their fleet came to Corcyra, and forraged the Island, and the
Islands also of Syntae. They landed also upon the main land of Epirus, and
pillaged the towns about Dodona and Nicopolis it self, and Anchialus, where
Anchises, the Father of Aenaeas sailing from Troy dyed, and gave the name to
the Town. They took upon the coast also many Greek ships, and some
transporting Provisions to Narses Army. Totilas likewise sent an army into
Picenia to take Ancona, commanded by Skipuar, and Giblas and Gundulse, (called
by some Indulfe) formerly of the lifeguard to Belisarius. He gave them forty
seven galleys to block up the Castle by sea also. The Seige lasting long, and
the besieged wanting victual, Valerianus being at Ravenna, and unable alone to
succor it, wrote this Letter to John, Vitalianus his Sisters Son, at Salonae.

Ancona you know is only left us within the Jonian Gulf, if it be left us: it
is so sharply besieged, that I fear our succors will come too late, and we
shall use our endeavor after our opportunity. I forbear to write more; the
necessity of the besieged claims all our time, and their danger permits not a
long Epistle, requiring succor swifter then speech.

John, though the Emperor had forbidden him to stir, adventured to go,
conceiving the necessity, whereinto fortune had cast them, to dispense with the
Emperors instructions: He chose his best soldiers, and put them aboard forty
Galleys, swift of Sail, and well built for a Sea fight; and having furnished
them with all necessaries, came with them before Ancona. Whether soon after
came Valerianus with twelve ships: Upon conference together they rose from
thence, and Anchored at a place called Senogallia, not far from Ancona. The
Goths General also manned forty seven ships with their choice men, leaving the
rest to block up the Castle: and sailed against the Romans. Skipuar commanded
the men left behind, and Giblas and Gundulfe those in the Ships. The Fleets
being near, each drew their ships as close together as might be and exhorted
their men. John and Valerianus spoke thus.

Think not fellow Soldiers! that you are to fight now only for the Castle of
Ancona, and the Romans in it; but that the main of the war depends upon this
battle; and that the conclusion of our fortune is to be drawn in the same Lot
with it. Consider, how the chief moment of war consists in the expenses of it,
and that they who want supplies, are of necessity to be beaten in the End.
Valor and hunger cannot dwell long together, nature not enduring to pine with
famine, and to fight bravely too: And other fortress we have none between
Otranto and Ravenna, where we can lay in any provisions for our selves or our
Horses. And the Enemy being Master of the Country we have no place our friend,
from whence to furnish any small proportion of victual. In Ancona is our only
hope, where such as come from the opposite land may put in and ride safely. So
that if we win this battle, and thereby assure Ancona, we may hope well of all
the rest of this war; but if we be defeated, I will not speak any thing that is
harsh, God grant unto the Romans the perpetual Dominion of Italy. And consider
too, that if you speed ill now, you cannot so much as run away; the Enemy
possessing all the land, and being also absolute master of the Sea. Our only
hope of living now is in our arms, and depends upon our actions in this fight.
Fight bravely therefore, having this in your minds, that if you now be beaten,
it will be your last beating; if you conquer, you will be rancked with honor
among the most happy.

Thus John and Valerianus; and the Goths Commander spoke thus. These wretched
men expulsed out of Italy, and long hid in some corners of the Sea and Land,
seeing now they dare to sight with us again; it is our parts to check their
unadvised presumption, least it grow higher being let alone. Folly, not
restrained in the beginning, proceeds to endless daring, and at last ruins
those it incounters. Show them then quickly, that they are Greeks, and
naturally cowards, and now grown desperate with being beaten. Take heed least
they prosper upon this Experiment; Cowardice despised, becomes bold, and
fool-hardinesse in the end may grow to be incapable of fear. And if you do
valiantly, think not that they can stand long. A spirit not measured out
proportionably to the power of him that uses it, commonly rises before the
business; but when the battle is begun, it suckes. Remember therefore the
often trials this Enemy has made of your valor; and from their then success,
argue, that they are not now suddenly become better men; but have rashly
undertaken as then, and will go off with the like fortune.

After these exhortations, the battle began, and was stoutly sought, and
something like a land fight. They stood with all their ships in front against
each other; and plied their Bows. The forwardest grapled, and fought from the
decks with Javelin and sword, as in a field. But the Goths unexperienced in
Sea-sights maintained the encounter with much disorder. Some stood aloof,
whereby the Romans set on them single: Some came on so thick, that they fell,
foul with their fellows for want of Room. Their ships stood jumbled together
like so many baskets that they could neither shoot at the Enemy, nor manage
their Javelins nor swords; but were perpetually employed in getting clear of
one another, with loud clamours, and confused pushing off with their long
poles; intangling their front for want of room, and then getting aloof, and
both to their own mischeise: their cries and hollowings were not against the
Enemy, but to their own men to keep off; and thus puzzelling one another, they
were the chiefest cause of the Enemies victory. Who in their close fights did
valiantly, and in their Sea fights skillfully; keeping their ships in front,
not too far asunder, nor more close then was convenient; And still joining and
severing in good proportion, when they saw an Enemies ship scattered, they
struck at her, and with ease sunck her; and where they saw the Enemy in
confusion, thither they sent clouds of arrows; then seeing them wearied with
the toil of their disorder, they fell on them and cut them in pieces. The
Goths desponding, did neither consider their cross fortune, nor their own
Errors; and being not able either to use their ships, nor to fight from their
decks they left fighting and fell to a dangerous quietness, committing
themselves to fortune; and then betook themselves to a shameful and disorderly
retreat, having no remembrance either of resisting, or of handesomly flying;
but being scattered among their Enemies, they stood amazed. Eleven ships got
away; the rest the Romans took, or sunck with the men in them. Giblas was taken
Prisoner; but Gundulse escaped in the eleven ships, and the men being landed,
he set them on fire, that they might not come into the Enemies hands. Then they
went a foot to Ancona, where relating the accident to their companions, they
all retired from thence, leaving their camp for the Romans, and they ran
tumultuously into Auximum. The Romans came to the Goths camp before Ancona, and
took it, then put provisions into the Castle, and sailed away, Valerianus to
Ravenna, and John to Salonae. This overthrow much abated the power of Totilas.

In Sicily at the same time thus it was. Liberius was sent for home to
Constantin^ple, and Artabanes by the Emperor was made sole Commander of the
army in Sicily; Who took in all the Castles from the few Goths left in the
Island, after some sieges and overthrowes given them. The Goths were terrified
therewith, and with the late defeat at Sea, and their hearts with these losses
were so dejected, that if any succors should come to the Romans, they had no
thought of subsisting, or of keeping their footing in Italy; nor could they
hope to obtain any thing from the Emperor. For Totilas had sent many
Ambassadors to the Emperor, showing how the Francks had seized upon a great
share of Italy, and how the rest was become wast: That the Goths should quit to
him Sicily and Dalmatia, which only remained unspoyled; and should pay tribute
for the wasted Lands in Italy, and serve the Emperor against all the World,
and in other things be obedient to him. But the Emperor would take no notice
of these overtures, but still sent away the Ambassadors, being distasted at
the very name of Goths, and purposing to chase them out of the Roman Empire.

CHAP. XV.
NOT long before dyed Theodebert King of the Francks, having unjustly made
tributary some Towns in Liguria, and the Cottian Alps, and a great part of
Venetia: The Francks thus getting without blows, what the two Antagonists were
busily fighting for. In Venetia the Goths had little; the Sea-townes the Romans
had, and the Francks seized upon the rest, while neither the Goths nor Romans
had leisure to make new Enemies. The Goths also came to this agreement with the
Francks; that during the War with the Emperor, both should hold what they had,
and forbear hostility. If Totilas conquer, that then the said acquisitions of
the Francks be disposed, as should be agreed between the parties. But in the
Kingdom of Theodebert succeeded Theudibald his Son, to whom the Emperor sent
Leontius a Senator, and Son-in-law to Athanasius, his Ambassador, to persuade
a League against Totilas, and to demand the Towns in Italy, unjustly held by
Theodebert, and surprised during the Truce. The Ambassador spoke thus to
Theudibald. Others, Sir, (it may be) have had Accidents which they expected
not, but no men (I think) such as the Romans have had from you. The Emperor
entered not into this War, nay not into any expostulation with the Goths,
before the Francks had received great sums of money of him, and had promised
aides, and the conjunction of their Forces: Which Accord they have not only
not performed, but have done us injuries, which none could imagine. Your Father
Theodebert has intruded into a Province by the Emperor, acquired with much
toil and hazard, and with the Francks consent. But I come not to chide, nor
complain, but to demand only, and therewithal to give you this advise; to
establish the prosperity you have, and to let the Romans have that which is
theirs. Some small thing often times unjustly gotten, is the occasion of losing
great and powerful acquisitions; stable happiness, and injustice never
meeting in one point. I advise you likewise to join in this War, according to
your Fathers engagement to the Emperor. Nothing becomes good Sons better,
then to rectify their Fathers erroneous Proceedings, and to ratify what they
have well done.

The wish of a wise man is, that his Son may emulate his virtuous Actions, and
if he have done any thing amiss, he wishes another may rather imitate it, then
his Son. Indeed you should not have needed invitation to this War against the
Goths, originally your Enemies, and false to you of old, and ever in War with
you, without truce or quarter. Now for fear of us they fawn upon you, but
being rid of us, they will soon show their intentions. Wicked men change not
their Natures with their Fortunes; in adversities indeed they hide them,
especially when they have need of a Neighbor. Consider this, and renew your
Amity with the Emperor, and take a revenge against your ancient Enemies.
Theudibald answered this Speech in this manner.

It is not now just in you, to demand our assistance against the Goths, now in
Amity with us; If we prove unsure to them, we shall not be trusty to you. A bad
disposition to Friends being once discovered, puts a man for fear out of the
right way. Concerning the Towns you mention, my Father Theodebert was no
oppressor of his Neighbors, nor intruder: And it appears so, for I am not
rich; And he took not the Towns from the Emperor, but got them fairly from
Totilas, the then owner of them, which should please the Emperor, to see one
who wronged him, disseised by another, and thereby justly punished, unless
because he would have them himself, and cannot get them, he will envy him
that can. But let us refer the examination of these things to Arbitrators: If
it shall appear that my Father has taken any thing unjustly from the Romans,
there is reason we should give satisfaction: And we will shortly send our
Ambassadors to Constantinople, touching the same. With this he dismissed
Leontius, and sent Leudard a Franck his Ambassador to Justinian, with three
others; who at Constantinople effected what they came about.

Totilas desired to get the Islands belonging to Africa, and he sent an Army to
Corsica, and Sardinia, which he made tributary to him. John the General of
Africa, sent presently to Sardinia some Forces, who besieged the City of
Carnalis; blocking it up only but not able to assault it, having a very
sufficient Garrison of Goths within, which sallied suddenly, and routed the
Romans; who having lost many, ran to their Ships, and returned to Carthage,
where they wintered, purposing in the Spring to renew the Voyage with greater
preparations. There grows an Herb in this Island of Sardinia, which being
tasted, puts men into fatal Convulsions, wherein they seem to laugh, and
quickly dye of it; whence is called the Sardonian laughter. Corsica was
anciently named Cyrnus, and in it, as there is a Generation of Dwarfes, so
there are races of horses not much bigger then sheep.

A mighty troup at that time of Slavonians, fell upon Illyrium, committing
mischeifs not to be expressed. Justinian sent against them an army commanded by
the Sons of Germanus, and others. Who being much fewer then the Enemy, durst
not fight; but infested their Rear, and cut off some, and sent of them some
prisoners to the Emperor. These Barbarians did infinite hurt, long pillaging
the Country, and strewing the high ways with dead bodies, and then went home
with innumerable prisoners, and all their booty, none incountring them. The
Romans could not infest them in their passage over the Ister, because the
Gaepedes transported them, and had for every head a gold stater for their fare:
This troubled the Emperor, having no means to restrain their passage over the
River Ister, to spoil the Empire, nor their sudden retreat, which made him
resolve to make a League with the Gaepedes who were then again quarrelling with
the Lombards, and fearing the power of the Romans. (who had lately sworn a
league with the Lombards) they endeavored to be admitted friends and
Auxiliaries. They sent Ambassadors accordingly, and the Emperor swore a league
with them also, and upon the demand of the Ambassadors, twelve Senatots swear
it likewise. Shortly after, the Emperor sent an army to aid the Lombards
against the Gaepedes, whom he charged since the League, to have transported
Slavonians over the River Ister against the Romans. The Army was commanded by
Iustine and Justinian the Sons of Germanus, and Aratius and Swartwall, formerly
made Prince of the Herulians by the Emperor, but banished (as I said before) by
the Herulians of Thule, and returning to Constantinople made General of the
Cohorts there. There was likewise Amalafridas a Goth, the Daughters Son of
Amalafridas (who was Sister to Theoderick) by Hermenifrid Prince of the
Thuringians, who being brought to Constantinople by Belisarius with Vitigis,
the Emperor made him Commander of Roman troops, and betrothed his Sister to
Auduin Prince of the Lombards. Of the aforesaid army only, that Amalafridas
with his troops, came to the Lombards, the rest by the Emperors direction
staid about the City of Vlpiana, in Illyrium, where was a mutiny among the
inhabitants about things, wherein Christians contend among themselves, as shall
be set down in my relations concerning the same. The Lombards with Amalafridas
invaded the Gaepedes, and in a battle defeated them, and killed many: And
Auduin their King sent the good news to the Emperor of his victory; but
complained of the not coming up of the Emperors army according to the League;
so great numbers of Lombards having been so lately sent by him to aid Narses
against Totilas.

CHAP. XVI.
GReat Earthquakes at that time happened in Boeotia; and Achaia, and other
parts of Greece, about the Gulf of Crisaeum, overthrowing many Cities, as
Chaeronea, Corone, Patra, and Naupactus. Many men perished, and in many places,
by the renting of the Earth, were made bottomless holes; some whereof closed
again afterward, some continue still so, that the people are to compass much
Ground to come to one another. The arm of the Sea between Thessaly and
Boeotia, flowed up into the land about the City of Echinae, and Scarphia in
Boeotia, and overwhelmed all the Towns there: The waters lay long, and men went
into the Island lying upon that arm of the Sea on dry land; while the Sea
leaving her ancient current covered the firm land even to the mountains.
Afterward it returned to the channels again, leaving the fishes upon the land;
a strange and prodigious accident; For some tried to sees and eat them; but no
sooner heated, but they turned to a slymy matter, extremely putrified. In one
town, where the greatest breach was, the people being assembled at a great
festival, more men perished then in all Greece beside.

But in Italy, the Crotonians, and the Garrison commanded by Palladius, being
sharply besieged by the Goths, and wanting food, had sent to Artabanes in
Sicily, protesting, if they were not instantly succored, to yield the Town and
themselves too. But no succor was sent; and so ended the winter, and the
seventeenth year of this war, written by Procopius.

The Emperor commanded the Garrison at Thermopylae, in Greece, Incipit Annus
18. Bell. Goth. in an. 26. Justiniani. Et An. Dom. 552.
to sail for Italy and to relieve Crotona. Who getting a fair wind, came
unexpected into the Haven of Crotona. The Goths upon sight of the fleet rose
from their siege in much fear and tumult, and fled some by sea to Tarentum,
others ran from their trenches up to the mountain of Scyllaeum. These things
much dejected the Goths: And Ragnaris Commander of the Garrison in Tarentum,
and Morras of that in Archerontia, two principal Goths, with their Soldiers
assent, had a treaty with Bacurius, the Son of Peranius, Commander of the
Romans in Otranto, for receiving assurances from the Emperor, and thereupon to
deliver up the towns in their Guard: the Capitulation Bacurius took with him
to Constantinople. And now Narses marched from Salonae against Totilas, with a
very gallant army; having received much treasure from the Emperor to levy and
furnish the same, and above al to pay to the Soldiers in Italy their arreares,
which were grown great, being due for many years. He was with this money also to
invite the revolted, to return again from the Goths to the Romans. The Emperor
in the beginning of this war, made it very carelessly, but now his preparations
were very great; for Narses seeing him eager to have him to lead the army into
Italy, did like a brave General, protesting herein not to serve the Emperors
commands, unless he might have competent forces; and by this resolution, he
procured money, men, and arms, befitting the Roman Empire. Then with much
alacrity he made up gallant companies out of the Constantinopolitan Guards, and
Garrisons of Thrace,, and many he raised in Illyrium. With him went John with
his own Troops, and those left him by Germanus his Father in Law. Auduin also,
prince of the Lombards, in accomplishment of the league, and for great sums
given him by the Emperor, sent five and twenty hundred selected men for
auxlliaries, accompanied with a retinue of above three thousand men. Narses had
also three thousand Herulians, all horsemen, commanded by Philimuth and others,
and he had many Hunnes. Dagistthaeus also was with him with his troops, being
discharged of his imprisonment for the same purpose. Cabades went also with
many Persian fugitives, who was the Son of Zames, and Grandchild of King
Cabades, and long ago came into the Empire; having by the practice of
Chanaranges escaped his uncle Chosroes; and a young Gepaede very valiant, named
Asbadas, with four hundred Gepaedes, good Soldiers. And Aruth an Herulian,
from a child bred among the Romans, and married to the widow of Mauricius the
Son of Mundus, a gallant man, and accompanied with many old Soldiers of his
Nation; John Phagas also commanding many Romans, good Soldiers. Narses was a
man liberal, and most forward in releiving men in want; using his disposition
the more easily, by reason of his great power with the Emperor, so that he had
obliged many, both commanders and common Soldiers; who all upon his being now
General were eager to serve under him, both in acknowledgement of former
favors, and in expectation of great advancements by him. Above all, the
Herulians, and other Barbarians loved him, having done them many benefits.
Being come upon the Confines of Venetia, he sent to the Captains of the
Francks, to demand passage as for friends. They refused it, and protested to
hinder it, both for the Francks good, and for their amity with the Goths,
pretending also a poor excuse; because Narses had with him Lombards, their
greatest Enemies. Narses was troubled at it; but was told by some Italians,
that if the Francks gave him passage, he could not from thence get to Ravenna,
nor further possibly then to Verona. For Totilas had placed in Verona a choice
number of Goths under Teias, a most valiant General, to lie in the Romans way.
This Tejas had stopped up all the passages with works, and made in some places
with much art and labor thickets, in others, ditches, deep holes, and bogs,
and overflowed the Grounds; and himself lay with his army ready to fight with
the Roman army attempting to force their way. This was done by Totilas
direction, knowing how the Romans would not be able to pass along the
Seacoast, by so many great Rivers mouths, which made the shore unpassable; and
how they had not ships enough to transport the whole army at once over the
Gulf, and coming but few at once, that he might easily hinder their landing.
Narses being herewith much perplexed, John, who knew those parts exactly,
advised him to march with the army by the Seashore, the people there being
their subjects; and to be attended with some ships, and many boats, with which
boats they might make a bridge over the currents of those rivers, and so make
their passages: Narses followed this advise, and got to Ravenna with his whole
army.

CHAP. XVII.
DUring the wars, came to Constantinople Ildigisall, a Lombard. The Kingdom of
the Lombards of right belonged to him, but Anduin forced it from him, whereupon
he fled his country. Justinian entertained him with favor, and made him
Captain of one of the Cohorts, called Scholae, which guard the Palace. He had
three hundred followers his country men, who had been bred sometime with him in
Thrace. Auduin demanded him of the Emperor, as a reward due to his freindship,
and late confederacy; but the Emperor would not deliver him to him. This
Ildigisall afterward grew discontented at the meanness of his entertainments;
which Goar perceived, a Goth, taken in Dalmatia, in the wars of Vitigis, and
sent Prisoner to Dalmatia, being a man proud and valiant, and repining at his
condition, and upon the late revolt of the Goths in Italy, he was discovered to
plot against the Roman State. This Goar persuaded Ildigisall to run from
Constantinople, promising to accompany him; and so with some few with them they
came to Apri, a City in Thrace, joined with some Lombards they found there, and
taking many Horses from the Emperors Horse-pastures in Thrace, they went
forward. The Emperor commanded the Companies in Thrace and Illyrium to oppose
these Fugitives. First they were fought with by Cuturgurian Hunnes, lately
planted in Thrace by the Emperor (as has been said) But they beat these
Hunnes and killed many, and then past through Thrace with their Troops, none
disturbing them. In Illyrium they found an Army levied against them, commanded
by Aratius, Recithangus, Leonianus, Arimuth, and others: Who having rode all
day, resolved in the evening to lodge in a woody ground, and taking with them
each three or four Soldiers, went to drink of the River, being extremely
thirsty. Ildigisall and Goar, understanding of their being there by their
Scouts, sell suddenly upon them, and killed them all; and thenceforward marched
on at their ease, the Soldiers perplexed, and without Commanders ryding back
again. They went then to the Gepaedes: from the Gepaedes was also fled one
Vstrigoth, the only Son of Elimund late King of the Gepaedes, who being
suppressed by Thorisin, and but a Boy, fled to the Lombards: but the Lombards,
Gepaedes, and the Emperor making peace, and swearing a perpetual amity, both
the Emperor and Auduin, Prince of the Lombards, sent to Thorisin to deliver to
them their common Enemy Ildigisall, requiring thus, for an expression of their
new made amity, the betraying of a poor man come for refuge. Thorisin demanded
herein the opinion of the principal Gepaedes; who plainly disadvised it,
protesting to choose rather to perish with their Wives and Children, then to be
guilty of so foul an impiety. The Prince being unable to do it without the
consent of his Subjects; and unwilling to revive the War with the Romans and
Lombards, sent to Auduin, and demanded of him Vstrigoth, the Son of Elimund,
provoking him to a like fault, and to betray servant for servant, that his own
loathnesse in the like absurdity might check his request to another. But Auduin
consented, and they both resolved upon this unjust act, and not daring to
acquaint their Subjects with it publicly, each treacherously killed his
Enemy; I forbear to tell the manner, the reports differing, as happens in all
secret actions. And this was the fortune of Ildigisall and Vstrigoth.

But in Ravenna, Valerianus and Justinus the Generals, and the remainder of
the Roman Army joined with Narses. Nine days after Vsdrilas a Goth, Commander
of the Garrison at Ariminum, wrote this Letter to Valerianus:

After you had filled the World with rumors, and possessed Italy with
phantasmes, thinking to scare away the Goths with your bigg looks; now you have
enclosed your selves in Ravenna, that an Enemy may not see your faint hearts,
which you cover with the same brave countenance, and lie with your mingled
multitude of Barbarians upon a Country, wherein you have no right: For shame
rise from thence and fight, show your selves; keep us not thus under a tedious
expectation: We attend you like spectators in a Theater to see a sight.

Narses laughed at the Letter, and the vanity of the Goths, and forthwith began
his journey, leaving Justinus in Ravenna with a Garrison. At Ariminum he found
the Bridge newly taken up by the Goths, and his passage not easy; by the
Bridge it self was never any passage but by one man a breast, unarmed and a
foot, with much ado, though none disturbed; but now numbers opposing, it was
not possible to ferry over. Narses came to the place where the Bridge had been,
and studied upon some expedient in this difficulty. Thither came also Vsdrilas
with some Horse, to observe the Romans proceeding. A Soldier of Narses let
fly an Arrow amongst them, and killed a Horseman; whereat Vsdrilas removed in
some haste, and put himself within the Town, and immediately at another Gate
sallyed with others of his best men; thinking to take Narses suddenly, and to
cut him in pieces, being now searching in another part of the River for a
passage. But some Herulians by accident encountered, and killed him; and a Roman
knowing him, brought his head to Narses; which filled them with courage, to see
God fight for them, and the Goths having a plot upon their General, to lose
their own Commander suddenly, not by any humane design or providence. But
Narses meddled not with Ariminum, though Vsdrilas were slain, nor with any
other Enemy-towne, that he might not retard his maine design, nor distract it
by any by-businesse. And the Enemy in Ariminum, having lost their Commander,
gave no impediment to him in the making a Bridge, by which he past the River at
his ease. He left Via Flaminia, and took the left hand way; for the Enemy had
taken the strong Rock of Petra pertusa, described by me before, and all other
pieces upon Via Flaminia, which made it unpassable for the Romans; and
therefore he left the shorter, and went the quieter way.

CHAP. XVIII.
TOTILAS, hearing what had happened in Venetia, stayed for the Army with Teias
about Rome. Who being all come up save two thousand Horse, without staying
longer for them, he martcht away with the rest, purposing to fight with the
Romans at his best convenience. In his way, hearing the news of Vsdrilas, and
