how the Enemy was past the River at Ariminum, he marched through Tuscany to the
Appennine, and in a Village there called Tagi^^ encamped. Afterward came
Narses, and sat down upon the Apennine also, in an even piece of ground,
twelve miles and a half from the Enemy. About the place were many little round
Hills, being the Tombs of the Gauls slain by Camillus and the Romans, and
they are to this day called Busta Gallorum; Busta in Latin being the
remainders and relics of a funeral Pile. Narses sent some unto Totilas to
desire him to to lay aside Hostility, and to entertain at last peaceable
counsels, representing how impossible it was for him, having under him but few
men, and them not held together by any Law, to contend long with the whole
Roman Empire. And he directed his Ambassadors, if they saw Totilas resolved
upon War, to bid him instantly appoint a day for a pitched Battle. They did
acccordingly, and Totilas with a brave countenance told them, that by any means
they must have War. Noble Sir, then quoth they, what time appoint you for the
Battle? Eight days hence, quoth he, we will meet you. Narses hearing this
report from the Ambassadors, suspecting some cunning in Totilas, prepared, as
to fight the next day: And he was in the right; for the next day Totilas came
with his whole Army. And they lay one against the other about a flight shot
off: Both parts had a mind to possess a little Hill, to gain advantage of
upper ground to shoot down on the Enemy, and there being also no beaten way to
the Roman Camp but by that Hill (the Camp being compassed by those round
Hills I mentioned) they esteemed it an important place, for the Goths to gaul
the Romans every way, and for the Romans to prevent that inconvenience. Narses
in the night time sent fifty choice men, who surprised the place, none
opposing. Before the Hill, and near the beaten way opposite to the Goths
Quarters runs a Brook; by this the fifty Romans stood close, body to body,
putting themselves into a square form. In the morning Totilas perceiving them,
sent a Troop of Horse to beat them away; who rode against them furiously and
with clamor, as if they would drive them away at the first onset: But they
stood thick and firm, and fenced close with their Sheilds, which clashing
together, and charging their Lances in sit time, all at once in order, they
bravely resisted the Goths hot assault; frighting their Horses with the noise
of their Sheilds, and the men with the points of their Lances. The Horses flew
back, having space enough to retire, and the men crying aloud to them, could
not be heard; but were thus beaten off. They came on again, and found the same
entertainment, and went off; and failing often, in the end they gave it over.
Totilas commanded out another Troop of Horse, who sped as the former, and so
did others after that; and Totilas having tried many Troops, and doing no good,
in the end quitted the business; whereby these fifty men got much reputation,
but especially Paul and Ausilas; who drawing their Cimiters, laid them before
them; then made many shots upon the Enemy, which killed many both men and
Horses; and their Quivers being empty, they took up their Swords and Sheilds,
and alone opposed the assailants, cutting off with their Swords their Lances
heads. And Paul having bowed his Sword with cutting the Lances, he threw it
away, and snatched from the Enemy four Lances, and by his valor was the
greatest cause of their despairing. Narses for this service made him one of his
Targeteirs. In the mean time both parts prepared for the Battle. Narses spoke
thus to his Soldiers.

When a Battle is to be with equal powers, happily it is necessary with
encouragements to get some advantage of the Enemy for the Victory: But you,
fellow Soldiers! being to fight with men inferior in valor, numbers, all
kind of preparations, need no more but with Gods propitious to begin this
Battle. Ever then with your prayers making him your assistant, march on with a
noble scorn against these thieves, the ancient Slaves of our Emperor, and now
Fugitives; though for a time they have troubled us, having gotten to themselves
a Tyrant picked out of their multitude. Indeed reasoning probably, it is most
strange that these men should so much as stand in rank against us. They are
weary of living, and like brutes and mad men run upon a manifest death; and
from that reasonlesse resolution, as they can have no hopes, so they care not
what befalls them, being men brought hither by God to be punished for their ill
government. When men have a sentence against them above, they run themselves
into their just chastisement You do likewise hazard in this Battle for a
lawful State, but they are Rebels, and struggle against the Laws. They think
not to leave their estates to their Posterity, and therefore live in momentany
comforts, which they know will be lost with their own breath: So that they are
to be despised. Men without Law and Government all good hopes fail, and
Victory abandons, which uses not to forsake the good cause.

Totilas also, seeing his Troops apprehensive of the Roman Army, used this
exhortation.

I am now, fellow Soldiers! to make to you my last Speech; we shall need no
more after this day, which certainly will conclude the fortune of the War.
Both our selves and the Emperor are even so spent with toils, fights, and
other necessities, that he that beats his Enemy, shall have need to fight no
more, and he that is beaten will have a fair excuse to be quiet. When men reap
from their affairs miserable fruits, they dare no more return to them, but
even in occasions vehemently pressing, their judgments start back upon the
memory of their former misfortunes. So that now it is you must fight, reserve
nor your valor for any other time, and endure now the labor, not preserving
your bodies for another hazard; and spare not Arms nor Horses, as things that
will no more be useful to you. Fortune having ruined all the rest, has left
us this day as the utmost of our hopes. Use now your courage, venture boldly;
our hopes hanging upon such a hair, we must not be remiss for the least
moment of time. The point of opportunity being past, the greatest endeavors
afterward fail; the nature of these affairs not admitting stale valor; all
must be unseasonable that comes after the occasion. So that let us do
effectually now, that we may find the benefit of what we do, and assure our
selves that running away is most ruinous. Men leave their rancks and fly, that
they may live; but when flying brings certain destruction, he that stands the
danger is safer then he that flies. And let us despise our Enemies, a mingled
multitude of many Nations. Such Auxiliaries are neither faithful, nor
powerful. As they are of several Nations, they have several intentions also;
and think not that the Hunnes, Herulians, and Lombards will hazard to the
death, or esteem their lives at a less rate then the Romans Money. They make
a countenance of fighting, but will turn cowards when they please; either
after receite of their pays, or upon their Commanders direction. The most
agreeable things not done freely, but upon the necessity either of compulsion
or hire, please not, but become grievous at last. Consider all this, and fight
with alacrity.

The Battles were thus put in order: they stood both in front, as deep and as
long as they could make it. The left wing of the Romans Narses and John had,
near the Hill, with the choicest men of the Army, being both followed with many
Lanciers and Targettiers, and excellent Hunnes, besides their Soldiers on the
List. In the right wing were Valerianus, John Phagas, and Dagisthaeus, with the
rest of the Roman Soldiers. The Battalion was of eight thousand foot, and the
Archers of the List; and between the same and both the wings were placed the
Lombards, Herulians, and other Barbarians; all whom Narses caused to alight
from their Horses, and to serve as footmen, that if they should turn willing
Cowards, they might fly but slowly. The left wing he put into the form of a
Wedge, and he set there fifteen hundred Horsemen, whereof five hundred were to
relieve the Romans, in case they should be put to the worst; and the other
thousand in the fight to get the backs of the Enemies foot, and to gaul them.
Totilas placed his Army in like manner, and rode about, with his countenance
and words animating his Soldiers. Narses did the like, holding out to them
gilt Chains and Bridles, as the Prizes of their valor that day.

CHAP. XIX.
BOth the Armies a while stood still, expecting each their Enemies assault:
Then a Goth named Cocas, much esteemed for valor, rode up to the Roman Army,
challenging any to fight with him. He had been a Roman Soldier, and revolted
to Totilas; to whom Anzalas an Armenian, and Lancier to Narses rode out. Cocas
spurd on to give the first blow with his Lance, aiming at his belly; Anzalas
turned his Horse aside, and avoided the blow, then thrust his Lance into his
left side, at which the Goth fell down dead, and the Romans shouted. Then
Totilas put himself between the Armies, not to fight a Duel, but to dally out
the time, understanding the two thousand Horse to be at hand, until whose
coming he would put off the Battle. He concealed who he was, wearing a Gilt
Armor, and from his Headpeice and Lance hung down streamers of purple; and he
was a gallant sigh, being bravely horst. He acted his feats of Arms skilfully,
winding his Horse round in a circle; then turning short, and making many such
circular passages: He tossed his Lance into the air in his full carriere, then
caught it as it came down again, and removing it skilfully from one hand to
another, he took much pride in his dexterity therein; lying upon his back, and
putting himself upon his Buttocks and bowing this way and that way, like a
Youth exactly taught all the tricks of a Dancing school. He spent a great part
of the afternoon in these exercises; then to gain more time, sent to the
Roman Army, offering a Parley. Narses said, he juggled, being before all for
War, and now making Propositions when the Battles were to join. In the mean
time came the two thousand Horse, which when Totilas understood, and it being
Dinner time, he caused the Army to draw off, and he went to his Tent; where in
his own quarter he found the two thousand Horse. He commanded his Troops to
dine, and himself put on another Armor, then led out suddenly against the
Enemy, thinking to surprise them unprepared: But Narses fearing what happened,
forbade his men to retire to their Dinner, or afternoons repose, or to put off
their Corslets, or to unbridle their Horses; commanding them in their rancks,
with their Armor on, to take a bit, and to have a perpetual eye upon the
Enemies return. They stood in the same order still, saving that Narses put
both the wings, with an addition of four thousand Foot, into the form of a
half moon.

The Goths Infantry stood behind their Horse, to receive them being routed
within their rancks, and jointly to renew the charge. Totilas commanded his
men, not to use their Arrows but their Lances; which senseless stratagem ruined
him, making hereby his Army inferior in their offensive weapons, as in all
things else. For the Romans used, according to the occasion, their Arrows and
Lances, and came up to the Sword, and did all which the present occasion
required, either charging on Horseback, or on foot, to their best advantage;
and sometimes compassing the Enemy, sometimes standing his charges. But the
Goths Horse, without their Foot, came on with unadvised fury, trusting only to
their Lances; and being in the midst of the Romans, they found their error,
being engaged among eight thousand Foot: By whom being gaulled on all sides,
they despaired: Our Archers drawing home the two ends of their Bows even to
their foreheads, and round like a half moon; so that the Goths, before they
could touch the Romans Horse, had lost many men and Horses. And after much
mischeife sustained, they came late up to the Romans Battalion of Horse; where
the Romans and Auxiliaries strove with equal valor, each one receiving the
Enemy bravely, and repelling them. Then the Evening coming on, the Goths began
to retire, and the Romans to pursue; the Goths being not able to stand after
their first furious charge, but turning about in confusion, daunted with the
Romans numbers and good order: And they gave over fighting; thinking that some
Spirits fell upon them, and that Heaven it self fought against them. When they
came to their Foot, there their mischeife increased; for they came not in any
orderly retreat, as to take breath for a new charge, or for any other point of
War, but ran in among them so confusedly, spoiling many, that they opened not
their rancks to receive them, but ran away with them for company, and it
growing dark they destroyed one another. The Romans killed them in this fear,
sparing none, and none daring to look them in the faces, who exposing
themselves to their Enemies, were pursued with terrors, and mastered with
cowardice. Six thousand were slain, and many taken Prisoners, and not long
after put to the Sword. Among them perished many Roman Soldiers, who had
revolted to Totilas. And now the darkness concluded the fight. Totilas fled in
the dark with five men, of whom Skipuar was one; he was pursued by some
Romans, who knew him not; among whom was Asbades a Gepaede, who had overtaken
him, and was making a blow at him: but a Gothish Boy following his flying
Master, cried out, Thou Dog! Do thou run after thine own Master to kill
him? But Asbades thrust his Lance forcibly into Totilas, and was himself hurt
in the foot by Skipuar, that he could follow no further; Skipuar also being
wounded, stood still: And the four men with Asbades followed no further, but
carried off Asbades. Those who accompanied Totilas rode on amain (thinking the
Enemy pursued still) and drew him after them, mortally wounded, and ready to
expire. Having run about ten miles, they came to a Town called Caprae; there
they rested, and dressed the wound of Totilas, who soon after gave up the
ghost: There they buried him and went away. Such a conclusion of his life and
reign had Totilas, having been King of the Goths eleven years; an end not
suitable to his former actions and successes. Fortune in him insulted upon the
frail condition of man, showing her strange proceeding, and absolute will.
She had without any apparent merit bestowed on Totilas a long time of
happiness; and now upon the sudden she hurryed him at her own pleasure into
cowardice, and an ignoble death. These are things to men incomprehensible, but
in all ages have been discoursed of according to men's conceits and fancies, to
comfort their ignorance with some seeming probabilities. But the Romans knew
not of the death of Totilas, till a Gothish woman told it, and showed his
Grave; who distrusting the report, opened the Grave, dug up the Coffin, and
took out the body, and finding it to be Totilas, they put him into the ground
again, and reported all to Narses. Some report this overthrow otherwise, that
the Goths did not make that unadvised retreat; but that in the first
skirmishing with the Romans, suddenly an Arrow, and by chance lighted upon
Totilas. For being armed like a common Soldier, and rancked among them in the
Battalion to conceal himself, he could not be known, nor purposely shot at.
But that being mortally wounded, in great pain he gallopt away with some few
with him to Caprae, and, after much misery and languishing, dyed under the
cure. And that the Goths amazed to see their King thus mortally wounded, and
gone off, being otherwise too weak, then became wholly out of heart, and fell
into that astonishment and shameful running away.

CHAP. XX.
BUT howsoever this fell out; Narses rejoicing at the success, took the True
course, to attribute all unto God: And he took order in the present occasions;
and first, to be rid of his unrulely Lombards, who were infinitely disorderly,
and burned houses, and ravished Women that fled into Churches. He bestowed
store of money on them for their Service, and sent them home; commanding
Valerianus, and Damianus, his Sisters Son, with their Troops to conduct them
out of the Roman Confines, that they might do no mischief in their way
home-ward. And so soon as these were out of the Roman Territories, Valerianus
besieged Verona; and the Garrison in it came to some Capitulation with him for
rendering the Town: But the Francks Garrisoned in the Towns of Venetia hindered
it, seeking with all their endeavor to get the whole Country to themselves;
whereupon Valerianus retired without effecting any thing.

The Goths who fled from the overthrow, went over the River Poe, and put
themselves into the City of Picenum, and other Towns about it, and made Teias
their King. He with the Treasures left by Totilas in Picenum, sought to draw
the Francks to his aid, and governed the Goths as he could in that Estate,
assembling them together. Narses advertised thereof, commanded Valerianus to
keep his Troops about the River Poe, to make the Goths rallying difficult:
Himself with the rest of the Army marched toward Rome. In Tuscany he took in
Narnia, and put a Garrison into Spoletum, with direction to reedifie the Walls
demolished by the Goths. He sent Troops also to attempt Perusia, commanded by
two Fugitive Romans, Meligedius, and Vlithus; who being one of the Lifeguard
to Cyprianus, was won by the allurements of Totilas to murder him, Commander
of the Roman Garrison there. Melegedius accepted the offers of Narses, and
consulted with his own Followers to yield the Town; which Vlithus with his
Friends openly opposing, was slain in the Fight, and the Town was rendered to
the Romans. Thus by Gods just Vengeance was Vlithus slain in the very place,
where he had murdered his Commander Cyprianus.

The Goths Garrisoned in Rome, hearing of the approach of Narses, put in
readiness to encounter him, as they could. At his first taking Rome, Totilas
had burnt most of the Buildings of the City; and then considering how the Goths
had not men enough left to Guard the whole Circuit of it, he took in with a
lesser Wall a small part thereof, about Adrians Tomb, joined it to the City
Walls, and so made it as a Castle; wherein the Goths laid their things of
Value, and guarded it carefully, neglecting the rest of the Walls. Yet then
desirous to try the Enemy, they left a few to guard that Castle, and put
themselves upon the Battlements. The Circuit of Rome so vast neither could the
Romans encompasse, nor the Goths guard; so that the assaults, and defenses were
accidentally in several places, as the occasions were. Narses charged one part
with multitudes of Archers; in another John, Sisters Son to Vitalianus, fell on
with his Troops. Another part Philimuth and his Herulians infested, and they
were far distant from one another: the Goths bravely resisting their Charges;
and being assembled all where the Romans fell on, the rest of the Walls were
empty. Dagisthaeus, with Narses consent, took some Troops with the Ensigns of
Narses, and John, and scaling Ladders, and set upon a part quite destitute of
Guards, and at his ease he mounted by his Ladders, none resisting; and then set
upon the Gates: the Goths seeing this, left their Guards and ran all away; some
to their new Castle, others to Portus. Writing this, it comes into my thoughts,
how Fortune plays with poor men; changing her looks with the times and places,
and varying suddenly not only her own humor, but even the value and worth of
the men. Bessas formerly lost Rome unworthily, and afterward recovered Petra in
Lazica very bravely. And on the contrary, Dagisthaeus poorly ran away from
Petra, and now soon after recovers Rome it self to the Emperor. These things
have been done from the beginning, and will be, while there is Fortune among
men. Narses then marched against the new Castle; But the Goths yielded it and
themselves, Anno 26. Just. Rome now had been taken five times in his Reign.
upon assurances for their Persons; Justinian being now in the 26th. year of
his Reign. Thus was Rome taken five times in his Reign, and Narses sent the
Keys of it to the Emperor. To the Roman Senate and People, this Victory
proved an extreme ruin; So to men that must have a mischief, even their
seeming good Fortunes turn to their destruction; that having had a fair
course, they both lose it, and undo themselves. For the Goths, now despairing
of the Dominion of Italy, in their flight killed all the Romans they found; And
the Barbarians of the Roman Army also, at their entering the City, used them all
as Enemies. Many Senators also confined by Totilas in Campania, and now
repairing to Rome (when they heard it to be in the Emperors possession) the
Goths quartered in the Towns of those parts, killed, and left not one
Patritian alive. Maximus was then slain, whom I have mentioned formerly.
Totilas also, going against Narses, called for all the Sons of the principal
Romans, and choosing out 300. of the goodliest of them, pretending to breed
them, but indeed holding them for Hostages: And he sent them beyond the River
Poe; whom Teias now finding there, killed them all.

Moreover, Ragnaris a Goth, who commanded in Tarentum, and had compounded with
Bacurius, (as I have said) to yield the City to the Emperor, and given six
Goths for Hostages: Now hearing of the Election of Teias, and that the Francks
were desired to aid him, and he immediately to march against the Romans, he
refused to perform the composition; and to get his Hostages again, he sent one
to Bacurius for a convoy of Soldiers to Otranto, from whence (he said) he
would go to Constantinople. Bacurius, not suspecting his plot, sent him 50.
men, whom Ragnaris imprisoned, and sent word to Bacurius, that if he meant to
have his Soulders, he must restore to him his Gothish Hostages. Bacurius led
out his Forces against him, leaving some few to guard Otranto. Upon this
Ragnaris killed the 50. Soldiers, and sallied out against the Romans, and in
fight was defeated, lost many men, and ran away into Acherontia, Tarentum being
blockt up by the Romans. The Romans soon after took Portus by composition, and
Nepa in Tuscany, and Petra Pertusa. Teias finding his Goths too weak for the
Romans, sent to Theudebald King of the Francks, importuning him with the offer
of great sums of Money to join with him. But the Francks took the resolution
best for themselves, not to bestow their lives upon Goths nor Romans, but to
adventure them only in the Conquest of Italy for themselves.

CHAP. XXI.
BUT Narses (hearing how Totilas had laid the most part of his Treasures in
the Castle of Cuma in Campania, with a strong Garrison under his own Brother
and Herodian) sent to besiege the said Castle, staying himself at Rome to
repair the ruins, and sent others to besiege Centumcellae. Teias fearing the
loss of this Castle, and the Treasures; and having no hope from the Francks,
commanded his Troops to be ready for a Battle with the Romans. Narses finding
his intention, commanded John and Philemuth, to martch with their Forces into
Tuscany, to stop the Enemies passage into Campania, and to assist in the taking
of Cuma. But Teias left his nearer way, which was to the right hand, and made a
huge compass; passing along the Sea coast of the Jonian Gulf into Campania.
Narses thereof advertised, remanded John and Philemuth, and sent for
Valerianus, who besieged Petra-Pertusa, and with his whole Army, in order to
fight, martcht into Campania. Mount Vesuvius in Campania (as I have said
before) often sends out a noise like the lowing of Oxen, which is ever
accompanied with a vomiting out of huge quantity of Cynders. Besides (as Mount
Aetna in Sicily) in the middle it has made it self hollow from the top to the
bottom, and below the fire burns perpetually: The fire is so deep, that
peeping in from the top, you cannot easily discern it. When the Mountain
vomits, the flame forces off pieces of rocks from the highest ridges of it,
shooting up the smaller pieces far above the Mountain, and scattering the
greater round about. From the top also of this Mountain runs a Torrent of fire
to the foot of it, and something further, as in Mount Aetna. This fiery stream
on either side makes high bancks, undermining the ground below; and when the
flame comes upon it, it looks like a flood of water set on fire. So soon as
the flame is quenched the stream stops its course; and the Sediment or Lees of
that fiery substance looks like dry Mud, and heaps of Cynders. At the foot of
the Mountain are wholesome Springs, from which comes the River Draco close to
the City of Nuceria: On either side of this River both Armies encamped; it has
a small stream but not to be past, being deep, as having worn out the ground
under the bancks very low. The Bridge which is upon it the Goths had gotten,
and being encamped near it, they had made upon it wooden Towers, and many
Engines, and set up Balistas to shoot down upon the Enemy. This River being
such, there was no possibility for a close standing Battle. So that each part
got as near as they durst to the banks, and plied one another with Arrows. Some
Duels there were also, sometimes Romans and sometimes Goths pasting over the
Bridge, and challenging all comers. Two months were thus consumed; and while
the Goths were Masters of the Sea, their Camp being near the Sea, was supplied
with provisions: But after the Romans had gotten their Ships by the Treason of
the Commander of them a Goth, and were re-enforced also with many other Ships
out of Sicily and other Roman Dominions; and that Narses had set up wooden
Towers upon the Rivers bank, the Goths hearts were absolutely dejected; and for
fear and famine were feign to fly up to a Mountain near there, called Mons
Lactis. The Romans for the fastnesses could not come at them: But the Goths
being there in more want, and having no way to get any provision for themselves
or their Horses, repenting their coming up, and choosing rather to dye by fight
then to starve, came suddenly upon the Romans, who stood against them as they
could, being taken unexpectedly, not being embattailed, nor under their
several Captains; not any way in order, nor at all observing what was
commanded them. The Goths quitted their Horses, and stood in a deep Battalion;
the Romans left their Horses and stood in front likewise. This fight, and the
valor of Teias in it, deserves a long discourse; being equal to that of the
ancient Heroes. Despair made the Goths venture all, and the Romans stood them,
though seeing them mad, yet ashamed to yield to beaten men; and so the one
weary of their lives, the other for demonstration of valor, fought with much
fury, beginning in the morning betimes. Teias accompanied with some few stood
in the first rank in open view, holding out his Shield and shaking his Lance.
A great number of Romans knowing that by his fall the Battle would be ended,
combined themselves against him, some charging, some throwing their darts at
him. Which he received all upon his Shield, and then slew out, and killed many.
His Shield being stuck thick with Darts, he gave it to one of his Targetiers
and took another. He continued thus a third part of the day, when he had twelve
Darts sticking on his Shield, that he could not move it as he would, nor beat
off the Assailants. Yet he quitted not his rank, nor gave the Enemy an inch of
ground; he did not so much as turn his body, or rest his back upon his Shield;
but stood upright, as if he were pitched into the ground, killing with his right
hand, and warding with his Shield; and calling by name his Targetier to give
him a new Shield, for his old was loaded with Darts. And in that instant, his
breast lying open, was hit with a Javelin, upon which he immediately dyed. The
Soldiers put his head upon a long Pole, and showed it to encourage the Romans,
and to cause the Goths to despair, and to quit the fight. But the Goths,
though they saw their King slain, yet gave it not over, and at night both
retired, and lay in their Armor. Early the next day they began again, and
fought till night, not turning to any side, nor giving back; and though many
were lost, yet their savage hatred held them still buckled to one another: The
Goths knowing it to be their last fight, and the Romans disdaining to be
overmatcht. At last the Goths sent Agents to Narses, to tell him; That they
perceived their fight to be with God himself, and saw the power which stood
against them; and their true estate now, by their former success; that they
would lay aside desperate resolutions, upon condition not to be put under the
subjection of the Emperor, but to live free with some other Barbarian Nation.
They entreated the Romans also to afford them a peaceable retreat, and in a
moderate consideration of their fortune, to bestow their own Goods upon them
for their journey, such as they had left in any Castles of Italy. Narses held a
consultation hereupon, where John advised him to grant the Petition, and to
contend no more with men weary of their lives, nor to stir a courage growing
from desperation, which commonly proves fatal, both to the men possessed with
it, and to such as encounter them. To moderate men (quoth he) it is enough to
be Victorious, whereas the desire of too much may end in some inconvenience.
Narses allowing the advice, they agreed upon conditions. That the Goths should
have their Goods, and immediately go out of Italy; and that they should never
bear Arms against the Romans. About a thousand Goths of this Company went away
to Picenum, and the parts beyond the River Poe, commanded by Ildulph and some
others; the residue stayed and ratified this agreement by their oaths: And the
Romans took in Cuma and all the rest. And so ended the eighteenth year of the
Gothic War, written by Precopius.

Finis Lib. 4. ^ell. Goth.

Dxa so THen m, dxa so
FINIS.
